answer: un deux trois quatre cinq (pronounced 'sanq' but the Q is dropped if a word follows cinq)
six ('sees') sept ('set') huit ('ueet') neuf dix ('dees')

dix-sept ('deeset') dix-huit ('deeswheat') dix-neuf ('deesnuff')
vingt ('vah')
vingt et un ('vante-oon') vingt-deux ('vant-dew') vingt-troix ('van-twoh')
vingt-quatre vingt-cinq vingt-six
vingt-sept vingt-huit vingt-neuf

question: For which 10's (under 100) do you have to add elements together?
answer: 70s (60 and add 10 11 12 13 etc to make the 70s) 80s (4 x 20) and 90s (80 and add 10 11 12 13 etc to make the 90s)
trente ('tront')
quarante ('karant'); The Q/K almost sounds like a hard G.
cinquante ('sah-cohnt'); The C/Q sound in the middle almost sounds like a hard G.
soixante ('swois-onT')
soixante-dix ('sois-on-dees')
quatre-vingt ('catre-von')
quatre-vingt-dix ('catre-von-dees')
soixante + soixante et un + soixante-duex + soixant-trois
soixante-dix + soixante et onze (use the 'et' with 1 and 11) + soixante-douze + soixante-treize
quatre-vingts + quatre-vingt-un + quatre-vingt-duex + quatre-vingt-trois

quatre-vingt-dix + quatre-vingt-onze + quatre-vingt-douze + quatre-vingt-treize; NB: to write out numbers add a dash between each word and delete a final S (e.g. from cents) if a word follows it - leave the final S if it is the last word in the number series.
cent (kind of like 'saw' in english but pronounced like sont in french)
cent un ('saw uh')
deux cents ('duh saw') + trois cents
deux cent un

question: Specify the pronunication: 500
answer: cinq cents ('san-sohn'; The Q sound at the end of cinq is dropped because it is followed by a word.)

question: Specify the pronunication: 600 coins
answer: six cents pièces ('see-sohn-pee-ays'); The S at the end of 'cents' is silent because followed by word that does not start with a vowel.

question: Specify the pronunication: 700 cash
answer: sept cents espèces ('sept-sohn-Zeh-spehs); Pronounce the S at the end of 'cents' as a Z because the following word starts with a vowel. A liaison is required.

question: Specify spelling and pronunciation of: 80 + 82 + 80 years.
answer: 80: quatre-vingts (silent S) + 82: quatre-vingt-deux (remove S in spelling because followed by more numbers) + 80 years: quatre-vingts an ('ca-tr-vuhn-Zan'; Keep the S in spelling because that is the word/number. Then the S makes a Z liaison with an because it starts with a vowel.)
mille ...one thousand - not one with decimals (exchange commas and periods moving from english to french)

question: 1997 (like the year)
answer: Years are spelled out (and spoken) as full numbers: mille-neuf-cent-quatre-vingt-dix-sept
six mille
dix mille (pronounced 'dimil' because we drop the x when a noun follows the 10)
cent mille
un million ...one million
cinq million ...no plural s
un milliard ...one billion

question: What time is it?
answer: Quelle heure est-il?; pronounced ...'ay-teel' because we link almost all words AND when a vowel follows est then we must pronunce the T - otherwise it would be two vowel sounds together which does not work in french; Use quelle (feminine singular form) because huere is feminine singular.

question: At what time does the class start?
answer: à quelle heure commence la classe?; à quelle heure + VERB + SUBJECT?; NB: Use classe to talk about the time you are at school. Use cours to talk about the type of class you are taking. e.g. un cours de tango (literally: a course of study)

question: the morning (6h to 12h)

question: midday/noon

question: the afternoon (12h to 18h)

question: the evening(18h to 22h)

question: the night(22h to 6h)

question: midnight

question: It is 1:00.
answer: Il est une heure.
sept heures; heures is pronounced 'euhr' (same sound as leur)
duex heures cinq; Do not use 'et' (and) if you are using numbers instead of quarter or half.; Pronounce the Q sound at the end of cinq because there is no word following it.
huit heures dix
neuf heures et quart

quatre heures vingt

dix-sept heures moins vingt

question: a second + a minute + an hour
answer: une seconde (the C almost sounds like a hard G) + une minute + une heure (liaison 'ooh-noor'); All denominations of time are feminine.

question: first + firstly
answer: 1e OR premier/première (m/f) + premièrement; '1e' is how you write floors of a building and the arrodissiments (e.g. 5e arrodissiment); Transform an adjective that ends in a consonant by selecting the feminine version of the adjective. Then add -MENT. This ensures a vowel is present before -MENT ending.

question: second
answer: deuxième / 2e (doo-ziem)

question: third
answer: troisième / 3e (twah-ziem)

question: fourth
answer: quatrième / 4e (ke-treim)

question: fifth
answer: cinqième / 5e (sanq-em)

question: sixth
answer: sixième / 6e (see-ziem)

question: seventh
answer: septième / 7e (seeup-tiem)

question: eighth
answer: huitième / 8e (wheat-iem)

question: ninth
answer: neuvième / 9e (nu-viem)

question: tenth
answer: dixième / 10e (dee-ziem)

question: eleventh
answer: onzième / 11e (ohn-ziem)

question: firstly
answer: premièrement; Use this when you are enumerating items or things that happened or will happen

question: secondy
answer: deuxièmement

question: a half (1/2) + a third (1/3)
answer: un demi + un tiers

question: a fourth (1/4) + a fifth (1/5)
answer: un quart + un cinquième

question: the 10th + the 20th + the 30th
answer: le dixième + le vingtième + le trentième

question: the 21st + the 22nd + the 23rd + the 31st
answer: le vingt et unième + le vingt-deuxième + le vingt-troisième + le trente et unième

question: the 100th (the hundredth) + the thousandth + the millionth
answer: le centième + le millième + le millionième

question: How do you pronounce: 6 people + 8 people + 10 people?
answer: six personnes ('see-pear-sohn') + huit personnes ('ooeet-pear-sohn') + dix personnes ('dee-pear-sohn'); Take care to drop the ending sound of the number when a noun follows it - NOT 'sees-pear-sohn' or 'dees-pear-sohn'.

question: How to pronounce a b c d e
answer: ah beh seh deh uh (like wool but the lips are a bit puckered and the sound is made high in the mouth; same sound as ö in german)

question: How to pronounce f g h i j
answer: eff zhey (like massage) ah-sh ee zhee/jhee

question: How to pronounce k l m n o
answer: kah ell ehm ehn oh

question: How to pronounce p q r s t
answer: peh keoo (like KEE with rounded lips) ehr ess teh

question: How to pronounce u v w x y z
answer: eew veh doobluh-veh eeks ee-grehk zehd

question: How are the following pronounced differently? à + â + a?
answer: no difference - these are all pronounced the same

question: How do you pronounce accent grave vs la grève (the strike)?
answer: grave ('grahv')...normal A sound in french / grève ('grave')... e with downward accent is pronounced like a hard A in english

question: How is 'an' pronounced differently than 'on'?
answer: 'an' is an open sound. The mouth is like in a big smile. The sound is nasal but towards the back of the nose/mouth. Pronunced like 'aunt' in British English.; 'on' is a closed sound. The mouth forms an o-shape. The sound is nasal but towards the front of the nose/mouth. The sound is short and a bit downward like a pout.

question: Pronounce these words with an open AN / EN sound: banc + sans + lent + Septembre + grand + jambre + champ + langue
answer: EN and AN sound like 'ohn' but with the corners of the mouth pulled back. Think 'aunt' in British English.; banc ('bohnk') + sans ('sohn') + lent ('lohn') + Septembre ('sehp-tohmbr') + grand ('grohn') + jambre ('zshohmbr') + champ ('shohm') + langue ('lohng')

question: Pronounce these words that all have the same open AN / EN sound: dans + en + éléphant
answer: EN and AN sound like 'ohn' but with the corners of the mouth pulled back.; dans ('dohn') + en ('ohn') + éléphant (ay-lay-fohn')

question: Pronounce these words with a closed AN / ENT which sounds more like like 'ohn': an (year) + camp + tante + vent (wind)
answer: an ('ohn') + camp ('kohm') + tante ('tohnt') + vent ('vohn')

question: How do you pronounce the written 'ai'?
answer: like 'ay'; e.g. j'ai is pronounced 'zshay'; Generally it is best practice to keep vowel sounds short - do not drag them out.

question: How do you pronounce the written 'au'?
answer: like a closed/ferme 'o' (called a hard O in English); e.g. au revoir ('oh-rev-ror') + aujourd'hui ('ohn-jer-dwee'); NB: AU makes the same sound as EAU and as Ô.

question: Pronounce the following: sauce + pause + épaule
answer: AU makes the same sound as EAU and as Ô... a hard/closed/downward O: sauce ('soes') + pause ('pose') + épaule ('ay-pole'); NB: AU is pronounced as one syllable but UA is pronounced as two syllables - two separate vowels.

question: What is this called: ç? And what does it do?
answer: C cédille; Ç is used to change the sound of a C from a hard K sound to a soft S sound. This is only necessary when the C is followed by A or O or U.; We do NOT need to make C cédille for ce or ci because those already sound like S. That is why c'est does not use C cédille.

question: How do you pronounce 'ce' and 'ci'?
answer: The C here is soft like S so 'suh' and 'see'; to make it sound harder like K you write 'cue' + 'cui'

question: How do you pronounce 'ca' and co' and 'cu'?
answer: The C in this cases is pronounced like a hard K.; To make the C sound like an S... use C cédille ...'ça' + 'ço' + 'çu'

question: How do you pronounce 'ça' and 'ço' and 'çu'?
answer: The C cédille changes the C from a K-sound to an S-sound: 'sa' and 'so' and 'su'.

question: Pronounce these words with 'ch': réchauffement + chou + chauflouer
answer: CH sounds like a soft 'sh' in English. réchauffement ('ray-showf-mohn') + chou ('show') + chauflouer ('show-floo-ay'); NB: The only words in french where CH makes the hard sound like 'chorizo' are words that are foreign to french. e.g. cheque from Czech.

question: When is a 'd' pronounced like T?
answer: When a liaison is required and the end of the first word is D. When you apply the liaison the ending D is pronounced as a T sound (e.g. un grand architecte is pronounced 'uhn-gran-Tar-shee-tehkt')

question: Pronounce these words with a regular E sound ('uh'): ce + que + petit + devez + sera + me + je + de + cheveaux + chemise + regard + depuis
answer: de ('duh') + me ('muh') + je ('zshuh') + ce ('suh') + que ('kuh') + petit ('puh-tee') + devez ('duh-vay') + sera ('suh-ra') + cheveaux ('zshuh-voh') + chemise ('zshuh-mees') + regard ('ruh-gar') + depuis ('duh-pwee')

question: Pronounce these words with 'eau' (sounds like a hard O): chapeau + l'eau + bureau + bateau
answer: chapeau ('shah-poe') + l'eau ('loe') + bureau ('bu-roe') + bateau ('bah-toe'); EAU and AU and Ô all make the same sound. A hard O where the sound is at the bottom of the mouth. The tone is very short and downward.

question: What is the name of this character and how is it pronounced? é
answer: L'accent aigu (acute accent) sounds like 'ay' instead of a regular e which sounds like 'uh'; Most of the time accent marks do not impact pronunciation significantly. É is the major exception.

question: What is the name of this character and how is it pronounced? è
answer: L'accent grave (grave accent) is pronounced exactly the same as ê... sounds like a light 'eh' sound with open mouth; e.g. lève ('lev')

question: What is the name of this character and how is it pronounced? ê
answer: L'accent circonflexe (circumflex) is pronounced exactly the same as è... sounds like a light 'eh' sound with open mouth; e.g. lève ('lev')

question: Pronounce these words with the open È or Ê sound (ouvert) which sounds like 'eh' in english: dès + êtes + près
answer: dès ('deh') + êtes ('eht') + près ('preh')

question: Pronounce these words with the closed E sound (ferme) which sounds like 'ay' in english: pied + ses + et + chez
answer: pied ('pee-ay') + ses ('say') + et ('ay') + chez ('shay')

question: How are these pronounced differently?: -ez / -er / -é / -et / -ai
answer: They are pronounced exactly the same. They are used often in verbs.

question: Pronounce these words where the EU is pronounced in an open way: ingénieur + beurre + peur + seul + fleur + cœur + cooleur + heures + leur
answer: with flattened mouth and an open sound high in the mouth (like a mix between 'uh' and 'ooh'): ingénieur ('uhn-juh-neuhr') + beurre ('beuhr') + peur ('peuhr') + seul ('seuhl') + fleur ('fleuhr') + cœur ('ceuhr') + cooleur ('coo-leuhr') + heures ('heuhr') + leur ('leuhr')

question: Pronounce these words where the EU is pronounced in a closed way: peu + ceux + feu + lieu + veux + monsieur + bleu + euro
answer: with a closed rounded mouth but the sound is still high in the mouth (not a deep U sound): peu ('poo') + ceux ('coo') + feu ('foo') + lieu ('loo') + veux ('voo') + monsieur ('mohn-soo') + bleu ('bloo') + euro ('oo-roh')

question: How are these words pronounced differently? un œil (an eye) + des yeux (eyes)
answer: UN ŒIL ('uhn-oouhy'; there are two vowel sounds in the last syllable but it is pronounced smashed together as one syllable. The mouth is open and flattened.; DES YEUX ('dayz-yoo'; The sound is still in the top of the mouth but the 'oo' sound is more closed than in œil.; There is a liaison but we still hear the Y sound.

question: When is G pronounced softly 'zsh' vs hard 'ghu'?
answer: 'ge' and 'gi' are soft; 'ga' and 'go' and 'gu' have the hard g sound. But this will change some if accents are added on the vowels.

question: When is J pronounced softly 'zsh' vs hard 'ghu'?
answer: J is always pronounced as a soft sound.

question: Pronounce these words with the soft 'zsh' sound: rejeter + danger + écologie
answer: rejeter ('ruh-zshuh-tay') + danger ('dahn-zshay') + écologie ('ay-kohl-oh-zshee')

question: How do you prounounce 'h' at the beginning of a word?
answer: It's completely silent and you ignore it. This means that if the second word in the letter is a vowel - then you may need to use a liaison to connect.

question: How do you pronounce î and ï differently?
answer: These are pronounced exactly the same.

question: How do you pronounce double I (ii) in french?
answer: It makes a Y sound.; This happens with verbs in the imparfait tense in the nous and vous forms. e.g. ÉTUDIER: nous étudiions + vous étudiiez

question: How do you pronounce all of these written syllables: in + ain + ein + en?
answer: It's an open nasal sound that is a mix between 'ohn' and 'uhn' - like INgénieur ('uhn-geh-noor')

question: Pronounce these words with an open 'in' sound: INgénieur(e) + main + train + chien + fin + coin + nain + pain + rien + saint + teint + lien + vin + chien + point + prochain
answer: INgénieur ('AHN-zshay-noor') is leading example for this group + main ('mahn') + train ('trahn') + chien ('shee-ahn') + fin ('fahn') + coin ('kwahn') + nain ('nahn') + pain ('pahn')+ rien ('ray-ahn')+ saint ('sahn') + teint ('tahn') + lien ('lay-ahn') + vin ('vahn') + chien ('shee-ahn') + point ('pwahn') + prochain ('proe-shahn')

question: How do you pronounce important + immueble? Why?
answer: important ('AHM-por-tahn' with the same open 'ahn' sound as ingénieur) + immueble ('EE-mobl'; imm makes a hard E sound because the I is followed by a double consonant which changes the sound of vowels)

question: Pronounce these words with a long 'EEL' sound: pile + il + fil (thread) + bile + avril + gilet + huile
answer: pile ('peel') + il ('eel') + fil ('feel') + bile ('beel') + avril ('ah-vreel') + gilet ('zshee-lay') + huile ('ooeel')

question: Pronounce these words with a long 'EEY' sound because the combination of 'ille' like Y in french: pille + famille + fille + grill + grille + maquillage + billet
answer: pille ('peey') + famille ('fa-meey') + fille ('feey') + grill ('gril'; This does not have lle so the sound is like an L instead of a Y) + grille ('greey') + maquillage ('ma-key-ahj') + billet ('bee-yay'); NB: ville is an exception as it is pronounced 'veel'.; NB: The combination 'elle' does not result in a Y sound. e.g. elle + voyelle

question: inalienable (as in a right); Specify the pronunciation.
answer: inaliénables ('EEN-ah-lee-ah-nabl'); NB: When IN is a prefix AND the N is between two vowels (as it in this case) instead of part of the word (like ingénieur)

question: indiscipline; Specify the pronunciation.
answer: indiscipline ('UHN-dis-ee-plin'); IN is a prefix in this case but the N is not between two vowels. So the IN is pronounced the same as ingénieur.

question: How do you pronounce 'll' in french and what are the two exceptions?
answer: ll is pronounced like Y (e.g. fille = 'feey' and famille = 'fa-meey'); the two exceptions are mille ('mil') and ville ('vil') which are pronounced like L

question: How do you pronounce 'r' at end of a word?
answer: light 'gh' at back of throat - put tongue at the top of back of mouth and blow air across it almost like a hiss (e.g. noir + catre + être) - it's more like a rolling g instead of a rolling r; If it's at the end of the word then you hit it quickly and lightly.

question: How do you pronounce 'r' in the middle of a word or when linking words?
answer: strong gurgling 'gh' witha trilling at the back of the throat.; Take care not to trill with the tongue which is a spanish R - not a french R.; When the R occurs in the middle of a word or link then you hit it very hard - as hard as the 'th' sound in english.

question: How to you pronounce 's' at the end of word? what about 'se'?
answer: if just one 's' then it is completely silent; but if an e follows the s 'se' (like française) then it makes a z sound

question: Which combinations of letters produce an S sound (instead of K or Z)?
answer: s (when not between two vowels) + ss + + sc + c + tion ('seeon')

question: How do you pronounce the french word association?
answer: 'ah-so-see-ay-syon'; almost every syllable has an S sound; TION in french is 'seeon'

question: How do you pronounce words that end in -TION?
answer: The ending is a very sharp 'seeon' - as quick and emphatic as non; It's very quick with a downward tone almost like a pout. There is no 't' or 'sh' sound as in english and spanish.

question: How do you pronounce le métro odéon?
answer: luh-may-tro-da-yon'; everything flows together and é is pronounced 'ay' instead of 'uh'

question: How do you pronounce 'oi'?
answer: 'wah' e.g. the king = le roi ('rwah') e.g. the law = la loi ('lwa')

question: Pronounce these words with an open 'o' sound (ouvert): personne + robe + mort + école + l'alcool (alcohol) + soldat (soldier) + hotte (hood)
answer: Sound is at the top of the mouth: personne ('pear-sohn') + robe ('rob') + mort ('mohr') + école ('ay-cohl') + l'alcool ('lal-cohl') + soldat ('sohl-da') + hotte ('hoht'); Remember that a double consonant can change the sound of the vowel that precedes the pair. e.g. personne

question: Pronounce these words with a closed 'o' or 'ô' sound (ferme): hôpital + diplôme + mot + policier + chocolat + dossier + pot + l'eaux + peau
answer: In english it is called a hard O. Mouth rounded. Sound in the bottom of the mouth. Short/downward tone.; hôpital ('ope') + diplôme ('ome') + mot ('moe') + policier ('poe-lee-seeay') + chocolat ('choe-coh-lah') + dossier ('doe-seeay') + pot ('poe') + l'eaux ('loe') + peau ('poe'); NB: This sound occurs with both o and ô. The accent does not make a large difference.

question: Pronounce these words with a closed 'on' sound: bon + don + son + long + Montpellier + oncle
answer: bon ('bohn') + don ('dohn') + son ('sohn') + long ('lohn') + Montpellier ('mohn-peh-leeay') + oncle ('ohncl')

question: How do you pronounce the 'o' at the end of a word? e.g. vélo + zéro + apéro + photo + bistro + numéro
answer: When an O is at the end of a word then use the closed/ferme sound with a short and downward tone. Do not drag it out. It is same sound as -eau at end of a word. The last syllable receives a lot of emphasis.

question: How is 'un homme' pronounced differently than 'un nom'?
answer: Un homme uses an open O sound. It is pronounced like a mix between 'ah-nohm' and 'ah-nahm'.; Un nom has closed O sound. It is pronunced like 'ah-nome'.; Both use liaison but the only way to tell the difference between these two when speaking is to differentiate the O sound.

question: How are these pronounced differently?: un os (bone) + des os (bones)
answer: un os ('uhn-ohs') is open/ouvert with sound at the top of the mouth. des os ('day-zoh') is closed/ferme with downward tone.

question: How are these pronounced differently?: on / -ont / -ons
answer: They are pronounced exactly the same. They are used often in verbs. The sound is very nasal.

question: How do you practice the difference between OU and U?
answer: Alternate saying: koukou and kuku. koukou is higher in the mouth with tongue pulled back from teeth. kuku is more downward with rounded lips and tongue resting on the bottom teeth.

question: How do you pronounce 'ou' (an open sound)? How do you pronounce these words: ou + où + nous + vous + sous + dessous + bouche + fou + four + jour + cour + route?
answer: OU is pronounced somewhat like an English U (the 'ooo' sound like in food). But the mouth is in a flattened shape and slightly open. The tongue does not touch the teeth - it is pulled back from the teeth a bit!; With the mouth in a flattened shape.: ou ('oo') + où ('oo') + nous ('noo') + vous ('voo') + sous ('soo') + dessous ('duh-soo') + bouche ('boosh') + fou ('foo') + four ('foor') + jour ('joor') + cour ('koor') + route ('root'); NB: VOUS (like 'food') is pronounced differently than VU (uses the french U sound which is more like 'ewww' with lips in pursed o-shape); The following spellings are all pronounced with the same sound: ou + où + ous + oux + oû + ow + hou + houx

question: How do you pronounce 'u' (a closed sound)? How do you pronounce these words: tu + Hugo + vu + eu (avoir passé composé) + musique + voiture + minute + rue + avenue + bus + rue + vue + mur + Lune + sucre + puce (chip)?
answer: The french 'U' is very different than the English U (which is pronounced like 'food'). The french U is a long 'ewwww' sound with pursed and rounded lips (o-shape). The tongue rests on the bottom teeth. The mouth is pursed in an O shape. The sound has a deep and downward tone / low in the mouth. You should feel reverberation of the sound - like a bass speaker.; tu ('teuww') + Hugo ('euww-go') + vu ('veuww') + eu ('euww') + musique ('meuww-zik') + voiture ('vwa-teuwwr') + minute ('mee-neuwwt') + rue ('reuww') + avenue ('ah-vuh-neuww') + bus ('beuwws') + rue ('reuww') + vue ('veuww') + mur ('meuww') + Lune ('leuwwn') + sucre ('seuwwkr') + puce ('peuwws')

question: How are these words pronounced differently? DEUX (2) + DOUZE (12)
answer: DEUX = mix between 'duh' and 'dooh' with flattened mouth and an open sound; DOUZE = 'dewwwz' the very deep french U sound with downward and closed tone - where the sound is not on the top of the mouth.

question: What's the difference in pronunciation between u and û and ù?
answer: There is no difference. These are all pronounced like the french 'U' which is very different than in English.; It's a long 'ewwww' sound with pursed and rounded lips (o-shape) in French. The tongue rests on the bottom teeth. It's not the 'oo' sound that we use for U in English.; NB: Even though u and û are pronounced the same in french they will change the meaning of a word in writing.

question: How do you pronounce: l'accentuation (emphasis)?
answer: 'lahk-suhn-syOO-Ah-syon'; UA is pronounced as two separate vowels. This is different from AU which is pronounced as single 'oh' sound.

question: How do you pronounce Y?
answer: Treat it like I. Y is a vowel in french.

question: How do you pronounce Zoe v Zoé?
answer: 'zo' v 'zo-ee'

question: How do you know whether or not to pronounce the 'e' at the end of a word?
answer: Never pronounce an E (without accent) at the end of a word.; If the E has an accent (e.g. é) then you pronounce it as 'ay' regardless of where it is in the word.

question: How do you know whether or not to pronounce a consonant at the end of a word?
answer: 1)DPST ('DePoSiTo') never pronounce these consonants at the end of a word - but pronounce them lightly if followed by 'e'; 2) LCFR ('lucifer') are the only four consonants that are pronounced when at the end of a word (e.g. aérobic) OR if at the end and followed only by an 'e' (e.g. livre) - otherwise the final consonants (regardless of if they are followed by an 'e') are not pronounced unless feminine adjective

question: Pronounce petit (masc singular) + petite (fem singular) + petits (masc plural) + petites (fem plural)
answer: 'puh-tee' + 'puh-teet' + 'puh-tee' + 'puh-teet'

question: When might you need to use a liaison between a two words?
answer: If the first word ends in a consonant and the second word starts with a vowel (or H muet = silent H).; NB: If the second word starts with an H aspiré (apirated H) then you cannot form a liaison. e.g. un homme ('uhn-ohm'; with liaison because H in homme is a silent H) + un héros ('uhn-hay-ro'; no liaison because H in héros is aspirated)

question: What is the difference between 1) liaison obligatoire 2) liaison facultative 3) liaison interdite? When do you use them?
answer: 1) Liaison obligatoire (obligatory) must be used in order to be understood in any scenario. There are many types of liaison obligatoire.; 2) Liaison facultative (optional) are used in formal settings. One typically does not use these in casual situations among friends.; 3) Liaison interdite (forbidden) are word combinations where the liaison is forbidden.

question: What are three major types of liaison obligatoire? (there are more than 3 in total)
answer: 1) Between a subject pronoun and its verb: Nous‿avons... Peut‿-on...; 2) Between le déterminent (e.g. article) and its noun: un‿intérêt + les‿amis + mes‿amis + quels‿adorables; 3) Between these prepositions and their object: dans + chez + sans + en. e.g. dans‿une maison + sans‿objectif + chez‿eux + en‿avance

question: How do you pronounce these? dans une heure + dans une usine
answer: Both phrases have two obligatory liaison - first between proposition and its object and second between a déterminant and its noun. dans‿une‿heure ('dan-zoo-noor') + dans‿une‿usine ('dan-zoo-noo-zeen')

question: When should you use a liaison 'z' ('lez') instead of ('les')?
answer: when the noun is a vowel; e.g. write les ordinateurs but pronounce it 'lez-or-din-at-ors'

question: After which two words is there never a liaison?
answer: 1) ET (and) 2) All the forms of tout (tout/toute/tous/toutes); e.g. et une café. There is no liaison between et and une ...even though the first word ends in a consonant and the second word starts with a vowel.; e.g. and Anna = et Anna ('ay-a-na') We do not hear the T from et even though Anna starts with a vowel.

question: When you are spelling a word out loud how to you say two A or two L or two O?
answer: duex A ('duh-za') + deux L ('duh-zelle') + deux O ('duh-zoo'); liaison Z is added

question: How do you pronounce: Quand est-ce qu'on arrive? (When do we arrive?)
answer: 'koh-Te-skuh-na-reev'; When the word quand (when) makes a liason... the ending D makes a T sound.

question: How do you pronounce: Je viens de?
answer: 'juh-vee-yun-duh'; the two vowels make two separate sounds

question: What is the rule for pronouncing phrases?
answer: The words in a phrase are linked like singing and the last syllable is drawn out more than the others. e.g. Vous allez bien is pronounced 'voo-za-lay-bee-uuuuuhn'

question: How do you pronounce two sequential words where the first word ends in a vowel and the second word starts with a vowel?
answer: You make a very clear break between the two verbs to ensure they do not run together. e.g. J'ai eu ('jay' 'oo'; not 'jayoo')

question: Explain how academic disciplines are pronounced.
answer: They can be spelled and spoken with full greek ending (e.g. sociology + philosophy + physiology) but generally they are spoken and written as socio + philo + physio etc.

question: What does it mean if you see 'a' without accent?
answer: A plain lone 'a' is always a verb - the conjugated form of avoir; Remember you always need to add an accent (grave or aigu) to a lone 'a' if you do not mean the verb avoir

question: How do you conjugate for 'we' when speaking?
answer: Use nous ___ for writing. Use on ___ for speaking. (same conjugation as il/elle) There is often a liaison between 'on' and the verb.; NB: If you spell out the subjects (e.g. Jack and I go to the store.) then the verb must be conjugated in the nous form (not the il/elle/on form).

question: two ways to say yes
answer: 1) oui (yes); 2) moi aussi (me too)

question: three ways to say no
answer: 1) non (no); 2) moi non pas (not for me); 3) si (when you are contradicting a negative statement - e.g. Vous n'êtes pas Caroline? Si je suis Caroline)

question: this/that
answer: ça ('sah')

question: This is... +  These are...
answer: C'est... ('say') + Ce sont... ('suh-son')

question: This is not... + These are not...
answer: Ce n'est pas... + Ce ne sont pas...

question: What are the three primary variations of 'this' and how are they pronounced?
answer: Ce 'suh' (masculine singular) + Cette 'set' (feminine singular) + Ces 'sayz' (plural regardless of gender)

question: There is milk. / There is no milk.
answer: Il y a DU lait. / Il n'y a pas DE lait.; The former has an unspecified amount so we use the partitive article DU for the masculine lait.; The latter has a negative (which means specified) amount so we use DE (or D' if the noun starts with a vowel).

question: There is oil. / There is no oil.
answer: Il y a DE L'huile. / Il n'y a pas D'huile.; The former has an unspecified amount so we use the partitive article DE LA for the feminine huile (contracts to DE L' in front of the silent H)..; The latter has a negative (which means specified) amount so we use DE (which contracts to D' in front of the silent H).

question: There are eggs. / There are no eggs.
answer: Il y a DES œufs. ('dez-oo'; fs is silent)/ Il n'y a pas D'œufs.; The former has an unspecified amount so we use the partitive article DES for the plural œufs.; The latter has a negative (which means specified) amount so we use DE (or D' if the noun starts with a vowel).

question: How do you make a noun plural?
answer: generally just add 's' but don't pronounce it - does not impact pronunciation; there are only a few exceptions (for example sometimes you add x like un bateau changes to des bateaux)

question: How do form the plural of nouns that end in -al? (e.g. un animal)
answer: -al becomes -aux ('oh'); e.g. un animal des animaux; e.g. un festival des festivaux; e.g. végétal végétaux

question: Excuse me.
answer: pardon / excusez-moi

question: please (formal and informal)
answer: s'il te plaît (when you are familiar) / s'il vous plaît (when you are unfamiliar) = S.V.P.

question: thank you
answer: merci

question: Three idiomatic ways to say: You're welcome.
answer: 1) very casual/everyday use: de rien ('duh-rian') literally means 'it's nothing' 2) friendly with generosity: avec plaisir ('plah-Zeer') literally means 'with pleasure'; 3) very polite: Je vous en prie. ('zshuh-voo-zohn-pree') This is something that a vendor in a store would say to a client.

question: How do you accept an invitation - the equivalent of 'Yes I would like to'
answer: Je veux bien. ('voo' but at the top of the mouth - not the deep U sound) This uses the verb vouloir (to want).; NB: Be careful to make the distinction between Je veux ('voo' at the top of the mouth) bien = I want to do it! AND Je vais ('vay') bien = I'm doing well.

question: Thank you for inviting me.
answer: Merci de m'avoir invité.

question: I want to introduce Anna.
answer: Je veux présenter Anna.

question: a greeting that is strictly formal and a greeting that is strictly informal
answer: enchanté (pleased to meet you only when formal) + salut (for hello only when familiar)

question: How do you greet someone in the morning + in the afternoon + in the evening (starting 18:00)?
answer: Bonjour. + Bon après-midi. + Bonsoir.; For politeness add Madame/Monsieur.; NB: Use -jour and -soir for greetings. Use journée and soirée (the durations) for the salutation when leaving.

question: when leaving someone: Have a nice day. + Have a good afternoon. + Have a good evening. + Good night!
answer: Bonne journée. + Bon aprés-midi. + Bonne soirée. + Bonne nuit.; For politeness add Madame/Monsieur.

question: Have a good weekend!
answer: Bonne week-end!; NB: 'fin de semaine' means Friday - not the weekend

question: See you later! (today). + See you soon! (but no today)
answer: À tout à l'heure! + À bientôt!;  NB: Add À in front of the word to make it a salutation. If you are simply saying the word for tomorrow or a day of the week - then just use the word without à in front of it. e.g. On va aller demain. = We will go tomorrow. On va aller mercredi. = We will go on Wednesday.; NB: tout à l'heure can also mean previously.

question: See you next week!
answer: À la semaine prochaine!

question: Until tomorrow!
answer: À demain! ('ah-doo-ma'); NB: Add À in front of the word to make it a salutation. If you are simply saying the word for tomorrow or a day of the week - then just use the word without à in front of it. e.g. On va aller demain. = We will go tomorrow. On va aller mercredi. = We will go on Wednesday.

question: goodbye
answer: au revoir; In Paris this is pronounced as two syllables 'ah-voi'.; For politeness add Madame/Monsieur.

question: I look forward to seeing you! / I can't wait to see you.
answer: J’ai hâte DE te voir!; Literally: I have haste to see you.; Avoir hâte should be followed by DE + INFINITIVE (what you are looking forward to doing).

question: I can't wait to hear what is next.
answer: J'ai hâte D'entendre la suite.; Avoir hâte should be followed by DE + INFINITIVE (what you are looking forward to doing).

question: I am happy that I saw it.
answer: Je suis content DE l'avoir vu.

question: I was glad/happy to see you.
answer: J'étais contente DE te voir.

question: How do you say ___ in french?
answer: Comment on dit ___ en français? ('co-mun-dee')

question: How do you write ___? / How is it written?
answer: Comment ça s'écrit ___? (comm-on-sa-say-creet) / Ca s'écrit comment? (sa-say-creet)

question: How do you pronounce ___?
answer: Comment ça se prononce?

question: What does this mean?
answer: Qu'est-ce qu ça veut dire? (kes-kuh-sa-voo-deer); Alternatively - in very casual situations - you could repeat the word in questions and then add: C'est quoi? (literally: It is what?)

question: It means...
answer: There are many ways to express this: 1) Ça veut dire... = It wants to say... 2) C'est à dire... = That is to say... 3) Ça signifie... = It signifies...

question: ...a word that means
answer: un mot qui veut dire; literally: a word that wants to say

question: the meaning + I do not remember the meaning.
answer: la signification + Je ne me souviens pas DE la signification.

question: Can you repeat slowly? / Repeat slowly please.
answer: Est-ce que vous pouvez répéter lentement? / Répétez lentement s'il vous plaît.; informal: Est-ce que tu peux répéter lentement? / Répètes lentement s'il te plaît.

question: That makes sense.
answer: C'est logique. OR Ça a du sens.; e.g. Ça a du sens pour toi? = Does it make sense to you?

question: It's useful.
answer: C'est util.; Be careful. This is ok to use for a thing (e.g. a tool is useful). But if you use it for a person (e.g. The politician is useful) then the connotation is that you are using that person to your advantage. It is NOT a compliment when used with a person.

question: It's practical.
answer: C'est pratique. ('pra-teek')

question: It's helpful.
answer: There is no idiomatic way to say this in french with an adjective for a person or even for a thing. Instead you have to say: It helps me. e.g. Ça m'aide. = It helps me.; Il m'aide beaucoup. = He helps me a lot.

question: It's certain. + It's not certain.
answer: C'est certain. + Ce n'est pas certain.; incertitude = uncertainty; Alternative: sûr (sure) is a similar adjective.

question: We are sure.
answer: On est sûr.

question: We wanted to make sure that we would keep the apartment.
answer: On voulait ÊTRE SUR DE garder l'appartement.; Alternative: S'ASSURER = to make sure

question: I think..
answer: je pense...

question: Do you think the same?
answer: Penses-tu la même chose? / Est-ce que tu penses la même chose?; Alternative: Est-ce que tu LE penses aussi?

question: ok / alright (when in agreement) +  ok? / do you agree?
answer: d'accord + d'accord? ('duh-cor')

question: How are you? (informal)
answer: Comment vas tu? / Comment ça va?

question: How are you doing? (formal)
answer: Comment allez vous?

question: What's the difference between 'Comment allez vous?' and 'Vous allez bien?'?
answer: They mean the same thing but the former uses the interrogative form (so no upward intonation required - it's obviously a question); the latter uses the affirmative form (just a statement) so you must say with upward intonation to make it sound like a question.; The latter (reversal of subject verb) is more polite.

question: How was your day?
answer: Comment ta journée s'est passé(e)?

question: It's ok / it's going alright
answer: ça va! + ca va? (sa-va)...it is used as both question (is it going ok?) and response (it's going ok); the literal translation is "it goes" and it is conjugated in that way e.g. il/elle/on va

question: so-so + kind of (meaning a little bit)
answer: comme si comme ça + en quelque sorte; En quelque sorte can only be used in this sense. It cannot be used to say: a kind of music.

question: and you? (informal + formal)
answer: et toi? + et vous?

question: I hope you are doing well (for emails/texts)
answer: J'espère que tu vas bien.

question: How to close a letter
answer: Cordialement . (for business correspondence) + Chaleureusement ('warmly' for more casual correspondence)

question: a family name / a first name
answer: un nom / un prénom

question: My name is x.
answer: Je m'appelle x. OR...informally: Moi c'est x.

question: But my friends call me x.
answer: Mais mes amis m'appellent x.

question: a nickname
answer: un surnom; Take care because this is a 'faux ami'. It does not mean surname (British English for last name).

question: What is your name? (informal)
answer: Comment tu t'appelles? / Quel est ton nom?; nom is masculine so QUEL and ton must agree with it

question: What is your name? (formal)
answer: Comment vous vous appelez? / Quel est votre/ton nom?; nom is masculine so QUEL and VOTRE must agree with it

question: I am x years old (this year).
answer: J'ai x ans (cette année).; The number + ans is spoken very quickly; it's also fully linked together (e.g. 44 ans = 'catr-von-ca-TRON' where the end of the number has a liaison with ans); ans is a very quick nasal sound 'on' on the end; 'This year' is a duration so use année. Ans is used for counting (e.g. years old).

question: When I was 19 years old...
answer: Quand j'avais 19 ans...;Use imparfait because age is part of the setting in the past - like telling a story.

question: When I was in my 30s...
answer: Quand j'avais une trentaine d'années...

question: How do you pronounce when saying you or someone's age?
answer: there is always a linking between number and 'ans'; 'ans' is pronounced 'oh' super nasal

question: How old are you (informal)?
answer: Quel âge a tu?; Use QUEL because âge is masculine and singular here.

question: What are their ages?
answer: Quels sont leurs âges?; Use QUELS because âge is masculine and we are using the plural here.

question: I am X meters tall.
answer: Je mesure ('meh-zoor') 1`8 mètres.

question: I am a software engineer.
answer: Je suis développeure. OR Je suis injènieure logiciele.

question: What is the formal name for a software engineer - if you write it?
answer: Ingénieur en développement logiciel or Ingénieur en génie logiciel

question: I taught myself something.
answer: J'ai appris + quelque chose + en autodidacte.

question: I have a health issue.
answer: J'ai des problèmes de santé.

question: I am healthy + I am sick.
answer: Je suis en bonne santé. + Je suis malade.; Use 'en bonne santé' to describe the health of a person.

question: not healthy / not good for your health (like for food)
answer: pas sain; Do not use this to say that a person is not in good health.

question: I eat health(y).
answer: Je mange sainement.; sainement is an adverb that describes an activity (verb) that is good for a person's health (santé).; sain is used for objects; santé is used for people

question: What do you say when someone sneezes?
answer: á tes souhaits (a-te-sway) ...familiar / á vos souhaits ...formal; éternuer = to sneeze

question: No problem.
answer: pas DE problème; Use DE because PAS is a quantity.

question: to stay / to take-away (when ordering at a café)
answer: sur place / emporter

question: Hold on (when putting someone on hold)
answer: Ne quittez pa ('nuh-key-tay-pa'); literally you (formal) do not leave; the verb is quitter

question: I'm sorry.
answer: Je suis desolé(e).; Add the extra E if you are a woman because it is an adjective that modifies JE.

question: I was wrong.
answer: Je me suis trompé(e).; Add the extra E if you are a woman because it is an adjective that modifies JE.

question: Well done! (when someone succeeds at something)
answer: Bien joué! ('zhoo-ay'); loosely translated: they played it well; There are two syllables because this is in a past tense instead of present tense.

question: Good job!
answer: Bon travaille !

question: It's magnificent. + It's marvelous.
answer: C'est manifique. (There is no G!) + C'est merveilleux. ('mare-vay-yo')

question: idiomatic ways to say: It's exciting! or I'm excited!
answer: 1) C'est enthousiasmant! = It's exciting news!; 2) Je suis content(e) pour toi. or Je suis impatient(e) pour toi.; In french you do not say that a person is excited unless you mean aroused.

question: idiomatic way to say: I enjoy... e.g. I enjoy swimming.
answer: Je prends du plaisir à + INFINITIVE; e.g. Je prends du plaisir à nager.

question: Was I right/correct?
answer: Est-ce que j'avais bon?; Generally the word good (bon/bonne) is used to mean correct.; Alternatively you can use the adjective exact(e). C'est exact. = That is correct.; Do NOT use 'correct' which technically exists in french but is extremely anglo.

question: You are right/correct.
answer: Tu as raison ('ray-zon').; Avoir raison is the way to express someone being correct.

question: You are reasonable.
answer: Tu es raisonnable.; raisonnable is the adjective that describes a person.

question: the correct choice / the correct response
answer: le bon choix / la bonne réponse

question: It doesn't matter.
answer: Two ways: 1) Ce n'est pas important. (It is not important.; Remember Z liaizon between pas and important.); 2) Ce n'est pas grave.

question: I don't care.
answer: The best translation is not direct. Two options: 1) Formal/polite: Je m'en fiche.  2) Informal/common: Je m'en fou.

question: whatever
answer: peu importe

question: I do not know. (when you don't have the information)
answer: Je ne sais pas.; pronounced 'shpa' in paris - very short and common

question: I do not know. (when you're not familiar with the person/topic)
answer: Je ne connais pa.; the verb is connaitre; connaissance is knowledge

question: I didn't know what to do. vs I didn't know what I had to do.
answer: Je ne savais pas QUOI faire. vs Je ne savais pas CE QUE je devais faire.

question: ...what to expect
answer: ...à quoi m'attendre

question: Do you understand English? (informal/formal)
answer: Comprends-tu anglais? / Comprenez-vous anglais?

question: I understand most of the sentences.
answer: Je comprends la plupart des phrases.; la plupart + DE + the thing

question: I understood a lot.
answer: J'ai très bien compri.; Do not use beaucoup in this case.

question: I did not understand.
answer: Je n'ai pas compris.

question: I do not understand all.
answer: Je ne comprends pas tout.

question: idiomatic way to say: I did not understand much. (use imparfait)
answer: Je ne comprenais pas grand chose.

question: You do not understand what they say.
answer: Tu ne comprends pas ce qu'ils disent.; QUE contracts with any word starting with a vowel.

question: I still only understand some sentences.
answer: Je continue de ne comprendre quelques phrases.; Translating STILL depends on the context. In this case use the verb CONTINUER (to continue) + DE because you are following the conjugated verb with another verb + NE to negate the infinitive.

question: My oral comprehension is not good.
answer: Mon comprehension oral n'est pas très bonne.

question: I continue to try.
answer: Je continue d'essayer.

question: I will get it (eventually).
answer: Je compredrai.; I will understand - using futur simple. This is a good way to express this sentiment.

question: It takes time to understand.
answer: Ça prend du temps pour comprendre.; This is an idiomatic expression in french that is very similar to the expression in english.

question: how quickly the people speak
answer: à quel point les gens parlent vite; à quel point is an idiomatic phrase - it can't be directly translated to english.

question: I like to dance.
answer: J'aime danser.

question: I like red wine.
answer: J'aime le vin rouge.

question: I don't like rose wine.
answer: Je n'aime pas vin rosé.

question: I don't like to sing.
answer: Je n'aime pas chanter.

question: I don't like peanut butter.
answer: Je n'aime pas le beurre de cacahouète.

question: I like it.
answer: J'aime bien. This is the best option.; You could also say: J'aime ça. But that is not idiomatic french.

question: I liked it.
answer: J'ai bien aimé.; You really do not need to use a pronoun (for it - the thing that you liked) with this phrase.

question: What is the difference between these two statements? J'aime le chocolat. + J'aime BIEN le chocolat.
answer: There is no difference in the translation: I like chocolate.; You can always add BIEN for emphasis but the statements are equivalent.

question: I like cocktails a lot.
answer: J'aime BEAUCOUP les cocktails.; This is how you express that you like something a lot.; Beaucoup is modifying the verb in this case (instead of indicating a quantity of the thing that is liked). You are not saying 'I like a lot of cocktails'. So there is no DE between beaucoup and the noun (les cocktails).

question: I like a lot of cocktails.
answer: J'aime BEAUCOUP DE cocktails.; Beacoup is a quantity in this case (instead of modifying the verb aimer). You are not saying 'I like cocktails a lot.' So you must use BEAUCOUP DE.

question: My husband likes to cook a lot.
answer: Mon mari aime BEAUCOUP cuisiner.

question: I like both.
answer: J’aime les deux.; Always use an article before a noun (deux).

question: Do you like X? (formal and informal)
answer: Aimez-vous X ? / Aimes-tu X ?

question: a formal way to ask: Do you like it? (used by venders when presenting an item).
answer: Ça vous plaît ?

question: Who is your (formal) favorite actor / actress (masculine)?
answer: Quel est votre acteur préféré / actrice préféréE ?

question: Who is your (informal) favorite singer (masculine)?
answer: Quel est TON chanteur préféré / TA chanteuse préféréE ?

question: Who is your (formal) favorite band?
answer: Quel est votre groupe préféré ?; le groupe is masculine

question: You adore the band The Donnas.
answer: Tu adores le groupe The Donnas.; use the article and noun - no preposition

question: I adore clothes.
answer: J'adore vêtements.

question: I appreciate jazz and rock.
answer: J'apprécie le jazz et le rock.; verb: apprécier

question: How do you express 'I appreciate you'?
answer: Do not translate directly. Just say: J'apprécie. (without an object pronoun)

question: I appreciate the meal.
answer: Le repas est trés apprecié.; In this case you must explicitly express the object (the meal). So you cannot use the verb apprécier. Instead use the adjective (apprecié) to describe the meal.

question: I'm a fan of Wu-Tang.
answer: Je suis fan de Wutang.; use DE preposition before the object

question: I am passionate about hiphop.
answer: Je suis passionné de musique hip hop.; use DE preposition before the object

question: My musical tastes are quite broad.
answer: Mes goûts musicaux sont plutôt larges.

question: I am a costume-lover.
answer: Je suis amatrice de costumes.; use DE preposition before the object

question: I am crazy about...
answer: Je suis fou de course à danse.; use à before the object

question: I'm interested in modern art and sculpture.
answer: Je m'intéresse à l'art moderne et à la sculpture ('skool-toor'; do NOT pronounce the P.).; This uses the verb intéresser reflexively. Use à before the object.

question: interested
answer: intéressé(e); This is a common pattern with adjectives. Elle est intéressée. = She is interested. Elle est intéressant. = She is interesting.

question: interesting
answer: intéressant; This is a common pattern with adjectives. Elle est intéressée. = She is interested. Elle est intéressant. = She is interesting.

question: It is interesting that...
answer: C'est intéressant que... ; This triggers the subjonctif tense for the phrase that follows.

question: leisure/hobbies
answer: les loisirs

question: interests + an interest
answer: les goûts ('goo') is idiomatic french for interests + un intérêt is commonly used to me an interest - like a hobby; NB: If you pronounce the T it is a different word: une goutte (a drop e.g of rain)

question: He is allergic to shellfish + walnuts + hazelnuts.
answer: Il est allergique (with soft g) AUX crustacés ('cru-sta-sets') + noix ('nua') + noisettes ('nu-ah-zet').

question: What is the difference between these words and how are they pronounced differently: noix + noir
answer: noix = walnut ('nwa' because the X is silent) + noir = black ('nwar' because the R is not silent)

question: Go ahead. (when you are opening the door for someone or letting them go ahead of you)
answer: Vas y. (informal; pronounced 'vah-zee') + Allez y madame/monsieur. (formal; pronounced 'ah-lay-zee')

question: How was it? (informal)
answer: Ça a été? (sa-EH-tay) ...really common and shortened; There is an implied 'bien' in the phrase. The full formal version might be "(Est-ce que) ça a (bien) été ?"

question: It's nice.
answer: C'est sympa.; This comes from the word sypathique which means friendly/pleasant/nice - not sympathetic.

question: It's great.
answer: C'est super.

question: It's perfect.
answer: C'est parfait.

question: It's cool.
answer: C'est cool.

question: It tastes great.
answer: C'est délicieux. ('day-lee-sow')

question: It was good.
answer: C'etait bien.; literally: It went well. This is idiomatic french.; Bien is an adverb (well) that describes a verb. So we do not use bon/bonne/bons/bonnes (the adjective for good) in this case.

question: It was a good day.
answer: C'etait une bonne journée.; We use the feminine journée because we are referring to the things that happened during the day (duration). Do NOT say: C'etait un bon jour. That would imply that there is something special about the day regardless of what happened - like a lucky date.

question: It was a good weekend.
answer: C'était un bon week-end (masculine).; Use bon/bonne/bons/bonnes because good is an adjective that modifies the noun. We do not use bien (well) which would need to modify a verb.

question: It would be good...
answer: Ce serait bien... (futur simple)

question: It's not bad.
answer: C'est pas mal.; Take care because 'pas mal' can also mean: quite a lot.

question: It's bad.
answer: C'est mauvais. ('say-mow-vay')

question: blah (when you have a negative reaction to something)
answer: bof

question: What a disappointment!
answer: Quelle déception!

question: It's horrible.
answer: C'est horrible. ('se-toe-reebl')

question: It sucks.
answer: C'est nul.

question: It's frustrating.
answer: C'est frustrant.

question: It's annoying./It's boring.
answer: These sentiments are not easy to distinguish in french. Both words could translate to ennuyant ('uh-nee-yohn') or ennuyeax ('uh-nee-yow').; Ennuyant tends to describe something that is temporarily boring/annoying. If you want to describe an annoying person then ennuyant is probably the best choice. There are some cases where ennuyeax sounds weird so if you are not sure then always default to ennuyant.; Ennuyeax tends to describe something that is actively or persistently boring/annoying. If you want to describe a boring person then ennuyeax is probably the best choice. But take care because there are some situations where ennuyeax sounds weird.

question: the boredom + the joy
answer: l'ennui + la joie ('jwa')

question: It's the same thing.
answer: C'est la même chose. / C'est egal.

question: at the same time
answer: en même temps; NB: temps is almost always plural - it always ends with S.

question: your free time
answer: ton temps libre

question: It tastes good. + It's delicious.
answer: C'est bon/bonne. + C'est délicieux/délicieuse (m/f).

question: It's very tasty/flavorful.
answer: C'est très gouteux.

question: the flavor
answer: la saveur (the specific type of flavor; e.g. strawberry ice cream) OR le goût ('tastiness' in general)

question: We ate well.
answer: Nous avons (très) bien mangé.; Bien is the adverb that modifies the verb manger. Generally the adverb is placed before the verb it modifies. Because bien is an adverb it does not adapt to agree (in number or gender) to the verb it describes - unlike adjectives.

question: I am hungry.
answer: J'ai faim.; Remember that the M is silent. Pronounce it the same as the word fin ('foh')

question: You are thirsty.
answer: Tu as soif. ('swof')

question: I am afraid/scared.
answer: J'ai peur. ('purr'); literally: I have fear.

question: to be right / They are right.
answer: avoir raison / Ils ont raison.

question: to be wrong / We are wrong.
answer: avoir tort / Nous avons tort.

question: to make mistakes
answer: faire des fautes

question: a mistake + a typo / an error
answer: une faute + une erreur

question: idiomatic way to say: I did not make any mistakes.
answer: Je n'ai fait aucune faute.; Use the singular form of mistakes (une faute = a mistake).; NB: There is no DE following aucune even though we are talking about a lack of something / negative quantity.

question: idiomatic way to say: It's my fault.
answer: C'est ma faute.

question: idiomatic way to say: I have no idea.
answer: Je n'en ai aucune idée.; NB: There is no DE following aucune even though we are talking about a lack of something / negative quantity.

question: to have good luck + She has good luck.
answer: avoir DE LA chance + Elle a DE LA chance.

question: You have a lot of luck. (two ways)
answer: Tu as beaucoup DE chance. + Tu as bien DE LA chance.; In the first case you saying the person literally has (AVOIR) a quantity of something (beacoup DE chance). In the second phrase you are using the verb 'avoir DE LA chance' (to have luck) and simply adding BIEN to modify the verb.

question: Why?
answer: Pourquoi? ('poor-kwa')

question: What is the difference between Pour quoi? and Pourquoi?
answer: Pour quoi? translates to What for? - respond with POUR + INFINITIVE = in order to X.; Pourquoi? translates to Why? - responde with PARCE QUE + SUBJECT + VERB.

question: because
answer: parce que ('par-se-kuh') OR car (shortened version); Use parce que (instead of à cause de or grâce à) for most scenarios and especially when you follow with a phrase. e.g. Because I went to the store... = Parce que je suis allé(e) au magasin...

question: Because of X...
answer: Use one of two expressions depending on the context. 1) À cause de + noun: used when the consequence is negative. 2) Grâce à + noun: (literally 'thanks to...') used when the consequence is positive.; NB: Use à cause DES + plural noun. Use grâce AUX + plural noun.

question: with negative connotation: Because of technology... + Because of cars...
answer: À cause DE LA technologie... + À cause DES voitures...; Use DE for singular nouns and DES for plural nouns.

question: with positive connotation: Thanks to technology... + Thanks to donations...
answer: Grâce À LA technologie... + Grâce AUX dons....; Use À for singular nouns. Use AUX for plural nouns.

question: idiomatic way to say: That's why...
answer: C'est pour ça...; e.g. That's why I was late. = C'est pour ça j'étais en retard.

question: for example
answer: par exemple ('par-ex-ompl')

question: also
answer: aussi ('osi')

question: like this
answer: comme ça

question: How do you ask: Is it X?
answer: Est-ce X? ('ehsss'); Remember that Est-ce (Is it?) is the inverse of C'est (It is.) So... It is difficult. = C'est dificil. Is it difficult? = Est-ce dificil?.; You construct the simple question by replacing C'est with Est-ce.

question: How do you ask: Is that X?
answer: Est-ce que c'est X?; Literally: Is it that it is X?; e.g. Is that bizarre? = Est-ce que c'est bizarre?

question: What is this and how do you pronounce it?: Est-ce que...?
answer: This is a super common and informal way to begin a yes/no question.; The whole thing is pronounced 'ehssss-kuh' - the s sound is long at the beginning.; Est-ce que... indicates the beginning of a yes/no question - it is not asking 'how' or 'what'.; A potential translation of est-ce que: Is it that which...?; NB: The subject and verb NEVER reverse if you use Est-ce to ask the question (Est-ce + subject + verb); If you want to speak more formal french then use the reversal of subject and verb (plus upward intonation) to pose a question (instead of using Est-ce que...?).

question: How do you ask: What is ...?
answer: Generally: Qu'est-ce que ...? ('kes-kuh'); This is always followed by subject + verb. Do not invert the order when forming the question.; NB: Do not always use QUE to translation 'what'. In french it matters whether you are asking for a subject that is doing the action (use QUE) or a direct object with a preposition (use QUOI).

question: What is this and how do you pronounce it?: Qu'est-ce que...?
answer: The whole thing is pronounced 'kes-kuh'. It is a contraction of QUE + EST-CE QUE.; This is generally how you ask: What is...? The response is NOT yes/no. You are asking for a noun.; NB: In french it matters whether you are asking for a subject (QUE) or a direct object (QUOI).

question: What are three ways to ask a closed (yes/no) question?
answer: 1) Soutenue (formal with inversion): VERB + DASH + SUBJECT ? (e.g. Vas-tu? = Are you going?); Often uses a dash between verb and subject with added T for pronunciation as needed.; 2) Standard (aka interogative or courante): EST-CE QUE + SUBJECT + VERB? Remember that a noun ALWAYS follow EST-CE QUE. No inversion of subject/verb when using est-ce que! (e.g. Est-ce que tu vas? = Are you going?); 3) Familiére (aka affirmative): SUBJECT + VERB?; You must use intonation to make it sound like a question. Only use this structure with friends in very casual situations.

question: What are three ways to ask an open (non-yes/no question)?
answer: It is the same three options as closed questions. To make the question open we add an interogative word (que + quand + où + pourquoi + comment...). Add it at the beginning of the formal and standard formats. Add it at the end of the familiar format.; 1) Soutenue: MOT INTERROGATIVF + VERB + DASH + SUBJECT ? e.g. Où vas-tu? = Where are you going? 2) Standard: MOT INTERROGTIF + EST-CE QUE + SUBJECT + VERB? e.g. Où est-ce que tu vas? = Where are you going?; 3) Familiére: SUBJECT + VERB + MOT INTERROGATIF? e.g. Tu vas où? = You go where?; NB: When using the familiar form you will typically use DE QUOI instead of QUE to signify 'what' because we need a preposition. e.g. You know OF what?

question: How do you use a proper noun (instead of a pronoun) when asking a question using the soutenue/formal form? e.g. Is Patrick Irish?
answer: Patrick est-il irlandais?; To use the soutenue form when the subject is not a pronoun you must repeat the subject as a pronoun for the inversion: SUBJECT NOUN + VERB + DASH + SUBJECT PRONOUN.

question: Specify pronunciation of: Quand est-ce que tu vas? + Quand es tu libre? Explain the difference.
answer: Quand est-ce que tu vas? ('qan-Tuh-skuh-too-va') + Quand es tu libre? ('qan-Ehs-too-leebr'); Add a T liaison between QUAND and EST-CE. But there is never a liaison between QUAND and a VERB (e.g. es). Pronounce the two words separately without liaison in the second case.

question: Ask this question in two ways: Do you (formal) know of / are you familiar with X?
answer: 1) Soutenue (with inversion): Connaissez-vous X? 2) Interogative (using est-ce without inversion): Est-ce vous connaissez X?

question: Ask this questions in two ways: What did you (informal) do last weekend?
answer: 1) Soutenue (with inversion): Qu'as tu fait la semaine dernière?; 2) Interogative (using est-ce without inversion): Qu'est-ce que tu as fait la semaine dernière?; NB: QUE contracts with a following word that starts with a vowel.

question: How do you ask this question in a very casual setting with a close friend: What did you do last weekend?
answer: Very informal structure (without inversion): Tu as fait QUOI la semaine dernière?; Reserve this structure for extremely familiar situations.

question: How do you change this to be a fully interogative question: Il est bon le poulet?
answer: Est-ce qu'il est bon le poulet?; NB: The QUE and subject IL get pushed together with apostrophe but they are pronounced all together as one word. Always ignore an apostrophe for pronunciation.

question: Do you have to work?
answer: Est-ce que tu dois travailler?

question: How do you know whether to use QUE or QUOI when asking 'what'?
answer: In french it matters whether you are asking for a subject that is doing the action (use QUE) or a direct object with a preposition (use QUOI)... even though often times in english we omit that preoposition. An example with QUE: What is the thing on the table? = QU'est-ce que la chose sur la table? The thing is the subject that is doing the action (being on the table). So we use QUE to refer to the thing when asking the question.

question: Best way to ask the question: What is it?
answer: There are three ways to ask this question: 1) Best/Normal: Qu'est-ce que c'est? ('kes-kuh-say') literally means: What it is? It does not require a preposition (e.g. of what? + for what?) because the it/what is the subject. So we use QUE (instead of QUOI) in this case. 2) Familiar (only use with friends): C'est quoi?; 3) Ultra formal (rarely heard / ignore): Qu'est-ce?

question: Best way to ask the question: What is it about? (like when you see someone with a book and you are curious what it is about)
answer: There are three ways to ask this question: 1) Best/Normal: Qu'est-ce que ça raconte?; 2) Familiar (only use with friends): Ça raconte quoi?; 3) Ultra formal (rarely heard / ignore): TBD

question: Best way to ask the question: What are you doing?
answer: There are three ways to ask this question: 1) Best/Normal: Qu'est-ce que tu fais?; 2) Familiar (only use with friends): Tu fais quoi?; 3) Ultra formal (rarely heard / ignore): Que fais tu?

question: What happened?
answer: Qu'est-ce qui s'est passé?

question: What did I say?
answer: Qu'est-ce que j'ai dit?

question: What are we eating? We are eating X.
answer: Qu'est-ce qu'on mange. On mange DU X.; NB: 'Que' and 'on' merge together using apostrophe ('kohn'). And always use DU when prefacing something being eaten.

question: What do you study? (formal and informal)
answer: Qu'est-ce que vous étudiez / tu étudie?; tu étudie is pronounced 'too-uh-tood' ...present singular verb forms are usually short with downward intonation

question: What did you do last week?
answer: Qu'est-ce que tu as fait la semaine dernière?

question: What are you doing this evening? (formal and informal)
answer: Qu'est-ce que vous faites / tu fais su soir?

question: What does he do for work?
answer: Il travaille dans quoi?; Use DE QUOI (instead of QUE) because the 'what' is the direct object and requires a preposition (for).; Literally: For what does he work? He is the subject. What is the object.

question: What's up?
answer: Quoi de neuf? (remember 'de' is pronounced 'duh'); Use DE QUOI (instead of QUE) because the 'what' is the direct object and requires a preposition.; Literally: Of what are you up to? You are the subject. What is the object.

question: What are you thinking about?
answer: Vous pensez à quoi?; Use DE QUOI (instead of QUE) because the 'what' is the direct object and requires a preposition.; Literally: Of what are you thinking? You is the subject. What is the object.

question: What is it like? (when you are asking someone to describe a location etc.)
answer: De quoi ça a l'air?; Use DE QUOI in this case.

question: What do you need?
answer: De quoi as tu besoin?; Use DE QUOI (instead of QUE) because the 'what' is the direct object and requires a preposition.

question: What else?
answer: Quoi d'autres? ('qwa-doh-truh'); Use DE QUOI (instead of QUE) in this case.

question: How do you ask: Which is ...?
answer: Quel est...? ('kel-ay-...') but it adapts to the gender and number of what you are asking about so there are four possbilities: Quel? (masc sing) Quelle? (fem sing) Quels? (masc plural) Quelles? (fem plural); All four forms are pronounced exactly the same: 'kel'.

question: What is your (informal) profession?
answer: Quelle est ton profession?; Use QUELLE because profession is feminine and singular.

question: What kind/type is it? (e.g. type of car or dance or music)
answer: Quel genre est-il? ('kel-jon-ray-til'); Use QUEL because genre is masculine and singular.

question: What type of jackets do you have?
answer: Quel genre de veste avez-vous? OR Vous avez quel genre de veste?; If you use Quel then you have to invert the subject verb; OR you can make a statement (subject + verb) and use intonation to make it a question

question: What color is the dress?
answer: DE quelle couleur est la robe?; Use DE QUEL instead of QUEL because we use a preposition in english: What is the color OF the dress? The presence of the preposition in english indicates that we need to use DE QUEL... in French.

question: What colors are you (formal) wearing?
answer: DE quelles couleurs vous portez?; Use QUELLES because couleures is plural and feminine.; couleur is pronounced 'kool-oor' like heurre

question: Who is ...? / Who is it?
answer: Qui est ...? ('kee-ah-...')/ Qu'est-ce? ('kes'); It doesn't matter whether the 'who' is the subject or direct object of the verb. Always use QUI.

question: Whose is ...?
answer: À qui est ce sac?; To change from 'who' to 'whose' just add the preposition à.

question: How do you ask how is something?
answer: Comment ...? ('como')

question: Where is ...? / Where is it?
answer: Où est ...? ('ooh-ay-...') / Où est-il? ('ooh-ay-eel')

question: What is the difference between où and ou?
answer: où (with accent) means where; ou (without accent) means or; They sound the same ('oo').

question: When is ...? / When is it?
answer: Quand est ...? ('kon-ah-...')/ Quand est-ce? ('kon-tes'); NB: quand is a general word for 'when' whether you are making a question or a statement. lorsque is a slightly more formal word that you can use instead of quand.

question: When do you (informal / formal)...?
answer: Quand est-ce que tu/vous...?; NB: Quand ends in consonant sound (D) and est-ce begins with vowel sound (E) so you must link the words when speaking ('koh-Des-kuh'...)

question: How many times per week / per month?
answer: Combien de fois par semaine / par mois?

question: How often?
answer: A quelle frequence?

question: I go to the cinema a few times per month
answer: Je vais quelque fois par mois au cinema.; take care on the order: adverb of frequency + actual frequency + object

question: How many years?
answer: Combien D'années?; Use combien for how many and how much. Use combien DE because you are asking about a quantity of something. Use années instead of ans because the quantity is indefinite/inexact.

question: How much is it?
answer: C'est combien? / Ça fait combien? ('sah-fay-kom-bien')/ Combien ça coûte? ('kom-bien-sa-coot'); Ça fait is a really common way to say 'It is' or 'It must be'. It is used in situations similar to - but different from - il faut.

question: How much is X?
answer: Combien coûte ...? ('kom-bien-coot')

question: How much do I owe you?
answer: Je vous dois ('dwa') combien?

question: It costs... + It is worth...
answer: Ça coûte... + Il vaut... (from the verb VALOIR)

question: idiomatic way to say: It's worth it. + It's not worth it.
answer: Ça vaut le coup. + Ça ne vaut pas le coup.; vaut is from the verb VALOIR (to be worth).

question: My labtop is expensive but it is worth it.
answer: Mon ordinateur est cher mais IL vaut le coup.; Il replaces Ça as the subject. The conjugation of VALOIR does not change because still 3rd person singular.

question: May I / Can I... (do something)?
answer: Puis-je ('pooj')... X?

question: You come with us? (formal and informal)
answer: Vous venez / Tu viens AVEC nous?

question: idiomatic way to ask: Do you want to eat? (formal and informal)
answer: Ça vous / te ('tuh') dit ('dee') DE manger?; This is very idiomatic french. It doesn't translate exactly but it means: Do you want to do + DE + INFINITIVE.; A server might ask 'Ça vous dit?' to take your order.

question: idiomatic way to ask: Do you want to go to the movies? (formal and informal)
answer: Ça vous/ te ('tuh') dit ('dee') d'aller au cinéma?; NB: The DE transformed to D' because the infinitive verb starts with a vowel.

question: Let's go!
answer: C'est parti!; This is a useful french phrase that can mean let's go! + let's get going! +  ...and their off!; It contains a past particple (parti from partir) but it is only used to describe things happening in the current moment.; On y va! is another really common french expression that is used in the same way. Technically it means 'Let's go there'.

question: That's all. (like when you are in a store and you don't need anything else)
answer: C'est tout ('too').

question: It's finished. (like when a show is over or you are at the end of a meal)
answer: C'est fini.

question: So...
answer: donc / du coup (as a result); Watch out because DONK means fuck or damn.

question: absolutely or definitely (common french phrase)
answer: tout à fait; often used in response to a question

question: of course
answer: bien sûr

question: with + without
answer: avec + sans

question: a way (of doing something)
answer: une façon / une manière

question: once
answer: une fois

question: only + only one
answer: seulement / uniquement + d'un seul (only one); NB: -ent is always pronounced in words that are not congugated verbs

question: alone
answer: seul

question: a single word
answer: un seul mot

question: about
answer: Different words are used in different contexts.; ENVIRON is the word to use for roughly (e.g. about 10 years); À PROPOS works in most situations where you mean about some topic. It's not always idiomatic but everyone will understand what you mean.; DE is used when you express that you talking about something or someone (e.g. Je t'ai parlé de lui. = I told you about him.); SUR is also used (e.g. sur lui = about him); Il s'agit... = It's about...

question: I read lots of books about history.
answer: Je lis beaucoup de livres à propos d'histoire.

question: I heard things about him.
answer: J'ai entendu DES choses SUR LUI.

question: aside from / exluding
answer: à part

question: a (small) part of
answer: une (petite) partie DE; partie is the noun and it is feminine

question: The room is one part of the café.
answer: La salle fait partie DU café.; Use FAIRE. de + le = du

question: the ambiance of the café
answer: l'ambiance DU café (de + le = du)

question: except
answer: sauf

question: already
answer: déjà

question: ready
answer: prêt(e); adjective that describes a person; e.g. Je suis prêt(e). = I am ready.; NB: Prét a mange. = Ready to eat.

question: not yet
answer: pas encore; encore can mean 'yet' or 'even'

question: almost
answer: presque

question: almost all of the people
answer: presque toutes les personnes; Use toutes because personnes is plural and feminine.

question: enough
answer: suffisant(e) OR assez; NB: assez means different things in different contexts. e.g. assez effrayant means quite scary - not scary enough.

question: sufficiant + sufficiently
answer: suffisant(e) + suffisamment; This follows a rule for transforming adjectives to adverbs: If adjective ends in -ANT or -ENT then remove -NT and add -AMMENT or -EMMENT respectively.

question: There are not enough days in the summer.
answer: Il n'y a pas ASSEZ de jours durant l'ete.

question: idiomatic way to say: It's enough.
answer: Ça suffit. ('say-soo-fee')

question: entirely + the entire book
answer: entièrement + le livre entier

question: generally
answer: généralment

question: maybe + probably
answer: peut-être ('poo-ehtr') + probablement ('proh-BA-BLUH-mon'); There are more pronounced syllables than you might expect in pro-ba-ble-ment.

question: in this case
answer: dans ce cas ('don-suh-ka')

question: rarely
answer: rarement; NB: For these kinds of freqency adverbs place them after the verb. e.g. Il court rarement. (He runs rarely.)

question: sometimes
answer: quelques fois / par fois; Use quelqueS because fois (times) is plural.

question: frequently
answer: souvent / fréquemment

question: most of the time
answer: la plupart du temps; do not forget the article before plupart - it is incorrect to start a sentence with 'Plupart du temps...'

question: usually
answer: d'habitude

question: always
answer: toujours; toujours can also mean still

question: still + I am still sick
answer: toujours + Je suis toujours malade.; The translation of STILL depends on the context. Toujours is one possibility but it can also mean always.

question: They still want to go to Greece.
answer: Ils veulent toujours aller en Grèce ('gres').; Grèce is feminine.

question: never
answer: jamais

question: just
answer: juste

question: until
answer: jusqu'à

question: recently
answer: récemment; The adjective (recent) is récent(e).

question: currently
answer: actuellement; Take care because this is a 'faux ami'. It does not mean actually in English.

question: nothing else
answer: rein d'autre ('ray-on-doot'); Rein is generally the word for nothing. It replaces PAS when you are saying nothing happened.

question: none
answer: aucun

question: soon
answer: bientôt ('beey-en-toe')

question: right away / immediately
answer: tout de suite

question: the rest + the rest of my friends
answer: le reste / la suite + le reste DE mes amis; Use suite if you are talking about a sequence. Suite has many different meanings/uses in french including following and sequel.

question: the rest of the cake + There is cake left over.
answer: le reste DU (de + le) gâteaux + Il reste des gâteux.; The verb RESTER can also be used to indicate food left overs

question: even without... / even if...
answer: même sans... / même si...

question: regardless...
answer: quand même...; This is a french expression. The closest literal translation is 'all the same'.

question: actually
answer: en fait ('ohn-feht'); The final T is pronounced.

question: obvious + obviously
answer: évident + évidemment

question: properly
answer: proprement; This adverb is used the same way in conversational french and english. e.g. when you do something 'properly' you do it completely or maybe even to excess

question: To be clear...
answer: Pour clarifier...

question: another one / one more
answer: un(e) autre

question: to others (other people) + the other friends; Specify pronunciation.
answer: aux autres ('oh-zotr'; x makes liaison) + les autres amis ('lay-zot-rah-mee'; An entire syllable is dropped at the end of autres!)

question: one more week
answer: une semaine de plus (pronounce the S at the end of plus)

question: What are the four forms of 'all'. Specify pronounciation.
answer: tout ('too' sing masc) + toute ('toot' sing fem) + tous ('too' pl masc) + toutes ('toot' pl fem); For pronunciation you really only need to know if you are in a masculine 'too' or feminine 'toot' situation.

question: everything
answer: tout (generally); If it is unclear exactly what things you are referencing then defer to the singular masculine form (TOUT).; But if you are referring to some group of things already mentioned than you need to select from tout/toute/tous/toutes depending on the number and gender of the 'everything'.

question: all the girls + all the boys
answer: TOUTES les filles (pl fem) + TOUS les fils (pl masc)

question: the luggage... everything follows.
answer: les bagages (pl masc)... TOUS suivent.; Use tout/toute/TOUS/toutes as a noun to represent 'everything'. Choose tous because it references a noun that is plural masculine.

question: the suitcases... everything follows.
answer: les valises (pl fem)... TOUTES suivent.; Use tout/toute/tous/TOUTES as a noun to represent 'everything'. Choose toutes because it references a noun that is plural feminine.

question: She is entirely/totally/completely emotional.
answer: Elle est TOUT émue. Use ; Use tout/toute/tous/TOUTES as an adverb to represent entirely/totally/completely'. Choose tout because it modifies an adjective (émue) that is singular feminine.

question: everyone
answer: tout le monde; It also means everybody.; Use TOUT because le monde is masculine singular.

question: every man / all men
answer: tout homme or chaque homme; This is idiomatic french. Homme is singular (not like men in english). Use TOUT to agree with masculine and singular homme.

question: every day + every night
answer: tous les jours + tous les soirs (literally: all days/nights); Use TOUS because both are masculine and plural.

question: every Monday
answer: tous les lundis (add S to make plural); Use TOUS because both are masculine and plural.

question: in every year
answer: chaque année; Use chaque when you are using every/each as an adjective.; Use année (instead of an) because we are specifying that something happens within the duration of a year.; NB: chaque never changes regardless of the gender/number of the word it describes.

question: in every country
answer: dans chaque pays; Use chaque when you are using every/each as an adjective.; NB: chaque never changes regardless of the gender/number of the word it describes.

question: in each book
answer: dans chaque livre; Use chaque when you are using every/each as an adjective.; NB: chaque never changes regardless of the gender/number of the word it describes.

question: Each is important.
answer: Chacun(e) est important.;  Use chacun(e) when you are using each as a noun. Use the E if the noun you are replacing is feminine.; Use chaque if you use each as an adjective.

question: one of the friends
answer: un des amis

question: one of my favorites + one of my favorite restaurants
answer: un de mes préférés + un de mes restaurants préférés; You can use favoris instead of préférés but it is less idiomatic.

question: my friend's party
answer: la fête d'un de mes amis; This is the common way to express it in french. Literally: The party of one of my friends.

question: anything
answer: n'importe (or n'importe quoi); This is a contraction of NE + conjugated form of verb IMPORTER (to matter); It literally means 'no matter' or '(it) does not matter'.

question: anyone (of them - not referring to people)
answer: n’importe lequel

question: anybody / anywhere or wherever / anytime or whenever
