answer: n'importe qui / n'importe où / n'importe quand

question: some X
answer: quelque(s) X; When are using 'some' as an adjective use quelque(s) but it can never stand on its own as a noun - like the word 'some' does in English. Use quelque if the noun you describing is singular. Use quelques if the noun you are describing is plural.

question: some thing (or something) + some horses
answer: quelque chose (singular) + quelqueS chevaux (plural); NB: un truc is slang for a thing.

question: a few (things) + some of them
answer: quelques uns + certains d'entre eux; Certain is slightly more specific than certain.; Generally quelque is used for things and certain is used for people. But this is not a hard rule.

question: some friends
answer: certains amis; Certain (instead of quelque) is the better choice in this case.

question: someone / somebody
answer: quelqu'un (masculine) or quelqu'une (feminine); NB: qu'un is pronounced 'kahn' not 'koon'

question: someday / sometime...
answer: un jour; literally: one day...; Do NOT use quelque which would mean a group of days (some/several days).

question: somewhere
answer: quelque part; literal translation: some location; Quelque (instead of certain) is the better choice in this case.

question: somewhere else / elsewhere
answer: autre part / ailleurs

question: everywhere
answer: partout OR n'importe où; This is the same phrased used to express 'anywhere'.

question: nowhere
answer: nulle part

question: far from...
answer: loin de...

question: It's nearby. / It's far away.
answer: C'est proche. / C'est loin.

question: near + close to
answer: proche + prés de

question: by the sea
answer: au bord de mer; au bord = at the edge

question: close to the Hungarian border
answer: proche DE la frontière d'Hongrie

question: along (e.g. along the coast)
answer: le long DE

question: beside / next to; Specify the pronunciation.
answer: à côté DE; Make sure to pronounce the E with accent ('koh-tay') because 'koht' is a totally different word: la côte = the coast.

question: the table next to me
answer: Two ways to express this: 1) la table à côté de moi 2) la table d'à côté ; NB: Both cases use the word with accent aigu: côté ('koh-tay'). This avoids confusion with the word for coast (côte pronounced 'koht')

question: on the other side
answer: DE l'autre côté; Make sure to pronounce the E with accent ('koh-tay') because 'koht' is a totally different word: la côte = the coast.

question: the coast + the Amalfi coast; Specify the pronunciation.
answer: la côte + la côte Amalfitaine; This is only one syllable 'koht'. The E is silent. This is important because 'koh-tay' is a totally different word: à côté de = next to

question: the rib + the ribs
answer: la côte + les côtes; NB: This is the same word for coast.

question: to the right of...
answer: à droit DE...

question: to the left of...
answer: à gauche DE...

question: the center of London + in the middle/center of the country
answer: le centre DE Londres + dans le centre DU pays

question: between
answer: entre

question: through
answer: It depends on context.; 1) PAR is less aggresive. e.g. Je regarde PAR la fenêtre. = I look through the window. Je passe PAR le quartier. = I pass by the neighborhood. 2) À TRAVERS is more aggressive with emphasis on crossing or literally going through one thing in order to get to another thing. e.g. I throw the ball through the window. = Je lance la balle à travers la fenêtre.; TRAVERSER (the verb) is a faux ami of 'to traverse'. The definitions are not exactly the same.

question: to go by (something) + to go through (something)
answer: PASSER + PAR + noun (e.g. Je passe par le quartier. = I pass by the neighborhood.) + TRAVERSER + noun (e.g. Je traverse le quartier en voiture. = I drove through the neighborhood.); NB: When you use TRAVERSER you are emphasizing the action of crossing something / going through it. The focus is on the destination.; TRAVERSER is a faux ami of 'to traverse'. The definitions are not exactly the same.

question: here + around here + over there
answer: ici ('ee-see') + là + là-bas

question: surrounding / around
answer: autour DE; If you mean instead that you walked 'around' a city (meaning through it) then use DANS instead.

question: the surroundings
answer: les environs / les alentours

question: indoors / outdoors
answer: à l'intérieur / en dehors

question: in (inside of)
answer: dans

question: in front of / in front of the table
answer: devant ("duh-von") / devant la table; There is no preposition DE after devant.; Using devant implies an order. e.g. Je suis assis devant Paul. = I am sitting in front of Paul. - like in a theater or on a bus where some seats are in front of others.

question: facing
answer: en face DE; Do not forget the preposition DE.; en face is different from devant (in front of) because it implies two things facing eachother. e.g. Je suis assis en face DE Paul. = I am sitting across from Paul. - like at a table where seats are facing one another.

question: in front of us + facing us
answer: devant nous + en face DE nous; Use DE with en face but not with devant.

question: Faced with this situation...
answer: Face à cette situation...; Literally: Facing this situation...

question: behind / behind the table
answer: derriér / derriér la table

question: on top of (touching); Specify the pronunciation.
answer: sur; Pronounced with the high-pitched 'ooouh' that you make by first singing 'eeee' and then rounding the lips. And then there is a soft but guteral 'gch' sound at the end for the 'r'.; Sur implies contact between the two objects.

question: above (not touching)
answer: au-dessus de; NB: below (not touching) looks very similar with one letter difference: au-dessous de

question: The apple is on the table. (touching) + The ceiling is above the floor.(not touching)
answer: La pomme est sur la table. + Le plafond est au-dessus du sol. (de + le = du)

question: It's 'on top'.
answer: C'est dessus.

question: above the sea
answer: au dessus du niveau de la mer; You cannot translate this directly. You have to say that you are above 'the level' of the sea.

question: under (at a short distance and possibly hidden); Specify the pronunciation.
answer: sous; Pronounced with the low-pitched 'oo' like being punched in the stomach. No ending consonant or sound.; NB: sous does not necessarily imply that the two objects are in contact. That is different from sur which does imply contact.

question: below and not touching (at some distance)
answer: au-dessous de; NB: above (not touching) looks very similar with one letter difference: au-dessus de

question: The apple is under the table. + The floor is below the ceiling.
answer: La pomme est sous la table. + Le sol est au-dessous de la plafond.

question: It's 'underneath'.
answer: C'est dessous.

question: at the top + at the bottom
answer: en haut ('ohn-o') + au fond; NB: en haut does not have a liaison so the N falls in the first syllable 'ohn-o'. But en eau (= sweating) does use a liaison so the N is pronounced in the second syllable ('oh-no').

question: upstairs + downstairs
answer: à l'étage + en bas

question: I went up the stairs. + I went upstairs.
answer: Use the verb MONTER (to ascend). Je suis monté(e) les marches. + Je suis allé(e) à l'étage.

question: I went down the stairs. + I went downstairs.
answer: Use the verb DESCENDRE (to descend). J'ai descendu les marches. + J'ai descendu les étages.

question: The sun sets.
answer: Use the verb DESCENDRE (goes down). Le soleil descend.

question: high + low
answer: haut(e) + bas/basse

question: at the beginning / first of all
answer: au début / d'abord

question: the beginning
answer: le début

question: in the middle (of something)
answer: au milieu + DE; e.g. au milieu DU mot = in the middle of the word (de + le = du)

question: at the end
answer: à la fin ('fon')

question: at the end of his/her studies
answer: à la fin de ses études

question: the ending
answer: la terminaison

question: the beginning of May
answer: début mai; NB: la quiazaine is a half of the month. la 1ème quiazaine (days 1-15) and la 2ème quiazaine (days 16-31)

question: mid June
answer: mi-juin; mi- works for any time period where you want to express the middle; Do not use 'demi' in this case.

question: the end of July
answer: fin juiliet

question: finally / at last
answer: en fin

question: eventually
answer: au final

question: until
answer: jusqu'á

question: then...
answer: puis... or ensuite...; This is only for when you are describing things that really happen sequentially. Use alors for other cases especially when you are implying causation.

question: hopefully...
answer: aven un peu de chance

question: a childhood
answer: une enfance

question: too cold
answer: trop froid ('trow fwa')

question: too hot
answer: trop chaud ('trow show')

question: open
answer: ouvert ('ooh-ver')

question: closed
answer: fermé ('fer-meh')

question: before / after
answer: avant / après; NB: après que ALWAYS triggers the subjonctif

question: now
answer: maintenant ('mont-a-no') ...three syllables

question: today
answer: aujourd'hui ('ohn-jour-dwi'); the first syllable is a strong 'oh' sound which is the case for any word including 'au'

question: tomorrow / tomorrow morning
answer: demain ('duh-ma') / demain matin ('duh-ma-ma-ton');  NB: Add À in front of the word to make it a salutation. e.g. À demain! = Until tomorrow!; If you are simply saying the word for tomorrow or a day of the week - then just use the word without à in front of it. e.g. On va aller demain. = We will go tomorrow. On va aller mercredi. = We will go on Wednesday.

question: yesterday
answer: heir ('ee-air')

question: the day before yesterday + before yesterday
answer: The spelling for these two is exactly the same: avant hier. But if you mean the actual day before yesterday (2 days ago) it is pronounced 'a-van-tière' like one word. But if you mean the time in general that was before yesterday then it is pronounced 'a-van ee-ehr' like two separate words.

question: the day before
answer: la veille ('___'); Close but different from the feminine version of the adjective for old: vielle ('vee-ay')

question: 2 nights ago
answer: 2 nuits auparavant

question: I ate the food IN one hour.
answer: J'ai mangé la nourriture EN une heure.; Use EN for the quantity of time that it takes to complete something.

question: for (in the service of something)
answer: pour; Generally you can use the word 'pour' to replace the word 'for'. But this is not always true - especially when talking about time ranges.

question: for/during (the duration of some time frame completely in the past)
answer: pendant; Use pendant with verbs in the past tense. If the time frame is specified you will probably use passé composé. If the time frame is in the past but ambiguous then you will probably use imparfait.; Pendant is exclusively for time frames that started and ended in the past without relation to the present.; e.g. Je l'ai fait pendant 2 semaines. = I did it for 2 weeks.; NB: There are exceptions. Use pour if the time frame was pre-determined.

question: for (the duration of some time frame completely in the future)
answer: pour

question: for (the duration of some time frame that is ambigous - when you do not know if it occurs in the past present or future)
answer: pour

question: for (the duration of some time frame that overlaps with the present but was pre-determined)
answer: pour; e.g. Je suis ici pour trois jours.; Use present even though the time frame extends into the future.

question: for / since (the duration of some time frame that started in the past and overlaps with the present)
answer: depuis ('duh-pwi') or depuis que; Use depuis with verbs in the present tense. It is exclusively for time ranges that started in the past and continue in the present.; e.g. Je le fais depuis 2 semaines.= I have been doing it for/since 2 weeks.; NB: Sometimes we need to use depuis with past tense verbs but only when the action continues into the present.

question: for (the duration of some time frame strictly in the future)
answer: pour; Use pour only for time frames that are 100% in the future.

question: Which word (pendant or depuis or pour) would you use to describe an election term or the duration of a visa?
answer: pour; The hint here is that the duration is pre-determined.

question: Which word (pendant or depuis or pour) would you use in this sentence? I ran for one hour.
answer: J'ai couru PENDANT une heure.; Use pendant because the activity was strictly in the past and the duration was not pre-determined.

question: Which word (pendant or depuis or pour) would you use in this sentence? In the mornings I run for one hour.
answer: Le matin je cours pendant une heure.; Use pendant because 'in the mornings' is an indicator that it will happen again. This - in combination with present tense - forces the use of pendant.

question: Which word (pendant or depuis or pour) would you use in this sentence? I run for one hour last night.
answer: Je cours pendant une heure heir soir.; Use pendant because 'last night' is an indicator of the past. Even though the verb tense is in present we use pendant in this scenario.

question: When do you use DEPUIS vs DEPUIS QUE?
answer: They both mean for/since (some time frame that started in the past and continues into the present). Use DEPUIS when what follows is only the time frame (not a complete phrase) e.g. I have danced for 10 years / a long time. = Je danse DEPUIS 10 ans / long temps.; Use DEPUIS QUE when what follows is a complete phrase with subject and verb. e.g. I have danced since I began walking. = Je danse DEPUIS QUE j'ai commencé à marcher.

question: while
answer: PENDANT QUE; When you use 'pendant que' then you typically use présent or imparfait; e.g. Quelqu’un est venu pendant que je dormais. = Someone came (passé composé) while I was sleeping (imparfait).; e.g. Ils sortent pendant que je dors. = They go out (présent) while I sleep (présent).; NB: alors que is an alternative to pendant que but it is only used in special contexts.

question: I saw a film during my stay in Paris.
answer: J'ai vu un film pendant mon séjour à Paris.; Use pendant because the time frame began and ended in the past.

question: I will be in France for 5 years.
answer: Je serai en France pour cinq ans.; Use pour because the time frame is strictly in the future with no relation to the present.; Use ans (instead of années) because the quantity is exact.

question: I have been here for several years.
answer: Je suis là depuis plusiers années.; Use depuis because the time frame continues to the present (like since).; Use années (instead of ans) because the quantity is indefinite/inexact.

question: How long have you (formal) studied french?
answer: Depuis combien de temps ètudiez-vous le français?; Use depuis because the time frame continues to the present (like since).; You could substitute 'quand' for 'combien de temps' in this case.

question: When answering a question about 'how long'... It's been 3 weeks.
answer: Ça fait trois semaines.; Ça fait is a really common and casual way of expressing that something has been happening.

question: It hasn't been a long time.
answer: Ça ne fait pas longtemps.; Ça fait is a really common and casual way of expressing that something has been happening.

question: I've danced since I was 3 years old.
answer: Je danse depuis que j'ai 3 ans.; This makes sense in french. But it is more common to say: Je fais de la danse. Like faire de la musique.

question: I've been visiting France regularly for 10 years.
answer: Je viens en France régulièrement depuis 10 ans.; Use VENIR instead of VISITER.; Use DEPUIS with present tense to talk about an activity that started in the past and continues into the present.

question: How long did you stay in the Phillipes?
answer: Combien de temps resteras-tu (resterez-vous) rester aux Philippines?; resteras/resterez are futur simple; aux because Philippines is plural.

question: Cook the meat for 20 minutes.
answer: Fais cuir la viande pour 20 minutes.

question: We have class for 4 hours.
answer: Nous avons classe pendant 4 heures.; Use pendant because a repetitive activity is implied.; NB: Use classe to talk about the time you are at school. Use cours to talk about the type of class you are taking. e.g. un cours de tango (literally: a course of study)

question: Since 2020...
answer: Depuis 2020...

question: Two months since I was in class.
answer: Deux mois DEPUIS QUE je suis en classe.; Use present tense in this case.; NB: Use classe to talk about the time you are at school. Use cours to talk about the type of class you are taking. e.g. un cours de tango (literally: a course of study)

question: Two ways to say: It was 20 years ago that I was a scientist.
answer: 1) Il y a 20 ans QUE je suis scientifique. 2) Ça fait 20 ans QUE je suis scientifique.; NB: Use present tense in both cases.; scientifique is same for masculine and feminine

question: I have been studying for 6 months. + I have not studied for 6 months.
answer: J'étudie depuis six mois. + Je n'ai pas étudié depuis six mois.; When the statement is positive use present tense with depuis. But when you negate this kind of phrase you have to use passé composé. We still use depuis because the lack of action continues in the present.; NB: The negated structure implies that the action was happening before it stopped happening.

question: I have been reading a book for 1 month. + I have not read a book for 1 month.
answer: Je lis un livre depuis un mois. + Je n'ai pas lu un livre depuis un mois.; When the statement is positive use present tense with depuis. But when you negate this kind of phrase you have to use passé composé. We still use depuis because the lack action continues in the present.; NB: The negated structure implies that the action was happening before it stopped happening.

question: monday + tuesday + wednesday; Specify pronunciation.
answer: lundi ('luhn-di') + mardi ('MAR-di' ...remember to let the r catch in the throat a bit) + mercredi ('MEH-cri-di'); NB: Add À in front of the word to make it a salutation. e.g. À lundi! = See you on Monday!; If you are simply saying the word for tomorrow or a day of the week - then just use the word without à in front of it. e.g. On va aller demain. = We will go tomorrow. On va aller mercredi. = We will go on Wednesday.

question: thursday + friday + saturday + sunday; Specify pronunciation.
answer: jeudi ('zshooh-di' ...the j is really soft) + vendredi ('VON-dra-di') + samedi ('sam-di') + dimanche ('DEE-monsh') NB: Add À in front of the word to make it a salutation. e.g. À samedi! = See you on Saturday!; If you are simply saying the word for tomorrow or a day of the week - then just use the word without à in front of it. e.g. On va aller demain. = We will go tomorrow. On va aller Dimanche. = We will go on Sunday.

question: How do you make a day of the week plural?
answer: les dimanches; same as any other word - add S

question: january + february + march; Specify pronunciation.
answer: janvier ('zhahn-veeay') + février ('fay-vReeay') + mars ('mars' like the planet in Englisy); fèvrier has an R. janvier does not.

question: april + may + june; Specify pronunciation.
answer: avril ('ah-vreel') + mai ('may' same as English) + juin ('zshoo-uhn')

question: july + august + september; Specify pronunciation.
answer: juillet ('zhoo-yay') + août ('ahoot' as one syllable) + septembre ('suh-ptohMbr')

question: october + november + december; Specify pronunciation.
answer: octobre ('oak-tohbr') + novembre ('noe-vohMbr') + décembre ('day-sohMbr'); octobre does NOT have an M. But septembre novembre and decembre do have M.

question: June 21
answer: le 21 juin; Dates always have an article in front and they are always masculine.

question: March 1
answer: le premiere mars; the 1st of a month is always spoken as 'le premiere' - never with a number. The other dates in a month always use numbers (e.g. le deux or le 2).

question: Friday December 2
answer: vendredi 2 décembre; !! no 'le' in front of the date when the date is preceded by the day of the week.

question: On Saturday... + On Sunday night
answer: Samedi... + Dimanche soir...; Do not use a preposition in front of a day's name.

question: a day
answer: un jour

question: a week + a weekend
answer: une semaine + un week-end

question: this week
answer: cette semaine; this could mean the previous week or the following week (same as english) so you must listen for context

question: a month + a year
answer: un mois ('mwa') + un ans ('ahn'); NB: If you are counting use un ans. If you are talking about a duration of time use une année.

question: in a few months
answer: dans quelques mois; Use quelqueS becuase mois is plural.

question: a season
answer: une saison

question: a winter + a spring + a summer + an autumn
answer: un hiver + un printemps + un été + un automne (do NOT pronounce the M in automne); all masculine

question: It is winter.
answer: C'est l'hiver.; Do not use 'il y a...' or 'il fait...' for this statement.; Do not forget the article.

question: a calendar
answer: un calendrier

question: holidays
answer: jours fériés

question: in august
answer: en août; en is the translation for in when talking about a month or year

question: in the 19th century
answer: PENDANT le 19ème siècle; You must use pendant (instead of dans) because the century is a duration of time. So literally: during the 19th century

question: in the 1900s
answer: DANS les années 1900; Use dans here because you are referencing a group of years. You cannot use dans if you want to reference a specific/single year.

question: in 1988
answer: EN 1988; Use en when referencing a specific/single year.

question: In the past...
answer: Dans le passé...

question: from 1995 to 1997
answer: de 1995 à 1997; de / à are also used like from / to for email and mail

question: starting from 1990
answer: à partir de 1990

question: about 10 days
answer: environ 10 jours; environ is the word to use when you mean approximately; It's been raining for 10 days. = Il pleut depuis dix jours. Use jours in this case - not journées.

question: Not so long ago...
answer: Il n'y a pas si longtemps...

question: 5 years before / after X
answer: 5 ans avant / après

question: the day afterwards
answer: le jour d'après; d'après means something like following / afterwards; NB: d'après can also mean 'according to' e.g. d'après toi = according to you. But selon que is a better way to express 'according to'

question: according to me / in my opinion
answer: selon que moi; selon que is the best translation of according to. 'Selon que moi...' is the idiomatic way to express: In my opinion...

question: according to the press
answer: selon que la presse

question: before the water stopped
answer: avant que l'eau s'arrête; In this case we use the present tense following AVANT QUE even though it may have actually happened in the past.; We use the reflexive form of the verb (SE ARRÊTER) because some subject has to stop the water - it can't be ambiguous. In this case the water is stopping itself. Or we could be explicit that someone turned off the water - then we could use the non-reflexive form: ARRÊTER.

question: before studying French...
answer: avant D'étudier le français...; the structure for this: AVANT + DE + INFINITIVE; This structure does not work for aprés.

question: before moving to NYC...
answer: avant DE s'installer à NYC; the structure for this: AVANT + DE + INFINITIVE; This structure does not work for aprés.

question: after studying French...
answer: aprés mes études de français... (literally: after my french studies); You cannot use an infinitive after aprés like you can with avant + de. So we have to change the structure.

question: after moving to NYC...
answer: aprés mon installation à NYC... (literally: after my move to NYC); You cannot use an infinitive after aprés like you can with avant + de. So we have to change the structure.

question: 9 o'clock in the morning / afternoon / evening.
answer: 9h DU matin / DE l'après-midi / DU soir; DE + LE/LA + time of day is the correct structure for expressing doing something at some time of day or the time at some time of day.; We are referring to a specific instant - not a duration. So use matin + jour + soir + etc

question: How do you know whether to use jour vs journée / soir vs soirée / an vs année / etc?
answer: The rules are not hard. Generally the former (jour/soir/an) is for talking about that period of time as a subject - on this day or in that year. Generally the latter (journée/soirée/année) is for talking about the duration of time - how it is spent.; But probably the best approach is to memorize which prepositions trigger which version.

question: all day long + all night long + all year long
answer: toute ('toot') la journée + soirée + année.; Use toute because all three are feminine singular.

question: during the day/night/year
answer: pendant la... journée + soirée + année; The preposition pendant triggers this form instead of jour/soir/an.

question: one time per day/night/year
answer: une fois par... jour + soir + an

question: one time in the day/night/year
answer: une fois dans la... journée + soirée + année; The preposition dans triggers this form instead of jour/soir/an.

question: some years later
answer: plusieurs années plus tard

question: the north + It is one hour north of X.
answer: le nord (masc) + C'est à une heure au (à + le = au) nord de X.

question: the south + It is one hour south of X.
answer: le sud (masc) + C'est à une heure au (à + le = au) sud de X.

question: the east + It is one hour east of X.
answer: l'est (fem) + C'est à une heure à l'est de X. (à + la does not contract)

question: the west + It is one hour west of X.
answer: l'ouest (fem) + C'est à une heure à l'ouest de X. (à + la does not contract)

question: definite articles for masculine + feminine + plural nouns
answer: le/la/les; If the noun starts with a vowel then you replace le/la with l' and pronounce the verb as if it starts with L - ignore the apostrophe when speaking

question: indefinite articles for masculine + feminine + plural nouns
answer: un (masculine..make a smile when you speak it like 'aahn') + une (feminine...make a closed o-shape with mouth like 'oo-yn' and really pronounce the n separately it's almost like two syllables...like bier in german) + des (for all plurals regardless of gender; pronounced 'day')

question: femine masculine plural
answer: féminin masculin pluriel

question: What are some ways to determine if a noun is féminin?
answer: Ending with 'tion'; Ending in E is not a helpful because there are feminine and masculine nouns that end in E.

question: When should there be an apostrophe instead of spelling out le/la?
answer: when the noun starts with a vowel OR when the second letter is a vowel and the first letter is not pronouned (e.g. h); l'académie instead of la académie; l'ordinateur instead of le ordinateur; l'hôtel

question: Aside from a definite article (the) when do you use le/la/l'?
answer: These are also the pronouns for ils/elle when he/she/it is the direct object of a verb; e.g. I read it. = Je le lis. (I + it masculine + read conjugated in present tense)

question: a word

question: the vowel
answer: une voyelle ('voy-ehl')

question: a noun / a verb
answer: un nom / un verbe

question: the thing
answer: la chose ('shows')

question: things to do
answer: des choses a faire

question: Date of Birth (for forms)

question: birthday

question: marriage anniversary
answer: anniversaire de mariage

question: the nationality + the citizenship
answer: la nationalité + la citoyenneté

question: What is your nationality?
answer: Quelle est votre/ta nationalité?; nationalité is feminine so Quelle and votre/ta must agree with it.

question: I am American.
answer: Je suis américain (m) / américainne (f).; the 'n' is pronounced very lightly and only in the feminine version.; Names of countries are capitalized in French. Names of nationalities and languages are not capitalized in French.

question: You are French.
answer: Tu es français (m) / française (f).; masculine pronounced 'fran-say'; feminine pronounced 'fran-seZ'; Names of countries are capitalized in French. Names of nationalities and languages are not capitalized in French.

question: How is the name of a language related to nationality?
answer: There are masculine and feminine versions of every nationality. The language is always the masculine version.; e.g. Il est allemand. Elle est allemande. Elle parle allemand.; 'allemand' is how you translate German when you mean the language.; BUT the word for language is feminine (la langue). So if you want to say the entire phrase 'the french language' then it is a feminine noun with a feminine adjective: la langue allemande.

question: a french/argentine passport
answer: un passport français/argentin

question: I live in New York.
answer: J'habite à New York.

question: I do not come from Paris.
answer: Je ne viens pas de Paris.; making a statement negative is done by 1) adding NE in front of the verb and 2) adding PAS after the verb

question: I do not live in Berlin.
answer: Je n'habite pas à Berlin.; If the verb starts with a vowel or the first pronounced sound is a vowel (no 'h' in france) then use N' instead of NE.

question: I have family in Sweden.
answer: J'ai de la famille en Suède.; AVOIR + 'de la famille' is an idiomatic way of expressing that some of your family is in a location.

question: I don't see well.
answer: Je ne vois pas bien.

question: I speak English.
answer: Je parle anglais. OR Je parle en anglais. Either is correct - like in english (I speak English. OR I speak in English.); NB: In french we always use an article in front of noun. Speaking a language (using the verb parler) is the only exception. When using parler we do not say/write... Je parle l'anglais. But any other time you use the name of a language (or any other noun) then you always add an article in front of it.

question: I do not speak Mandarin.
answer: Je ne parle pas mandarin.; Names of countries are capitalized in French. Names of nationalities and languages are not capitalized in French.

question: I speak a little Spanish + French + German.
answer: Je parle un peu espagnol et français et allemand.

question: a french class / a tango class
answer: un cours français / un cours ('koohr') de tango ('tohn-go');  NB: cours looks plural ending in S but it is singular.; Do not use 'classe' for this. Une classe refers to class heirarchy (e.g. 1st class) or the specific time that you are in school.

question: I go to french class. / I take a tango class.
answer: Je vais EN cour de français. / Je prends un cours de tango.; Do not use à for going to class. That is used for going to a city etc. - somewhere you visit.

question: a french A2 class
answer: un cours du A2; 'french' is understood

question: a class + a race + a yard
answer: All of these words sound similar but have different meanings.; un cours ('coor') = a class / a course of action / an errand; une course ('coors') = a race; une cour ('coor') = a yard / a courtyard

question: a messenger / a courier
answer: un corsier

question: short
answer: court ('coor') if masculine / courte ('coort') if feminine; This adjective is used for inanimate objects (e.g. a short skirt or a short rope) - it is NOT used to describe humans.; For humans use petit(e) instead.

question: brief + briefly
answer: bref/brève (m/f) + brièvement; This is an irregular adjective/adverb pairing. It does not follow the major rules for transforming and adjective to an adverb.

question: the level + the levels
answer: le niveau + les niveaux; e.g. mon niveau de français = my level of french

question: a high level of skill
answer: un haut niveau de compétence; the skill = la compétence

question: at most + at least
answer: au plus + au moins

question: several
answer: plusieurs

question: a lot / many
answer: beaucoup; If you use beaucoup as a quantity (e.g. a lot of fish / many fish) then you must add DE between beaucoup and the noun (e.g. beaucoup de poisson).; If you use beaucoup to modify a verb (e.g. We drank a lot.) then it is an adverb and must come before the verb (e.g. Nous avons beaucoup bu.)

question: not much (like when someone asks you what you have been doing and there is little to report)
answer: pas grand chose; Do not use the phrase 'pas beaucoup' - this does not make sense in french.

question: too much
answer: trop / beaucoup trop ('troh')

question: It was too much.
answer: C'etait trop ('troh').; Use imparfait tense.

question: I have too much energy.
answer: J'ai trop d'énergie.; trop (too much) is a quantity so you follow it with DE.

question: There are too many cultures to count.
answer: Il y a beaucoup trop cultures pour les compter.

question: so much (stuff)
answer: tellement DE choses; Tellement is the word that adds emphasis like 'so' in english.; You have to explicitly state the object (choses).

question: so many activities
answer: tellement D'activités; Tellement is the word that adds emphasis like 'so' in english.; You have to explicitly state the object (choses).

question: I do quite a lot of things.
answer: Je fais pas mal de chose.; NB: 'pas mal' can mean not bad but it can also mean quite a lot.

question: She eats apples. Which word is assumed in English but cannot be assumed in French?
answer: Elle mange DES pommes.; Partitive article is the name for the word that describes an uncountable or unknown quantity of something. In this case the partitive article is 'some'. She eats (some) apples. 'some' here is optional in English.; In French the partitive article is never optional.

question: What are the partitive articles (used for describing an unknown or uncountable quantity) in French?
answer: du/d' + de la/de l' + des/d'; They are all contractions/combinations of DE + le/la/les.; DU (de + le) is for masculine nouns. DE LA does not contract for feminine nouns. DES (de + les) is for plural nouns.; Do not use these if the quantity is specified in any way (e.g. un kilo de...) - then a different set of articles are used.

question: Is there (some/any) coffee / onion?
answer: Est-ce qu'il y a du café / d'oignon?; We must include partitive article (du / de la / des) when quantity is uncertain.; These nouns are masculine so we use DU. DU contracts to D' when the noun starts with a vowel.

question: Is there (some/any) meat / water?
answer: Est-ce qu'il y a de la viande / de l'eau?; We must include partitive article (du / de la / des) when quantity is uncertain.; These nouns are feminine so we use DE LA. LA contracts to L' when the noun starts with a vowel.

question: Are there (some/any) lemons / onions?
answer: Est-ce qu'il y a DES citrons / DES oignons?; We must include partitive article (du / de la / des) when quantity is uncertain.; The gender of the plural noun does not matter. DES never contracts when the noun starts with a vowel because DES ends with a consonant.

question: the water
answer: l'eau; eau is feminine. But la eau contracts to l'eau to avoid back-to-back vowels.; This is pronounced really strongly "loh".; -eau is pronounced as a strong 'oh' - like the words chateau and bateau.

question: two glasses of water (explain the pronunciation difference)
answer: deux verre d'eau; The O sound in deux is higher in the mouth. The O sound in d'eau is lower in the mouth; d'eau = DE + EAU. Use DE EAU instead of LA EAU because verre is specified quantity so we use the generic DE/DES without the definite article (la).

question: The water is good. + a glass of water +  + I drink water.
answer: These exhibit the three different ways to talk about water.; 1) L'eau est bonne. = The water is good. We are using the noun with its article (simply LA which contracts to L').; 2) un verre d'eau = a glass of water. The glass is a quantity so we use the generic preposition DE/DES without a definite article. (DE contracts to D'.); 3) Je bois DE l'eau. = I drink water. The verb BOIRE is always followed by DE but it is not a quantity indicator. So you also have to give the object of the verb (water) it's partitive article - LA (because water is feminine). DE + LA + EAU = de l'eau.

question: She eats a lot. + She ate a lot.; Note the location of 'beaucoup' in both cases.
answer: Elle mange beaucoup. + Elle a beaucoup mangé.; If beaucoup describes the verb (manger) - as it does in both of these sentences - instead of the object (e.g. beaucoup DE frais)... then beaucoup must follow the conjugated portion of a verb. That means that 'beaucoup' falls between the two parts of passé composé in this case.

question: You (informal) eat a lot of apples.; Which preposition is required?
answer: Tu manges beaucoup DE pommes.; 'A lot' in this case does not modify the verb (manger) here. It describes the quantity of apples (just like 'a kilo'). When quantity is specified we only use DE/D' (instead of the partitive articles) because gender and number do not need to be reflected.

question: He ate a lot. + He ate a lot of apples.; Note the location of 'beaucoup' in both cases.
answer: Il a BEAUCOUP mangé. + Il a mangé BEAUCOUP de pommes.; Both examples are passé composé so there are two parts to the verbs. In the first case BEAUCOUP modifies the verb (manger) so it must follow the conjugated portion of the two-part verb. In the second case BEAUCOUP modifies the object (pommes) so it must be placed after the entire verb.

question: There is a box of coffee.
answer: Il y a un carton DE café. (le café); The quantity is specified so use the general articles (DE / D') that do not care about gender or number.

question: There is a pack of salad.
answer: Il y a un paquet DE salade. (la salade); The quantity is specified so use the general articles (DE / D') that do not care about gender or number.

question: There is a jar strawberry jam.
answer: Il y a un pot DE confiture de fraise. (la confiture); The quantity is specified so use the general articles (DE / D') that do not care about gender or number.

question: There are a dozen cookies.
answer: Il y a une douzaine DE biscuits. (les biscuits); The quantity is specified so use the general articles (DE / D') that do not care about gender or number.

question: group words for: a dozen + a set of 10 + a set of roughly 100
answer: une douzaine + une dizaine + une centaine ('son-ton')

question: There is a handful of blueberries.
answer: Il y a une poignée DE myrtilles (les myrtilles); The quantity is specified so use the general articles (DE / D') that do not care about gender or number.

question: There is no fish.
answer: Il n'y a pas DE poisson.; A negative quantity is a specified quantity. So we use the general articles (DE / D') that do not care about gender or number.

question: There are no limes.
answer: Il n'y a pas DE citrons verts.; A negative quantity is a specified quantity. So we use the general articles (DE / D') that do not care about gender or number.

question: I need vacation.
answer: J'ai besoin DE vacances.; avoir besoin triggers the use of the general articles (DE / D') that do not care about gender or number.; vacation is always plural in french - vacances

question: I want sun.
answer: J'ai envie DE soleil.; avoir envie is how you express craving something; avoir envie triggers the use of the general articles (DE / D') that do not care about gender or number.

question: Given: I would like more wine. - Is the S in plus pronounced? Why?
answer: Je voudrais plus de vin; S in plus is pronounced because it relates to a noun with a positive quantity.

question: Given: There is no more school. - Is the S in plus pronounced? Why?
answer: Il n'y a plus d'école.; The S is NOT pronounced because it relates to a noun with a negative/lack of quantity.; But we still need DE/D' because it is a quantity - even if negative.

question: Given: I do not want it anymore. - Is the S in plus pronounced? Why?
answer: Je n'en veux plus.; The S is NOT pronounced because it relates to a noun with a negative/lack of quantity.

question: Given: You are more intelligent than an apple. - Is the S in plus pronounced? Why?
answer: Tu es plus intelligent qu'une pomme.; Contract que + une = qu'une.; S in plus is pronounced because it precedes an adjective that starts with a vowel or a silent h followed by vowel.

question: Given: I am stronger than you. - Is the S in plus pronounced? Why?
answer: Je suis plus fort que toi.; S in plus is NOT pronounced because it precedes an adjective that DOES NOT start with a vowel or a silent h followed by vowel.

question: How do you pronounce "3 + 4 = 7"?
answer: trois plus quatre égal sept ('twa-ploos-cat-ree-gal-set'); the S is pronounced because it is being used as a mathematical sign

question: It's more of an apple than a pear.
answer: C'est plus une pomme qu'une poire.; Contract que + une = qu'une.; S in plus is pronounced as a Z because it makes a liaison with une.

question: It's easier in Asia than in Europe.
answer: C'est plus facile en Asie qu'en Europe.; Normally the N in en is silent because it is at the end of the word. But here you must pronounce the N in en to make a liaison with the next word (Europe) which starts with a vowel.; Pronounce the last two words as one word blended together 'koh-noo-rope'

question: It's more difficult in Spain than in France.
answer: C'est plus dificil en Espagne qu'en ('koh') France.; Remember that the N in en is silent. It stays silent here because the next word (France) starts with a consonant.

question: The doctors in France give more drugs than in the United States.
answer: Les médecins en France donnent plus de médicaments qu'aux Etats-Unis. ('koh-zuh-ta-zoo-nee'); pronounce the last part as a single word

question: no more; specify the pronunciation
answer: non plus ('pa-ploo'); the S is silent because we are dealing with a negative/lack of quantity

question: a lot more; specify the pronunciation
answer: beaucoup plus ('ploos'); the S is pronounced because we are dealing with a positive quantity

question: more than X; specify the pronunciation
answer: plus que ('ploos-kuh') X; S on plus is pronounced because it refers to a positive quantity.

question: Jean is faster. + Jean is faster than Michel.
answer: Jean est PLUS rapide. + Jean est PLUS rapide QUE Michel.; S in plus is pronounced because it refers to a positive quantity and comes before a word that starts with a consonant.; The structure for comparing with adjectives: plus/moins/aussi + adjective + que; The adjective (rapide) should adapt to the subject (Jean) that it describes.

question: The rock is less intelligent. + The rock is less intelligent than the computer.
answer: Le rocher est MOINS intelligent. + Le rocher est MOINS intelligent QUE l'ordinateur.; The adjective (intelligent(e)) should adapt to the subject (le rocher - masculine) that it describes.

question: Angelique is just as intelligent as Simone.
answer: Angelique est AUSSI intelligente QUE Simone.; The adjective (intelligent(e)) should adapt to the subject (Angelique - feminine) that it describes.

question: He is as tall as his father.
answer: Il est AUSSI grand QUE son père.; When making equality comparisons with adjectives (as X as) you should almost always use AUSSI QUE instead of COMME. Comme should only be used when the quality cannot be quantified.

question: He is blond like his father.
answer: Il est blond COMME son pére.; This is an example of an equality comparison with adjectives (as X as) where you cannot use AUSSI because the quality is not quantified in any way. So you must use COMME in this case. But generally you should always use AUSSI QUE for making equality comparisons with adjectives.

question: Eva works more. Eva works more than Aileen.
answer: Eva travaille PLUS. Eva travaille PLUS QUE Aileen. ('ploos-kuh'); S in plus is pronounced because it refers to a positive quantity and comes before a word that starts with a consonant.; The structure for comparing with verbs: verb + plus/moins/autant + adverb (optional) + que.

question: Anna travels less. + Anna travels less than you (informal).
answer: Anna voyage MOINS. + Anna voyage MOINS QUE toi.; When a pronoun follows the QUE in comparisons use pronom tonique (toi).; The structure for comparing with verbs: verb + plus/moins/autant + adverb (optional) + que.

question: He eats as much as I do.
answer: Il mange autant QUE moi.; When a pronoun follows the QUE in comparisons use pronom tonique (moi).; The structure for comparing with verbs: verb + plus/moins/autant + adverb (optional) + que.

question: He speaks as well as I do.
answer: Il mange autant bien QUE moi.; The structure for comparing with verbs: verb + plus/moins/autant + adverb (optional) + que.

question: I run slower than I did yesterday.
answer: Je cours PLUS lentement QU'heir.; The structure for comparing with verbs: verb + plus/moins/autant + adverb (optional) + que.

question: I am less athletic than before.
answer: Je suis MOINS sportif QU'avant.

question: The salon has more furniture. + The salon has more furniture than the office.
answer: Le salon a PLUS DE ('ploos-duh') meubles. + Le salon a PLUS DE mobilier QUE le bureau.; The structure for comparing with nouns: PLUS/MOINS/AUTANT + DE/D' + noun + QUE); S in plus is pronounced because it refers to a positive quantity and comes before a word that starts with a consonant.

question: The casino has less money. + The casino has less money than the bank.
answer: Le casino a MOINS D'argent. + Le casino a MOINS D'argent QUE la banque.; The structure for comparing with nouns: PLUS/MOINS/AUTANT + DE/D' + noun + QUE)

question: I have as many books as Angela.
answer: J'ai AUTANT DE livres QU'Angela.; The structure for comparing with nouns: PLUS/MOINS/AUTANT + DE/D' + noun + QUE)

question: He/She is more than a banker.
answer: Il/Elle est plus qu'un/qu'une banquier/banquière.; S in plus is pronounced because it refers to a positive quantity and comes before a word that starts with a consonant.; NB: qu'un is pronounced 'kahn' not 'koon'

question: higher than me + lower than me
answer: élevé QUE moi + moins élevé QUE moi; If a pronoun follows QUE when making a comparison then the pronoun should be tonique.

question: less than other things
answer: moins que d'autres choses

question: even more + even less
answer: encore plus + encore moins; encore can mean 'yet' but when used with plus/moins it provides an emphasis like 'even'

question: The plane is even faster than the train.
answer: L'avion est ENCORE PLUS rapide QUE le train.

question: The car is even less convenient than the bus.
answer: La voiture est ENCORE MOINS pratique QUE le bus.

question: She studies even less (than before).
answer: Elle étudie ENCORE MOINS souvent QU'avant.

question: the most intelligent (specify the pronunciation)
answer: le/la/les PLUS ('ploos') intelligent(e); Adding the article (le/la/les) changes the plus from a comparator to a superlative. The article must agree with the subject.; The S is pronounced because we are dealing with a positive quantity.

question: the least intelligent
answer: le/la/les moins intelligent(e); Adding the article (le/la/les) changes the plus from a comparator to a superlative. The article must agree with the subject.

question: Eva is the most dynamic. + Eva is the most dynamic of the women.
answer: Eva est LA PLUS dynamique. + Eva est LA PLUS dynamique DE femmes.; The article that indicates the superlative (le/la/les plus) must agree with the subject that is being described (Eva - feminine).; When using a superlative use DE/D' to indicate the group within which they are the most/least.

question: Jean is least dynamic. + Jean is the least dynamic of the men.
answer: Jean est LE MOINS dynamique. + Jean est LE MOINS dynamique DE hommes.;  The article that indicates the superlative (le/la/les moins) must agree with the subject that is being described (Jean - masculine); When using a superlative use DE/D' to indicate the group within which they are the most/least.

question: He runs the most. She runs the least.
answer: Il court LE PLUS. Elle court LE MOINS.; The superlative is always masculine (LE plus/moins) when we compare with verbs (court).

question: She has the most books. She has the least books.
answer: Elle a LE PLUS DE livres. Elle a LE MOINS DE livres.; The superlative is always masculine when we compare with nouns (livres). Do not forget DE/D' before the noun.

question: conjugate 'to be' (a profession or a nationality)
answer: être: je suis + tu es ('ay') + il/elle/on est ('ay') + nous sommes + vous êtes ('vooz-eht')+ ils/elles sont ('ssson')

question: When is est (conjugated 'to be') pronounced as 'ayt' instead of 'ay'?
answer: when the adjective following it starts with a vowel; e.g. Ils est intelligente; If the t in est was not pronounced is would be two vowels together and that is not how french is spoken; But otherwise the t at the end of est is never pronounced.

question: When is et (and) pronounced as 'ayt' instead of 'ay'?
answer: Never. Never make the t sound - even when the next word starts with a vowel; e.g. Elle est grande et intelligente - the pronounciation of et does not change.

question: conjugate 'to have'
answer: avoir: j'ai + tu as + il/elle/on a + nous avons + vous avez + ils/elles ont

question: What is the radical of a verb?
answer: The radical is he smallest part of the verb infinitive. The radical generally does not change as the verb is conjugated.; NB: For group 1 (-er) and group 2 (-ir) verbs the radical is the part of the infinitive minus ER and IR.; Conjugation for group 3 verbs is more difficult. Some of those verbs have multiple radicals. e.g. ALLER uses the radicals: all (nous allons) + v (je vais) + ir (nous irons)

question: How do you conjugate group 1 verbs (regular -ER verbs) in present tense?
answer: endings: je -e (only pronouce the radical) + tu -es (silent) + il/elle/on -e (silent) + nous -ons (pronounced like nasal 'on') + vous -ez (pronounced like 'ay') + ils/elles -ent (-ent is ALWAYS silent in verbs but it forces the pronunciation of the previous letter)

question: What is the intonation on the conjugated forms for first person singular (je)?
answer: the intonation is always downward and shortened; e.g. je travaille sounds like 'ju tru-vay' not 'ju trav-a-ye'.

question: How do you pronounce the ending for the nous form of -ER verbs?
answer: the ending for nous is -ons ('ohn' very nasal without much of an 'n' sound on the end); this is the same sound as the on in il/elle/on ..when we use the casual form of 'we' when speaking

question: What is the only verb ending in -ER that is totally irregular?
answer: aller (to go)

question: What are some variations or small irregularities that occur when conjugating -ER verbs and which forms to they impact? (disregard the totally irregular verb ALLER)
answer: 1) In some cases there is an accent change in the second syllable when conjugating -ER verbs au présent (e.g. acheter + préférer); 2) For -YER verbs the Y can stay a Y or it can change to I before adding the endings. Either spelling is 100% correct but the pronunciations are slightly different. If we keep the Y in the spelling then the 'y' sound is heard more in the pronunciation.; When there are irregularities in conjugating -ER verbs au présent all forms are impacted EXCEPT nous and vous forms - those two forms are conjugated exactly as you would expect for -ER verbs.

question: How do you conjugate group 2 verbs (regular -ir verbs) in present tense?
answer: endings: je -is ('ee') + tu -is ('ee') + il/elle/on -it ('ee') + nous -issons ('ee-soh'; nasal and pouty) + vous -issez ('ee-say') + ils/elles -issent ('ees' -ent is ALWAYS silent in verbs but it forces the pronunciation of the previous consonant)

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to finish'.
answer: finir (regular -ir verb): je finis + tu finis + il/elle/on finit + nous finissons + vous finissez + ils/elles finissent ('fi-nees'; The double S changes the sound of the I and -ent is always silent on verbs.)

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to choose'
answer: choisir (regular -ir verb): je choisis + tu choisis + il/elle/on choisit + nous choisissons ('shwa-Zee-Sohn'; The single S makes a Z sound. The double S makes a Z sound because in between vowels.) + vous choisissez ('shwa-See-Say') + ils/elles choisissent

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to grow up'
answer: grandir (regular -ir verb): je grandis + tu grandis + il/elle/on grandit + nous grandissons + vous grandissez + ils/elles grandissent ('gran-dees'; -ent is silent on verbs); NB: Avoid confusion with GROSSIR whish means to put on weight.

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to see'.
answer: voir: je vois ('vwa') + tu vois + il voit + nous voyons + vous voyez + ils voient

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to receive'.
answer: recevoir; past participle: reçu; NB: This is VOIR with a prefix. So the conjugation of RECEVOIR (using radical REÇ) mirrors the conjugation of VOIR (using radical V). Except the nous and vous forms use radical REC (without cedille). je reçois + tu reçois + il reçoit + nous recevons + vous recevez + ils reçoivent

question: I would receive (conditionnel). + I would have received (conditionnel passé).
answer: Je reçevrais. + J'aurais reçu.

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to like'.
answer: aimer: j'aime + tu aimes + il/elle/on aime + nous aimons + vous aimez + ile/elles aiment

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to want'.
answer: vouloir: je veux ('voo' at the top of the mouth - NOT the deep U sound) + tu veux ('voo') + il/elle/on veut ('voo') + nous voulons ('voo-lon') + vous voulez ('voo-lay') + ils/elle veulent ('vuhl'; the -ent is not pronounced in verbs); NB: veux and veut are NOT pronounced 'voo'; VOUS - the subject pronoun - is pronounced 'voo'; VEUX and VEUT are pronounced like something between 'vuh' and 'voo' (same as PEUX) so that it is possible to distinguish them from VOUS; past participle: voulu

question: How do you pronounce... I want + I go + I see?
answer: Je veux ('voo' but higher in the mouth similar to 'vuh') + Je vais ('vay') + Je vois ('vwa')

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to go'.
answer: aller: je vais + tu va + il/elle/on va + nous allons + vous allez +ils/elles vont

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to come'.
answer: venir: je vien ('vyon') + tu viens ('vyon') + il/elle/on vient ('vyon') + nous venons ('vo-non') + vous venez ('ve-nay') + ils/elles viennent ('vyen'; NB: The double N changes the sound of the vowel that precedes the pair. 'vy' becomes 'vyeh'.)

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to do' / 'to make' (something).
answer: faire: je fais ('fay') + tu fais ('fay') + il/elle/on fait ('fay') + nous faisons + vous faites + ils/elles font ('fon')

question: to rejuvinate or renovate (a building or a face)
answer: refaire

question: to make someone feel a certain way + He makes me sick.
answer: When we use 'make' in this way we use the verb RENDRE instead of FAIRE. Il me rend malade. = He makes me sick.; Other examples: They make me tired + confused + crazy + nervous.

question: That accent makes/drives me crazy.
answer: Cet accent me rend fou/folle (m/f).; Use RENDRE when you mean to make someone feel a certain way.

question: The sun makes me tired.
answer: ; There are two ways to express this: 1) Using RENDRE: Le soleil me rend fatigué(e). 2) Using the verb FATIGUER (to fatigue): Le soleil me fatigue.

question: conjugate 'to take'
answer: prendre is irregular; je prends ('pruh') + tu prends ('pruh') + il/elle/on prend ('pruh') + nous prenons ('pruh-non' ...nasal ending)+ vous prenez ('pruh-nay') + ils/els prennent ('prehn'); NB: The double N in prennent changes the sound of the first syllable.; past participle: pris

question: to make a decision
answer: prendre une décision; Use prendre - not faire - in this case.

question: to decide + to decide to do something
answer: décider is the infinitive; past participle: décidé; I decide to do something = Je décide + DE + INFINITIVE VERB. e.g. I decide to try. = Je décide d'essayer.

question: to order (food)
answer: commander; NB: When you are actually ordering food you use PRENDRE e.g. Je prends des fraises. = I'll take some strawberries. But the verb that describes the action of ordering is COMMANDER - not PRENDRE.

question: to keep + to save
answer: garder (to keep) + sauver (to save)

question: conjugate 'to be able to'; often used as a helper verb (e.g. I can wait. You can work.)
answer: pouvoir: je peux ('juh pooh') + tu peux ('pooh') + il/elle/on peut ('pooh') + nous pouvons ('pooh-von') + vous pouvez ('pooh-vay') + ils/elles peuvent ('puhv'; the -ent is NOT pronounced in verbs)

question: conjugate 'to have to' / 'must' (do something)
answer: devoir followed by infinitive of action verb: je dois X ('dwa') + tu dois X ('dwa') + il/elle/on doit X ('dwa') + nous devons X ('duh-von') + vous devez X ('duh-vay') + ils/elles doivent X ('dwav')

question: I must read.
answer: Je dois ('dwa') lire.; Use the verb devoir and add the infinitive form of whatever you must do (e.g. lire).

question: I must go to the store.
answer: Je dois aller au magasin.;  Use the verb devoir and add the infinitive form of whatever you must do (e.g. aller).

question: How do you pronounce: They must eat.?
answer: Ils doivent manger. ('eel-dwa-manj-ay'); remember -ent is often dropped when pronouncing the third person plural

question: to need (something)
answer: avoir besoin DE (quelque chose); NB: Use avoir besoin DE... when a thing/object is needed. If you need to do something - then use the verb devoir + INFINITIVE instead.

question: I need the coffee. + You need the table.
answer: J'ai besoin du café (de + le = du). + Tu as besoin de la table.; NB: Use avoir besoin DE... when a thing/object is needed.

question: We need a boat. + She needs a dress.
answer: On a besoin d'un bateau. + Elle a besoin d'une robe.; NB: Use avoir besoin DE... when a thing/object is needed.

question: He needs privacy.
answer: Il a besoin d'intimité.

question: I would need X.
answer: J'aurais besoin X.; Use conditionnel version of AVOIR BESOIN.

question: What is the difference between DEVOIR and AVOIR besoin?
answer: Sometimes they can be used interchangeably but generally DEVOIR preceeds a verb and AVOIR BESOIN precedes a noun.; If you use DEVOIR followed by a noun then it means to owe - not to need.

question: I owe you a euro.
answer: Je te dois un euro.

question: Which three verbs are only conjugated in the 3rd person singular (il/elle)?
answer: falloir (to be required) + pleuvoir (to rain) + valoir (to be worth)

question: conjugate 'to know' (some information) AND give the past participle.
answer: savoir; past participle: su; conjugation: je sais + tu sais + il/elle/on sait + nous nous + vous savons + ils/els savent ('sav')

question: to know (to be familiar with)
answer: connaître (+ noun); Do not use DE or AVEC. e.g. Elle connaît la ville. (She knows - is familiar with - the city.); connaître can mean to know a someone personally or to know OF that person.

question: I didn't know that.
answer: Je ne connaissais/savais pas.; Use imparfait tense because you didn't know it before but now you do know it - something that was true in the past but is different now (similar to telling a story)

question: I didn't know X. What tense should the phrase X be in?
answer: Typically the phrase should be in the imparfait because you are describing some memory that you thought about in one way and now you know differently.

question: I haven't seen/heard of that (before).
answer: Je n'ai jamais entendu parler de ça.; JAMAIS replaces PAS.; In this case passé composé is the best choic in french. Though in English we use plus que parfait (had seen/heard).; The 'before/already' is implied in french. We do not need to add 'déja' for this specific expression.

question: I went to the store already. + I already went there.
answer: Je suis déjà allé(e) au magasin. + J'y suis déja allé(e).; Passé composé is a good choice in this case because the statement is straightforward in the past. The speaker is not using past perfect (had been).; Déja should fall between the two parts of the verb in both cases in french.; Déja is the word to use for a direct translation of 'already' or for when we use the word before to mean already. e.g. I went to the store (before).

question: Were you (informal) in the Netherlands? + Were you there?
answer: Est-ce que tu as été aux Pays-Bas? + Est-ce que tu Y as été?; Use pronom Y to reference a location.; Passé composé is a good choice in this case because the question is straightforward in the past. The speaker is not using past perfect (had been).

question: Were you (informal) in the Netherlands before/already? + Were you there before/already?
answer: Est-ce que tu as DÉJA été aux Pays-Bas? + Est-ce que tu Y as DÉJA été?; Déja always lies between the two parts of the verb.; Déja is the word to use for 'already' or for 'before' in situations where it can be replaced with 'already'.

question: Have you gone/been to Germany before/already?
answer: Est-ce que tu étais DÉJA allé(e) en Allemagne?; In this case ALLER and plus que parfait are the best choices in french.; Déja is the word to use for 'already' or for 'before' in situations where it can be replaced with 'already'. Déja always lies between the two parts of the verb.; JAMAIS replaces PAS.

question: Have you gone/been there before/already?
answer: Est-ce que tu Y étais DÉJA allé(e)?; Use pronom Y to reference a location.

question: conjugate 'to hate'
answer: détester: je déteste + tu détestes + il/elle/on déteste + nous détestons + vous détestez + ils/els détestent

question: conjugate 'to appreciate'
answer: apprécier: j'apprécie + tu apprécies + il/elle/on apprécie + nous apprécions + vous appréciez + ils/elles apprécient

question: How do you remember which verb tenses use a radical and which tenses use the entire infinitive as their base (before adding the ending for each form)?
answer: Use a radical - not necessarily the same one - in the past and present (passé composé + imparfait + présent). Use the full infinitive - or variation on the infinitive - in the future (futur proche + futur simple + conditionnel).; NB: The endings for the imparfait ('past-like') and conditionnel ('future-like') are exactly the same BUT their bases are different.

question: How do you remember which verb radical to use in imparfait vs futur simple/conditionnel?
answer: There is no hard rule. Generally for irregular verbs... the radical in the past tenses does NOT have an R at the end. But the radical in the future tenses does have an R at the end.; e.g. DEVOIR... je DEVais (imparfait) je DEVRais (conditionnel); e.g. POUVOIR... je POUVais (imparfait) je POURRais (conditionnel); e.g. AVOIR... j'AVais (imparfait) j'AURais (conditionnel); e.g. ALLER... j'ALLais (imparfait) j'IRais (conditionnel)

question: I go to the office at 8am.
answer: Je vais au bureau à 8 heures.

question: I hate being cold.
answer: Je déteste avoid froid.

question: that last week / the previous week
answer: la semaine dernière / la semaine précédente; you could make the latter plural: les semaines précedentes - the previous weeks

question: the last (of something) / the new (of something)
answer: la dernier X / la nouveau X

question: in the last lesson
answer: au dernier cours

question: a lesson
answer: une leçon / un cours (more like 'a class')

question: I have french lessons every Sunday online.
answer: J'ai des cours de français tous les dimanches en ligne.

question: We watch football (soccer). / We watch a game of football.
answer: On regarde DU foot. / On regarde un match de foot.; plural of match = matchs

question: I wanted to go to more (football) matches.
answer: Je voulais aller à plus de matchs.; Use imparfait of VOULOIR (instead of passé composé) because it is a state of being and whatever you wanted in the past is different from what you want at this moment. Also it is much more polite to express this with imparfait - just as we would use conditionnel (voudrais) to express what we want in the present.

question: a game (like a boardgame)
answer: un jeu; pronounced just like the word for I (je)

question: a video game
answer: un jeu video

question: the olympic games
answer: les jeux olympiques ('lay-zhoo-Zo-lim-peek'); There is a Z liaison between jeux and olympiques.

question: a team + the women's/men's team
answer: un équipe + l'equipe féminin/masculin

question: the stadium
answer: le stade

question: to play
answer: jouer

question: to play with words / to play with fire
answer: You can make a literal translation in these cases. JOUER + AVEC.; jouer avec les mots / jouer avec le feu

question: to play sports
answer: faire du sport

question: What are the three major ways to express doing some activity?
answer: 1) FAIRE + DU / DE LA / DES / D' + some activity  2) JOUER + AU / À LA / AUX  + game/sport 3) JOUER + DU / DE LA / DES / D' + music/musical instrument; à + le = au; à + les = aux; de + le = du; de + les = des; d' is used when the following word starts with a vowel

question: to play football (soccer)
answer: jouer au foot / faire du foot; Both are possible.

question: They play tennis.
answer: Ils jouent ('zshoo') au tennis.; JOUER + À because tennis is a sport/game.; Tennis is masculine singular. à + le = AU.; The present tense conjugations of jouer (e.g. je joue) have only one syllable - despite the multiple vowels - and they sound exactly the same as the word for cheek (une joue)

question: They play pétanque.
answer: Ils jouent ('zshoo') à la pétanque.; JOUER + À because pétanque is a sport/game.; Pétangue is feminine singular so à la remains À LA.

question: They play chess.
answer: Ils jouent ('zshoo') aux échecs.; JOUER + À because chess is a sport/game.; Échecs is plural. à + les = AUX.

question: I play piano.
answer: Je joue ('zshoo' - intonation down and short) du piano.; JOUER + DE because we are talking about music/musical instrument.; Piano is masculine singular. de + le = du

question: His friend plays the flute.
answer: Son ami joue ('zshoo') de la flûte.; JOUER + DE because we are talking about music/musical instrument.; Flûte is feminine singular.

question: She plays the drums / the guitar.
answer: Elle joue ('zshoo') de la batterie / de la guitare.; JOUER + DE because we are talking about music/musical instrument.; Drums and guitar are both feminine singular in french.

question: They play hip-hop music.
answer: Ils font de la musique hip-hop.; We do not use the verb JOUER in this case. Use FAIRE + DE instead.; La musique is feminine singular.

question: My friends played music (with instruments); Specify the pronunciation.
answer: Mes amis ont ('a-mee-ont'; NO liaison) fait de la musique.; There is not liaison after amis when using the verb avoir (conjugated as ont in this case); We do not use the verb JOUER in this case. Use faire de la musique instead.

question: We played some games.
answer: On a joué à quelques jeux.; Use quelqueS because games is plural.

question: He played soccer.
answer: Il jouait au football.; Use imparfait to describe someone's hobby in the past.

question: I ski.
answer: Je fais du ski.; Use FAIRE + DE.; Le ski is masculine singular. de + le = du.

question: He rides a bike.
answer: Il fait du vélo.; Use FAIRE + DE.; Le vélo is masculine singular. de + le = du.

question: I dance.
answer: Je fais de la danse.; Use FAIRE + DE.; La danse is feminine singular.

question: to do gymnastics
answer: faire de la gymnastique; Use FAIRE + DE.

question: I go to the gym.
answer: Je vais à la salle du sport.

question: to listen to the music
answer: ècouter de la musique; remember to always use a preposition and an article (DE LA) after écouter

question: a guitar + a drum + a bass
answer: une guitare + un tambour + une basse

question: a harp + a trumpet + a violin
answer: une harpe + une trompette + un violon

question: to watch television
answer: regarder la télé

question: to look after someone
answer: s'occuper de

question: We stay here.
answer: On reste ici.

question: to buy
answer: acheter; NB: achats ('ah-sha') is the noun for purchases and is derived from acheter

question: How does acheter change as it is conjugated au présent?
answer: j'achète + tu achètes + il achète + nous achetons + vous achetez + ils achètent; acheter is an -ER verb so the minor variations (adding accent grave è) do not impact the nous and vous forms.

question: to go shopping (for luxury clothing or goods)
answer: faire du shopping; this is not running errands - it's specifically for a luxurious experience

question: to go shopping (for daily food + home goods/furniture + clothing + gifts)
answer: faire les courses; this is more like running errands

question: to do housework / chores + to tidy up
answer: faire le ménage + ranger

question: Use for chores. + Do not use for chores.
answer: Utilisez pour faire le ménage. + N'utilisez pas pour faire le ménage.

question: to prefer
answer: préférer; 2 accent aigu!

question: How does préférer change as it is conjugated au présent?
answer: je préfère + tu préfères + il préfère + nous préférons + vous préférez + ils préfèrent; préférer is an -ER verb so the minor variations (changing accent aigu to accent grave) do not impact the nous and vous forms.

question: to return something (e.g. clothes to a store)
answer: retourner OR faire un retour; retourner is only used when you are returning some thing (a direct object) to a place that is different from where the speaker is currently located.; past participle: retourné(e) - retourner uses être in passé composé.; Do not use this when you are talking about the movement of a person. See REVENIR and RENTRER.

question: to return / to go back / to come back (when a person - not a thing - is returning)
answer: There are two verbs to choose from. 1) Revenir (RE + VENIR) is like 'come back' to a location that is the same as where the speaker is currently located.; 2) Rentrer means 'to go back home' wherever home is.

question: feedback (like on a job)
answer: retour

question: to sell
answer: vendre

question: to dine
answer: dîner

question: to travel
answer: voyager

question: We picnic.
answer: On pique-nique. OR On fait un pique-nique. Pique-nique can be a noun or a verb.

question: to think
answer: penser; a thought = une pensée; NB: When you use PENSER in the past you almost always use imparfait (instead of passé composé) because if you thought something in the past then it is likely that you think something different now.; past participle: pensé (regular -ER verb)

question: to become
answer: devenir; the base is venir (to come); the conjugation in present tense is exactly the same as venir except for nous and vous forms

question: to guess
answer: same as to become - devenir; Or you could use IMAGINE (same meaning as english)

question: to believe; Conjugate it.
answer: croire; je crois ('kwa') + tu crois + il croit + nous croyons + vous croyez + ils croient; past participle: cru

question: I believe you.
answer: Je te crois. ('kwa')

question: to make (something) up
answer: inventer

question: to behave + to act
answer: se comporter + agir; le compartment = the behavior

question: to pass by
answer: passer

question: to spend time
answer: passer; same verb as to physically pass by something

question: to break
answer: casser

question: to burst
answer: éclater; Use this verb to describe a storm breaking or a large burst of thunder. e.g. l'orage éclate = the thunder bursts but it also translates to: the storm breaks

question: to target
answer: cibler

question: to immerse (oneself) in something
answer: s'immerger

question: You immerse yourself (informal) in French.
answer: Tu t'immerge DANS français.; The masculine version of a nationality is the short form for the language.

question: to fail
answer: échouer; the failure = l'échec

question: to take (an exam) / to retake (an exam)
answer: passer (does not mean 'to pass an exam' - just to take the exam) / repasser

question: to pass (an exam) / to fail (an exam)
answer: réussir (the literal translation is to succeed but this is the verb to use when passing a course) / rater; NB: rater means to fail an exam. But it is not the general verb for failing.

question: My grades are bad.
answer: Mes notes sont mauvaises.; une note is a grade on an exam

question: They did not succeed (in anything - not necessarily an exam).
answer: Ils n'ont pas réussi.; NB: Be careful when saying someone succeeded in the past tense. Without context this may mean to succeed sexually. Unfortunately it applies more strongly when you are describing the actions of woman vs the actions of a man.

question: I succeeded in answering (the questions).
answer: J'ai réussi à répondre.; NB: RÉUSSIR + À to describe succeeding at something.; NB: Because there is an accent aigu on the É there are two vowel sounds ('ray-oo-seer'). If there were no accent (reussir) then EU together would make a single vowel sound.

question: success
answer: succés ('sook-say')

question: She is successful.
answer: Elle a beaucoup de succés dans ses affaires.; This is a better way to express that someone succeeded at some effort (other than passing an exam). ...instead of using RÉUSSIR.

question: business + event/case
answer: affaires + affaire; Take care because these are 'faux amis'. They do not mean a marital affair.

question: to help... to do something
answer: aider... À + VERB; e.g. Il m'aide à parler français. = He helps me to speak French.

question: to work
answer: travailler

question: the work + a job
answer: These are different words.; le travail = is the noun for the work; a job is translated as un travail or un job

question: a job offer
answer: une offre d'emploi

question: remote work + full-time + part-time
answer: télé travail + à temps plein + à temps partiel

question: in this field (of work)
answer: dans ce milieu; le milieu literally translates to 'middle' but it is commonly used to mean something like field or area or place

question: It opens doors. (idiomatic phrase in both English and French)
answer: Ça ouvre des portes.; Do not forget the article in front of portes.

question: to manage
answer: gérer

question: a manager / to be in charge of something
answer: un/une responsable (des ...); e.g. the person in charge of vegetables in a restaurant = un/une responsable des légumes; Responsable can also be used as adjective as it is in English (responsible for something). e.g. Elle est responsable de la façon moderne de cuisiner. = She is responsible for the modern way of cooking.

question: to take care of / deal with
answer: s'occuper

question: to send (in general) + to mail (using the post office)
answer: envoyer + poster

question: It's in the mail.
answer: C'est posté. This uses POSTER in passe composé.; For example: J'ai posté la lettre hier. = I mailed (or 'posted') the letter yesterday.

question: to watch / look at
answer: regarder

question: to look for / I am looking for a jacket (in a store).
answer: chercher / Je cherche ('shersh') une veste.; rechercher is similar but more thorough - perhaps meaning to research or seek

question: to show
answer: montrer; NB: This is different from MONTER (to ascend / to go up); Alternative: faire visiter e.g. Elle fait visiter son appartement. = She shows her apartment.

question: to celebrate / We celebrate.
answer: féter ...but it is used with faire / On fait la fête. ...literally we make a celebration - this might translate to party but not certain

question: to arrive
answer: arriver; this is also the verb for 'to happen'

question: It happens.
answer: Ça arrive. OR Ça se passe.; ARRIVER is typically used for both 'to arrive' and 'to happen'.; You can also use the verb SE PASSER for 'to happen'.

question: Two things happened.
answer: Deux choses sont arrivées. OR Deux choses se sont passées.

question: to talk/to speak + to talk about x
answer: parler + parler DE x; NB: This is different that the verb for 'to say': dire.

question: to say (something) / to tell (something - that is not a long story); Conjugate it.
answer: dire; je dis + tu dis + il dit + nous disons + vous dites + ils disent; past participle: dit

question: You were saying. (imparfait) + You might say. (conditionnel)
answer: Tu disais. + Tu dirais.; Infinitive: DIRE. Remember that the futur simple radical (used for conditionnel too) is usually the one that uses an R.

question: I wasn't going to tell you.
answer: Je N'allais (aller in imparfait) PAS te le dire.; le is a pronoun that stands of the thing that is being told (or not told)

question: to express
answer: exprimer; s'exprimer is to express oneself

question: to describe
answer: décrire

question: to tell (a story)
answer: raconter (une histoire); pronounced 'ra-kohn-Tay' - 'ra' is like the word 'rad' without the D or the word 'racoon'. The first syllable is NOT 'ray'.; There is only one N and the T is really sharp because it is not followed directly by an R. So the pronunciation is very different from the verb rencontrer (to meet for the first time); Raconter is used much more commonly than dire (to say) when you are talking about something that was told.

question: to notice (something)
answer: remarquer

question: idiomatic way to say: a good tip/note
answer: une bonne remarque; remarquer = to notice / to note (something)

question: to shout
answer: crier

question: to sing
answer: chanter

question: to enter
answer: entrer

question: to begin + to stop (doing something)
answer: commencer + arrêter

question: to dance
answer: danser

question: to ask (for something) + to ask (a question) ...2 different verbs
answer: demander (quelque chose) + poser (une question)

question: to require / to demand
answer: exiger; The adjective for demanding: exigeant(e)

question: to cost
answer: coûter

question: to spend (money) + to pay
answer: dépenser + payer ('pay-yay'... two Y sounds)

question: conjugate payer (to pay) au présent
answer: je paye/paie + tu payes/paies + il paye/paie + nous payons + vous payez + ils payent/paient; Payer is a -YER verb so for all forms (except nous and vous) the Y can stay or it can be changed to I. Both forms are correct.

question: List 5 verbs ending in -YER and explain what is special about their conjugation.
answer: payer (to pay) + essayer (to try) + nettoyer (to clean) + envoyer (to send) + effrayer (to frighten) + s'ennuyer (to be bored); -YER verbs can be conjugated in two ways au présent that are totally correct... for all forms (except nous and vous) the Y can stay or it can be changed to I.

question: to leave (a tip + a message + etc)
answer: laisser

question: the tip (for a server)
answer: le pourboire; literally 'for a drink'

question: a tip/trick (for doing something fast/well)
answer: une astuce

question: to grab a drink (like with a friend)
answer: prendre un verre; If we were using BOIRE then the verb must be followed by DE. But here we are using PRENDRE so DE is not required.

question: idiomatic way to say: Next round is on me!
answer: C'est ma tournée.; Literally: It's my turn.

question: to go too far / to cross the line
answer: dépasser les bornes; This is a french expression.

question: a favor
answer: une faveur

question: to share (also to split a bill)
answer: parteger; On partage? = shall we split it?

question: to give + to give back
answer: donner + redonner

question: to lend (for a short period of time
answer: prêter

question: to read
answer: lire; past participle: lu

question: to write + to spell + to register
