question: She could have gone to the movies.
answer: Elle aurait pu (conditionnel passé) aller (infinitive) au cinéma.; This is special variation of conditionnel passé (could have): AVOIR/ÊTRE conjugated in conditionnel tense (aurait) + PAST PARTICIPLE (pu from pouvoir) + INFINITIVE

question: We should have sang a song.
answer: On aurait dû (conditionnel passé) chanter (infinitive) une chanson.; This is special variation of conditionnel passé (should have): AVOIR/ÊTRE conjugated in conditionnel tense (aurait) + PAST PARTICIPLE (dû from devoir) + INFINITIVE

question: It could be worse. + It could have been worse.
answer: Ça pourrait être pire. (conditionnel) + Ça aurait pu être pire. (conditionnel passé)

question: What is the plus que parfait (pluperfect) tense?
answer: Use this tense to describe an event in the past that 'had taken' place and 'had been' completed BEFORE some other past event. Often the word AVANT is in the phrase.; Do not use this for something that happened independently or in the recent past (when you would use passè composé or imparfait instead).; In English we call this the 'past perfect' tense (e.g. I had been doing something).; In English we often use a simple past tense (e.g. passé composé or imparfait) for both events in the past. But in french you MUST use plus que parfait whenever you are describing an event that occurred before some other event in the past.

question: How do you construct the plus que parfait tense?
answer: Same as passé composé but AVOIR and ÊTRE auxiliaries are conjugated au imparfait instead au présent. Use the same past participle as passé composé.; e.g. I had been eating BEFORE you saw me. = J'avais mangé (plus que parfait) AVANT tu me voyais (imparfait).

question: We were already seated.
answer: On était assis.; Use plus que parfait to describe a past event that occurred before some other past event.

question: She returned to Portugal because her visa expired.
answer: Elle est rentrée (passé composé) au Portugal parce que son visa avait expiré (plus que parfait).; Use plus que parfait for a past event that occurred before some other past event.; Literally: Her visa had expired.

question: I read the book because I heard it was good.
answer: J'ai lu le livre parce que j'avais entendu que c'était bon.; The second phrase (j'avais entendu) is conjugated in the plus que parfait (literally: I had heard...) because it is a past event that occurs before some other past event.

question: If I had found ten euros (then) I would have bought a coffee.
answer: Si j’aVais trouvé (plus que parfait) dix euros... j'auRais acheté (conditionnel passé) un café.; If a conditional phrase (if..) is in the past (e.g. If we had arrived earlier...) - instead of in the present tense (e.g. If we arrive early...) - then that phrase should use the plus que parfait tense. And that means that the resultant/hypothetical phrase (what would have happened if the if-statement was true) should use the conditionnel passé tense (would have/could have/should have).

question: If they had found ten euros (then) they would have bought a coffee.
answer: S'ils aVaient trouvé (plus que parfait) dix euros... ils auRaient acheté (conditionnel passé) un café.; Si contracts with any word that starts with a vowel.; NB: Never use IF in the same phrase as the conditionnel tense. That would be duplication because the conditional tense assumes a hypothetical.

question: We would have finished early if we had worked together.
answer: On auRait fini (conditionnel passé) si on aVait travaillé (plus que parfait) ensemble.; If a conditional phrase is in the past (if we had worked together) then that phrase should use the plus que parfait tense. That means that the resultant/hypothetical phrase (we would have finished earlier) should use the conditionnel passé tense (would have/could have/should have).

question: What is the subjonctif (subjunctive) verb tense?
answer: It is used to express something that is desired. e.g. I wish that the weather is nice. - 'I wish' triggers the subjonctif tense to be used in the phrase 'the weather is nice'.; There are a lot of scenarios that trigger the subjonctif. Falloir (e.g. Il faut...) is a common trigger.; Three major categories (not exhaustive) that trigger the subjonctif include: 1) preferences / advice / needs / desires / orders 2) judgements / emotions / feelings 3) possibilities / opinions / doubts / suppositions.

question: What are the requirements of using the subjonctif tense?
answer: Three requirements: 1) A subjonctive phrase is dependent on another phrase triggering the subjonctive tense. e.g. I wish that you have a good life. 'I wish' is présent indicatif but the verb 'to wish' triggers the subjonctive in the subsequent dependent phrase: that you have a good life.; 2) A subjonctive phrase always starts with the word 'que' or 'qui'. e.g. Je souhaite... QUE vous ayez (avoir in subjonctive) une belle vie.; 3) The independent phrase (that triggers the subsequent subjonctif) must have a subject that is different from the subject in the subjonctif phrase. e.g. I wish that I have a good life. You can't use the subjonctif in this case because the subject of both phrases is the same.

question: How do you construct the subjonctif tense?
answer: 1) the radical: For je/tu/il/ils forms... use the radical from the ils form of the présent indicatif (e.g. venir -&gt ils viennent -&gt vienn); For nous/vous forms use the radical from the nous form of the présent indicatif (e.g. venir -&gt nous venons -&gt ven); 2) the ending: je: -e + tu: -es + il/elle/on: -e + nous: -ions + vous: -iez + ils/elles: -ent

question: Conjugate parler (regular -ER verb) in the subjonctif tense.
answer: que je parle + que tu parles + qu'il/elle/on parle + que nous parlions + que vous parliez + qu'ils/elles parlent; -ent is silent for all verbs

question: Conjugate venir in the subjonctif tense.
answer: que je vienne + que tu viennes + qu'il/elle/on vienne + que nous venions + que vous veniez + qu'ils/elles viennent

question: It is possible that you will never return.
answer: C'est possible que tu ne reviennes jamais.; C'est possible que triggers the subjonctif. REVENIR is the infinitive.; JAMAIS replaces PAS.

question: I prefer (présent indicatif) that you go to the park (subjonctif).
answer: Je préfère que tu ailles (subjonctif) au parc.; NB: préférer has a slight variation (change accent aigu to accent grave) au présent in all but the nous and vous forms.; The expression of a preference (I prefer) triggers the subjonctif in the phrase (that you go to the park).; ALLER is irregular in subjonctif.

question: I would prefer (conditionnel) that you go to the park (subjonctif).
answer: Je préférerais que tu ailles (subjonctif) au parc.; NB: The change of accent in conjugation of préférer is only applicable au présent so no change to the accent in this case (conditionnel).; Statements in both the présent and conditionnel forms can trigger the subjonctif in the second phrase.; ALLER is irregular in subjonctif.

question: My preference is X.
answer: Ma préférence est X.

question: She wants the meal to be ready by 8 o'clock.
answer: Elle veut que la repa soit (ÊTRE au subjonctif) prêt pour huit heures.; VOULOIR triggers the subjonctive. And we can use the subjonctive because the subjects of the two phrases (she and the meal) are different.

question: She wants to please everyone.
answer: Elle veut faire plaisir à tout le monde.; 'She wants...' would trigger the subjonctive. But we can't use that because the subject of the two phrases (she and she) are the same. So just use the inifinitive to express the desire.

question: How do you use the subjonctif for something in the future (e.g. It's necessary that you take the bus tomorrow.)?
answer: There is no different future form of the subjonctif tense. Just use the present subjonctif form.; Il faut que tu prennes (subjonctif present) le bus demain.

question: I must cry.
answer: Il fait que je pleure (subjonctif).; This is by far the most common way of expressing that you must do something (not with devoir and not with avoir besoin).; The literal translation of 'il fait' is 'it is required'. This always triggers the subjonctif in the subsequent phrase (Il fait que + SUBJONCTIF).

question: She must go to the store before she watches TV.
answer: Elle doit aller au magasin AVANT QU'ELLE regarde la télévision.; 'before doing something' is usually expressed using AVANT QUE + SUBJONCTIF)...avant que triggers the subjonctif.; So we use DEVOIR in the first phrase because we are using the subjonctif in the second phrase.

question: I hope that the sky is blue.
answer: J'espère que le ciel est (présent indicatif) bleu.; ESPÉRER (to hope) does NOT trigger the subjonctif. It is an exception to the subjonctif rules. So we use présent instead here.

question: They hope that you will eat well.
answer: Ils/Elles espèrent que tu mangeras (futur simple) bien.; ESPÉRER  (to hope) does NOT trigger the subjonctif. It is an exception to the subjonctif rules. So we use futur simple instead here.

question: I think that we have a cat.
answer: Je ponce qu'on a un chat (AVOIR au présent indicatif).; PONCER does not trigger subjonctif when it is used in the positive sense.; NB: PONCER does triggers subjonctif when it is negated.

question: I do not think that education the president is close to the people.
answer: Je ne ponce pas que le président soit (ÊTRE au subjonctif) proche de gens.; PONCER does not trigger subjonctif when it is used in the positive sense. But PONCER does triggers subjonctif when it is negated.

question: I believe that education is a human right.
answer: Je crois que l'éducation est (ÊTRE au présent indicatif) un droit humain.; CROIRE does NOT trigger the subjonctif when it is used in the positive sense.; NB: CROIRE does triggers subjonctif when it is negated.

question: I do not believe that you have a dog.
answer: Je ne crois pas que tu aies (AVOIR au subjonctif) un chien.; CROIRE does not trigger the subjonctif when it is used in the positive sense. But it does trigger subjonctif when it is negated.

question: What do you want me to say?
answer: Que veux tu que je dise?

question: I was running all week.
answer: J'ai couru toute la semaine.

question: I had a lot of energy from the party.
answer: J'ai eu beaucoup d'énergie suite à la fête.

question: I have big news to share.
answer: J'ai une grande nouvelle / une nouvelle importante. (literally: I have great/important news.)

question: good news + bad news + no news
answer: une bonne nouvelle + une mauvaise nouvelle + pas de nouvelle

question: keys
answer: des cles; remember you can't just use a noun; there must always be an article in front of it (the or a); if the noun is plural then your choice are les (the) or des (some..l like a).

question: an umbrella
answer: un parapluie

question: a charger
answer: un chargeur

question: a watch / a clock
answer: une montre / une horlage

question: a change purse
answer: un porte-monnaie

question: a wallet
answer: un portefeuille

question: a banknote
answer: un billet

question: a coin
answer: une pièce de monnaie

question: change (as in some coins)
answer: de la monnaie / des espèces

question: a bill (money)
answer: un billet ('bee-yay')

question: money; give the proper name and the slang
answer: de l'argent (proper) + de sous (slang; it is always plural); Je ne plus beaucoup de sous. = I don't have much money.

question: tissues
answer: des mouchoirs

question: a pen
answer: un stylo

question: a subway ticket + a theater ticket + a museum ticket
answer: The word used depends on the location: un ticket de métro + un billet de théâtre + un billet de musée

question: a ticket for X event
answer: un billet pour les épreuves de X.; There is a Z liaison between les and épreuves.

question: a movie + a trailer (for a movie)
answer: un film + une band-annonce

question: a toothbrush
answer: une brosse à dents

question: a personal camera
answer: un appareil photo

question: a professional video camera
answer: une camera

question: a telephone (mobile)
answer: un téléphone

question: land-line telephone vs old-fashioned telephone
answer: teléphone fixe vs le combiné

question: a laptop
answer: un ordinateur portable

question: keyboard (same as piano)
answer: le clavier

question: headphones
answer: les écouteurs (liaison z between); another older word for headphones is: un casque audio

question: a chalkboard
answer: un tableau

question: a computer mouse
answer: la souris

question: internet users
answer: internautes

question: a social network
answer: un réseau social ('rue-so-so-sial')

question: a reason
answer: une raison; The S sounds like Z because single S and it is between two vowels.; Make sure you make the strong closed 'ohn' sound for last syllable.; This differentiates it from the word for grape - une raisin ('ray-suhn'; in like ingénieur)

question: the primary/largest reason (for something)
answer: The idiomatic way to say this: la raison pour laquelle (the reason why).; Technically you could translate directly to: la plus grosse raison (the biggest reason) but this sounds weird in french.

question: the people + the characters
answer: les gens + les personnages

question: a friendship
answer: une amitié

question: the friend
answer: depends on gender: l'ami(e) (m/f); Masculine and feminine forms are pronounced the same.; NB: Avoid using mon ami(e) / mes amis when talking about platonic friends because this sounds like boyfriend/girlfriend in french. Instead use un(e) ami(e) or des amis.

question: a good friend + best friends
answer: un bon ami (m) / une bonne amie (f) + des meilleurs amis

question: 2 to 3 friends
answer: des amis; It's not idiomatic to say deux ou trois amis.

question: idiomatic way to refer to a classmate - a person that you went to school with and were friendly with but who is not necessarily as close to you as a friend
answer: two options: 1) un copain/une copine (m/f) is more modern 2)un/une camarade (literally: comrade) is less modern but still used

question: idiomatic way to refer to someone you work with but who is not necessarily a friend
answer: un/une collègue

question: a roomate
answer: colocataire

question: 2 steps to the train
answer: à deux pas du train

question: It's very convenient.
answer: C'est très practique.

question: book of metro tickets
answer: carnet

question: getting around
answer: SNCF trains (TGV are very nice) + RATP + metro

question: a road + a street + a pedestrian street
answer: une route + une rue + une rue piétonne; Take care because route is a bit of a 'false friend' - it means the pavement itself.

question: an avenue + a boulevard
answer: une avenue + un boulevard

question: on the avenue + on the boulevard
answer: DANS l'avenue + SUR le boulevard; Whether to use SUR or DANS has to be memorized.

question: on the road + on the street
answer: SUR la route + DANS la rue; Whether to use SUR or DANS has to be memorized.

question: in the plaza + in the street + in the photo
answer: SUR la place + DANS la rue + SUR la photo; Whether to use SUR or DANS has to be memorized.

question: a pathway + a bike path
answer: un chemin + une piste cyclable

question: a journey
answer: un voyage

question: a path (for your career)
answer: parcours; This can also mean path (un chemin) or journey (un voyage) but it can additionally be used to describe a path in life or work.

question: to drive (conjugate it)
answer: conduire; This is conjugated similar to dire. je conduis + tu conduis + il conduit + nous conduisons + vous conduisez + ils conduisent; past participle: conduit

question: We drove. + We were driving.
answer: On a conduit. + On conduisait.; NB: You can use the verb 'to drive' in french the same as you do in english. e.g. On a conduit (we drove) means that we were all on a roadtrip.

question: a bicycle
answer: un vélo

question: a motorcycle
answer: une moto

question: a car + a taxi
answer: une voiture + un taxi

question: a bus
answer: un bus; 'boos' the S is pronounced even though it is a final consonant because the origin of the word is foreign

question: a subway + a subway station
answer: le métro + la station de métro

question: a train + a train station
answer: un train ('tron') + la gare

question: a boat
answer: un bateau; -eau and -eaux is pronounced like a really strong 'oh' - like the word chateau; plural for all words that end in -eau is to add an X; So boats is les bateaux.

question: a sailboat
answer: un bateau à voile

question: an airplane + a flight + an airport
answer: un avion + un vol + un aéroport (4 syllables! 'ah-yah-ro-por')

question: an engine
answer: un moteur

question: How do you express that you will travel BY some form of transport (e.g. by train)?
answer: Use EN. en train + en avion + etc

question: public transport
answer: les transports en commun

question: one-way + roundtrip
answer: aller simple + aller-retour

question: a trip
answer: un trajet

question: the luggage + a suitcase
answer: les bagages (plural masculine) + une valise

question: a forest
answer: une forêt

question: the vineyard
answer: le vignoble ("veen-yo")

question: the nature
answer: la nature

question: the climate
answer: le climat

question: the tropics
answer: les tropiques; alternative: un climat tropical (a tropical climate)

question: the mountain(s)
answer: la montagne / les montagnes

question: the volcano
answer: le volcan

question: the ocean + the sea
answer: un océan + une mer

question: the river + the lake
answer: une rivière + un lac

question: the right bank + the left bank (of a river)
answer: la rive droite + la rive gauche; NB: sur berge = on the banks of river

question: the canal + the canals
answer: le canal ('kah-nal') + les canaux ('ka-noo'); The L in the singular form is pronounced.

question: the bridge + the port
answer: le poNt + le poRt

question: on the waterfront + the docks of the Seine
answer: sur les quais + les quais de Seine; pronounced 'kay'

question: a park on the Seine
answer: un parc SUR LA Seine; Use sur instead of dans. La Seine is feminine.

question: the beach(s)
answer: la plage / les plages

question: a beach cabana
answer: une cabine de plage

question: the sand
answer: le sable

question: the sky + the atmosphere
answer: le ciel + l'atmosphère (feminine)

question: a star + a planet
answer: une étoile + une planète

question: the Moon + the Earth
answer: la Lune + la Terre; These words are capitalized in french.

question: the fire + the fireworks
answer: le feu + le feu d'artifice; Fireworks is singular in french though plural in english.

question: the gift
answer: le cadeau

question: the checkout
answer: le caisses ('kes')

question: He goes to the checkout.
answer: Il va aux caisses.; à + les = aux ('oh')

question: shopping
answer: le shopping (remember 'le' is pronounced 'luh')

question: this bra
answer: ce soutein-gorge; soutein-gorge is actually masculine so use CE

question: this baseball hat
answer: cette casquette; casquette is actually feminine so use CETTE

question: these gloves
answer: ces gants

question: these pajamas
answer: ce pyjama; pyjama is singular in french but plural in english

question: this article (article is spelled the same in french but is masculine)
answer: cet article ('suh-tar-teecl'); normally we use CE for masculine singular but here the noun starts with a vowel so we change CE to CET; cette and cet are pronounced exactly the same because the T sound is required in cet to manage the following noun that starts with a vowel.

question: this summer
answer: cet été ('set-a-tay'); Êté (summer) is masculine so we would normally choose CE. But the noun starts with a vowel so we change CE to CET.; cette and cet are pronounced the same. The T sound is required in cet (even though an E does not follow the final T) in order to manage the following noun that starts with a vowel.

question: this island
answer: cette île ('se-teel'); Île (island) is feminine. Use CETTE regardless of whether or not the noun starts with a vowel.; Cette and cet are pronounced the same.

question: this apartment + this house
answer: cet appartement (masculine but use cet because starts with vowel) + cette maison (feminine)

question: I wear all black.
answer: Je porte tout en noir.

question: the color
answer: une couleur; The noun for color is feminine. But when you use a color as a noun (e.g. the blue) then it is always masculine (e.g. le bleu).

question: the (color) white + white (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le blanc + blanc ('blon') / blanche ('blonch') / blancs (masculine plural; pronounced same as masculine singular) / blanches (feminine plural; pronounced same as feminine singular)

question: the (color) black + black (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le noir + noir / noire / noirs (masc pl) / noires (fem pl); all four are pronounced exactly the same way

question: the (color) red + red (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le rouge + rouge / rouge / rouges / rouges; when an adjective ends in 'e' it has the same spelling for masculine and feminine

question: the (color) pink + pink (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le rose + rose ('roos') / rose / roses / roses; Adjectives that end in 'e' are the same for masculine and feminine.

question: the (color) orange + orange (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le orange + orange ('or-onj') / orange / orange / orange; We never add an 's' to orange.

question: the (color) yellow + yellow (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le jaune + jaune ('jown') / jaune / jaunes / jaunes; 'au' makes a strong 'oh' sound; if you say 'joon' that is a different word meaning young

question: the (color) green + green (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le vert + vert ('ver') / verte ('vert') / verts (masc plural) / vertes (fem plural)

question: the (color) blue + blue (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le bleu + bleu ('blu') / bleue / bleus / bleues

question: the (color) purple + purple (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le violet + violet ('vee-oh-lay') / violette / violets / violettes; Use 'bordeaux' to describe a deep wine color

question: the (color) brown + brown (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le marron + marron ('meh-ron') / marron / marron / marron; same spelling and pronunciation for all four forms

question: the (color) gray + gray (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le gris + gris / grise / gris / grises; The adjective already ends in 's' so the masculine plural is same as masculine singular (gris).

question: silver
answer: argenté(e)

question: golden
answer: doré(e)

question: bright (in color)
answer: lumineux

question: light (in color)
answer: clair

question: dark (in color)
answer: foncé/sombre

question: She wears light blue shoes.
answer: Elle porte des chaussures bleues claires.; chaussures are plural and feminine so the adjectives must agree; do not forget to use an article before the noun

question: He wears a dark yellow jacket.
answer: Il porte une veste jaune foncée.

question: I like green. + He likes orange.
answer: J'aime le vert. + Il aime l'orange.; do not forget that there must be an article before every noun and - in this case - green is a noun instead of an adjective

question: Do you have it in white?
answer: Vous l'avez EN blanc

question: a place
answer: un lieu ('lyew'; to make plural add x) OR endroit

question: a space
answer: un espace; the green spaces (in a city e.g. parks) = les espaces verts

question: a store
answer: un magasin ('ma-ga-zOn'); Take care because this is a 'faux ami'. un magazine ('ma-ga-zEEn') is like Vogue; alternative: la boutique (more like a shop)

question: a mall
answer: un grand magasin; e.g. Le Bon Marché + Les Halles + Le Printemps + La Samaritaine; This does not mean department store (e.g. BHV - Bazar de l'Hotel de Ville)

question: the clothing store
answer: le magasin de vêtements

question: the jewelry shop + jeweler (m/f)
answer: la bijouterie + bijoutier/bijoutière (m/f)

question: the market(s)
answer: le marché / les marchés ('mar-shay'); NB: When there is an accent on the E it means market. Without accent it means I walk ('marsh')

question: the fruit or vegetable stand
answer: le primeur ('pree-mur')

question: the pastry shop
answer: la pâtisserie

question: the bakery + the baker (m/f)
answer: la boulangerie ('boo-lan-jree') + le boulanger (masc 'ay') / la boulangère (fem 'ehr'); NB: Drop the 'e' in 'erie'. Do not say all the syllables like 'boo-lan-jear-ree' - instead just say 'boo-lan-jree'.

question: We go to the bakery.
answer: On va à la boulangerie.; Use à la OR au (à + le) OR aux (à + les) when you are talking about a place/location.

question: She goes to the cinema.
answer: Elle va au cinéma.;à + le = au ('oh')

question: at your place
answer: chez toi; do not use à or en in this case; chez includes the at - always just say chez moi + chez Marie etc; never à chez moi

question: You (informal) are in Marseille. You (informal) go to Marseille.
answer: Tu es à Marseille. Tu vas à Marseille.; Use à for being in a place and for going in the direction of a place (that is definitely not a person or a person's home).

question: the butcher shop + the butcher (m/f)
answer: la boucherie + le boucher / la bouchère

question: the fish shop + the fishmonger (m/f)
answer: la poissonnerie + le poissonier / la poissonière

question: the cheese shop + the cheesemonger (m/f)
answer: le fromager + le fromager OR le crémier / la crémière; NB: There is no feminine version of fromager.; The name of a cheese shop is an exception because it looks like the masculine version of a cheesemonger.

question: the floral shop + the florist (m/f)
answer: le fleuriste (like the person) + le fleuriste / la fleuriste; There is no word for floral shop (except maybe magasin de fleur). Use the word for the florist - like I'm going to the barber/hairdresser.

question: They go to the floral shop.
answer: Ils vont chez le flueriste.; There is no word for floral shop. So one always says they are going to the florist which is a person (not a place) so use chez instead of à.

question: the wine shop + the wine merchant (m/f)
answer: la cave de vin + le caviste

question: the chocolate shop + the chocolate merchant (m/f)
answer: la chocolaterie + le chocolatier / la chocolatiere

question: the bank
answer: la banque

question: the post office
answer: la poste

question: the mailperson
answer: two options: 1) le postier is a person who works at the post office; 2) le facteur is a person who delivers the mail

question: the laundromat
answer: la laverie

question: the dry cleaners
answer: le pressing

question: a cobbler store + a cobbler person (masc + fem)
answer: une cordonnerie + un cordonnier/une cordonnière (m/f)

question: a hair salon + a hairdresser (masc + fem)
answer: un coiffeur ('qwuh-fuhr') + un coiffeur/une coiffeuse (m/f); Le coiffeur (how you call the salon) is a person - not a place - so use chez instead of à when you say you go to the hair salon (like going to the barber).

question: I got a haircut.
answer: This is not translated literally. Instead say: I went to the barber. = Je suis allé(e) chez le coiffeur.

question: a pharmacist (m/f)
answer: un pharmacien / une pharmacienne

question: a pharmacy
answer: une pharmacie

question: a doctor (m/f)
answer: one word is most common for both: médicin (skip the pronunciation of the middle i) ...you can't make the word feminine because then it would be the word for medicine; a less common word to use is: un docteur / une doctoresse

question: a patient (m/f)
answer: un patient / une patiente

question: the reception desk (of a doctor's office)
answer: l'accueil du cabinet médical; NB: médical (medical) is an irregular adjective. It becomes médiCAUX when it modifies a plural noun. e.g. les cabinets médicaux = the medical offices

question: the person that works the reception desk of a doctor's office
answer: le/la secrétaire (same for m/f) OR l'assistant(e)

question: a doctor's office + an exam room (at the doctor)
answer: un cabinet du docteur + le cabinet médical

question: a (medical) clinic
answer: une clinique

question: a hospital
answer: un hôpital

question: health insurance (public) + health insurance (private + supplemental)
answer: une assurance maladie/santé + une mutuelle

question: the social security number
answer: le numéro de sécurité social; This is the number on the carte vitale.

question: the social safety net
answer: la sécurité sociale

question: I do not have mutuelle insurance yet - only public health insurance.
answer: Je n'ai pas DE mutuelle encore - seulement la sécurité sociale.; Use DE because a negative amount is still a quantity.

question: I have a headache. / My head hurts.
answer: J'ai mal à la tête.;à + la is ok as-is

question: My feet hurt.
answer: J'ai mal aux pieds.; à + les = aux

question: I have a stomach ache.
answer: J'ai mal au ventre.; à + el = au

question: I have a soar throat.
answer: J'ai mal à la gorge. / Ma gorge me fait mal.; To say that you hurt somewhere it is AVOIR + MAL + à + le/la/les + X.; To say that something hurts you... X + ME + FAIRE + MAL

question: My knees hurt.
answer: Two possibilities: 1) J'ai mal AUX genoux. (à + les = aux); 2) Mes genoux me font (FAIRE) mal.

question: I caught a cold.
answer: J'ai attrapé un rhume.; attraper is the verb 'to catch' and we use it the same way in french as in english.

question: I have a fever.
answer: J'ai de la fièvre.

question: to get sick
answer: s'enfermer (reflexive)

question: to cough
answer: tousser; eg. Je tousse

question: to sneeze
answer: éternuer

question: to be seasick
answer: AVOIR le mal de mer

question: painful (adjective) + a pain/hurt (the noun)
answer: douloureux/douloureuse + une douleur

question: It must have hurt.
answer: Ça a du (passé composé form of DEVOIR) être douloureux.; Literally: It must have been painful.

question: idiomatic ways to say: Get well soon. + Take care of yourself.
answer: Bon rétablissement. + Prends soin de toi.

question: the health
answer: la santé

question: the symptom
answer: le symptôme

question: a medical treatment
answer: un traitement

question: medicine
answer: two options: le médicament is for when you take medicine; la médecine is the subject of medicine - what doctor's study

question: a dose (of medicine)
answer: une dose ('doze') with a closed/ferme 'o' sound and downward tone.

question: a pill + a tablet + a lozenge
answer: une pilule + une tablette + une pastille

question: I will write an order for the pharmacy/laboratory.
answer: Je vais préparer l'ordonnance pour la pharmacie/le laboratoire.

question: I will prescribe X to you.
answer: Je vais vous prescrire X.

question: What is the common way to express: X is required. / X is necessary.; What is the infinitive of the verb?
answer: Il faut...; FALLOIR is the infinitive. The meaning is similar to DEVOIR but FALLOIR is only ever conjugated for 3rd person singular (il/elle/on). FALLOIR communicates that some ambiguous 'it' or 'one' must be or do something.

question: What is the difference between: Il faut... and Il faut que...
answer: IL FAUT + INFINITIV is even more general / less aggressive than IL FAUT QUE + PHRASE SUBJONCTIF.; Both of these options are more general / less aggressive than using the verb DEVOIR. e.g. Vous devez faire X. = You (personally) must do X.

question: What are two generalized / non-aggressive ways to say: You/One must take the medicine.
answer: 1) Il faut prendre le médicament. 2) Il faut QUE vous preniez le médicament.; The former is the most generalized way. It uses an infinitive. The latter is slightly more targeted/personal and uses a subjonctif phrase.; Both are more generalized in comparison to using DEVOIR: Vous devez prendre le médicament.

question: What are two generalized / non-aggressive ways to say: We must win this match.
answer: 1) Il faut gagner ce match. 2) Il faut QU'on gagne ce match.; The former is the most generalized way. It uses an infinitive. The latter is slightly more targeted/personal and uses a subjonctif phrase.; Both are more generalized in comparison to using DEVOIR: On doit gagner ce match.

question: What is a very direct / confrontational way to say: You must eat healthily.
answer: Vous devez manger sainement.; This is much more directy than: Il faut manager sainement. or Il faut que vous manger sainement.

question: What are three progressively direct / confrontational ways to say: You must go to the doctor.
answer: Most generalized using FALLOIR + INFINITIV: Il faut aller chez médecin.; Slightly more targeted using FALLOIR + SUBJONCTIF: Il faut QUE tu ailles (subjonctif) chez le médecin.; Most direct/confrontational using DEVOIR: Tu doit aller chez le médecin.

question: Using FALLOIR what are two ways to say: You/One must rest.
answer: 1) Il faut SE reposer. (more generalized / less aggressive); 2) Il faut TE/VOUS reposer. (still generalized but slightly more personalized / confrontational); SE REPOSER is reflexive. This means that there is an additional layer of subtlety that can be used simply by changing whether or not the reflexive pronoun is conjugated after Il faut...; NB: Il faut que... and Vous devez... would both be more direct / confrontational than the two options for reflexive verbs that use Il faut...

question: I must wait.
answer: Il faut que j'attende.; It is more common to express this using FALLOIR (instead of using DEVOIR).; Il faut que triggers the subjonctiv so j'attende is in the subjonctiv form.

If the other person is in a rush then it is possible to say 'un baguette s.v.p.' but this is an exception.

question: When ordering something in a market/store/etc. how do you contruct the opening phrase?
answer: Use the partitive articles (du/d' + de la/de l' + des/d') initially to indicate an unspecified quantity.; e.g. Bonjour je voudrais du café / de la farine / de l'huile / des pommes; NB: du = de + le and des = de + les because 'de le' and 'de les' are not used. D' occurs when du or des are followed by a noun that starts with a vowel.

question: When ordering something in a market/store/etc. how do you contruct the second half of the phrase?
answer: After opening with a general statement of what you want in unspecified quanities... then specify the amount. Doing so will replaces partitive articles with DE or D' - only two options.; e.g. 500 grammes de café / un paquet de salade / une carafe d'eau / plus de pommes.; D' occurs when de is followed by a noun that starts with a vowel.

question: How do you know whether to use à vs de vs pour in front of an infinitive verb?
answer: Use 'pour' if you could replace the phrase with 'in order to do x'. You are providing a reason/explanation for doing something.; The remainder use à or de but you have to memorize those. 'de' can usually be used to replace 'from'. 'à' can usually be used to replace 'to'.

answer: en Virginie + en Californie; Note that the spelling changes!; Use en instead of à when describing a region/territory. à is reserved for cities and very specific locations (e.g. a musuem)

question: in Provence + in Normandy
answer: en Provence + en Normandie; Note that the spelling changes!; Use en instead of à when describing a region/territory.

question: a country
answer: un pays ('pay-yee'); This is pronounced very clearly as two syllables - not 'pay'.

question: in France
answer: en France (feminine); Names of countries are capitalized in French. Names of nationalities and languages are not capitalized in French.

question: in Canada + in England
answer: au Canada (masculine) + en Angleterre (feminine)

question: in Sweden + in Switzerland + in Belguim
answer: en Suède + en Suisse + en Belgique (all feminine)

question: in Spain
answer: en Espagne (feminine); pronounced all together 'uh-nay-spagn'

question: in United States
answer: aux États-Unis (plural); aux is pronounced 'ooh'

question: in Mexico
answer: au Mexique (masculine)

question: in Iraq / in Iran
answer: both are masculine but we can't write/say 'au' + vowel in french so we must use 'en Iraq' and 'en Iran'

question: in Austria + in Hungary
answer: en Autriche + en Hongrie (both feminine)

question: from NYC + from France
answer: de ('duh') New York + France; Both are feminine.

question: from Brazil + from Japan
answer: du ('doo') Brésil + Japon; Both are masculine.

question: from the United States
answer: des États-Unis ('day' because plural)

question: All countries that end in 'e' are feminine except for which six?
answer: le Mexique + le Mozambique + le Belize + le Cambodge + le Suriname + le Zimbabwe

question: I live in Paris.
answer: Je vis à Paris.

question: I live in France.
answer: Je vis en France. (feminine)

question: I would like to live in Mexico.
answer: Je voudrais vivre au Mexique. (masculine)

question: I come / am from New York City.
answer: Je viens de New York. ('vee-yun-duh')

question: I come / am from the United States.
answer: Je viens des États-Unis. (plural)

question: I am early / on time / late.
answer: Je suis en avance / à l'heure / en retard.; En avance and en retard are the correct choice for describing arrival. But if you are describing departure (or a person or thing) then use plus tard and plus tôt.

question: exactly on time
answer: pile à l'heure

question: late (in the day) / early (in the day)
answer: tard / tôt

question: Sorry for being late.
answer: Je suis désolé(e) D'avoir été en retard.; Use DE after Je suis désolé(e) to explain for what you are sorry.

question: I'm sorry that I am not able to come.
answer: Je suis désolé(e) DE ne pas pouvoir venir.; Use DE after Je suis désolé(e) to explain for what you are sorry.

question: He arrived early. + He left the party early.
answer: Il est arrivé en avance. + Il est parti la fête plus tôt.; NB: En retard is used for arrival. Plus tard is used for departure (of people or things).

question: She arrived late.  + She left the party late.
answer: Elle est arrivée en retard. + Elle est partie la fête plus tard.; NB: En retard is used for arrival. Plus tard is used for departure (of people or things).

question: We talked late into the night.
answer: On a parlé jusqu'à tard dans la nuit.

question: It was a long time ago. + It's been a while.
answer: Il y a longtemps. + Ça faisait longtemps.

question: time (in general)
answer: le temps ('ton'); It has an S even when singular; Caution: Le temps can mean weather + time + tense of a verb.

question: nice weather
answer: la beau temps; Use temps instead of méteo to express this.

question: a good time
answer: du bon temps = having a good time

question: I need more time. / We have lots of time.
answer: J'ai besoin de plus de temps. / On a beaucoup de temps.; NB: Both plus and beaucoup are quantities so we use DE before the noun.

question: It takes a lot of time. / It will take a lot of time.
answer: Ça prend beaucoup de temps. / Ça prendra (futur simple) beaucoup de temps.; Different verbs are used to mean 'it takes' in different circumstances including: PRENDRE + METTRE + DEMANDER

question: It took a lot of time to fix the leak.
answer: Il a fallu beaucoup de temps pour; Il a fallu is FALLOIR in passé composé - the verb that is only conjugated in 3rd person singular.; It means a general/ambigous it 'took' or 'required' something.; We use the same verb in the present tense to talk about how something is required or must be.; Different verbs are used to mean 'it takes' in different circumstances including: PRENDRE + METTRE + DEMANDER

question: I need to practice more.
answer: J'ai besoin DE pratiquer plus.

question: I need to rest.
answer: J'ai besoin DE rester.

question: It takes a lot of practice.
answer: Ça demander beaucoup DE pratiquer.; Alternatively you can use: Ça demander beaucoup d'entrainements. This avoids the use of the 'anglo' pratiquer.;  Different verbs are used to mean 'it takes' in different circumstances including: PRENDRE + METTRE + DEMANDER.; Use DE between beaucoup and the verb because it is still a quantity.

question: I takes an hour (to do something).
answer: Je mets une heure...; Different verbs are used to mean 'it takes' in different circumstances including: PRENDRE + METTRE + DEMANDER

question: a lot of waiting
answer: beaucoup D'attente; Use DE between beaucoup and the verb because it is still a quantity.

question: the waiting room
answer: la salle D'attente

question: Can we practice asking questions?
answer: Pouvons nous pratiquer à poser des questions ?; This is a common way to use the verb pratiquer. If you really want to avoid that 'anglo' word then an alternative is to use the verb s'entraîner: Pouvons nous s'entraîner à poser des questions ?

question: X is the opposite of Y.
answer: X est le contraire de Y.

question: What/which do you choose?
answer: Qu'est-ce que vous choisissez?; remember single S is pronounced 'z' but double S is pronounced 'z'

question: It is difficult to choose the correct verb tense.
answer: C'est difficile DE choisir le bon temps.; Use DE - not POUR - in this situation.

question: the pronoun
answer: le pronom

question: Where do you place pronouns (that are objects of the verb) au présent?
answer: If there is only one word representing the verb in présent then pronouns come before that verb; NB: This is true for all tenses where a single word represents the entire verb.

question: Where do you place pronouns (that are objects of the verb) au présent when using two verbs (e.g. I want to dance.)?
answer: in between the conjugated HELPER and the INFINITIVE; NB: For any tense... whenever you need two different verbs where one is a conjugated HELPER and the other is the INFINITIVE... then pronouns usually are placed before the infinitive - but not before the helper verb.

question: Where do you place pronouns (that are objects of the verb) au passé composé?
answer: before both the AUXILLIARY conjugated form of avoir/être and the PAST PARTICIPLE; NB: This does not violate the general rule that pronouns come before an infinitive when using two verbs together (e.g. I want to dance) because there is no infinitive in passé composé - there are two words acting as verbs but they are viewed as a single verb (auxiliary + past participle). So the pronouns are placed before both the auxiliary and past participle.

question: Where do you place pronouns (that are objects of the verb) au imparfait and conditionnel?
answer: If there is only one word representing the verb in imparfait then pronouns come before that verb; NB: This is true for all tenses where a single word represents the entire verb.

question: Where do you place pronouns (that are objects of the verb) au futur proche?
answer: in between the conjugated form of ALLER and the INFINITIVE; NB: This follows the rule of dual verbs. Whenever you need two different verbs in french where one is a conjugated HELPER and the other is the INFINITIVE (e.g. I want to dance = Je veux danser)... then pronouns usually are placed before the infinitive - but not before the helper verb.

question: Where do you place pronouns (that are objects of the verb) au futur simple?
answer: If there is only one word representing the verb in futur simple then pronouns come before that verb; NB: This is true for all tenses where a single word represents the entire verb.

question: List the french pronoms sujets (aka subject pronouns) e.g. YOU went to the store.
answer: je + tu + il/elle/on + nous + vous + ils/elles

question: What is a COD (compléments d’objet direct) aka a direct object?
answer: An object that receives or experiences the action of the verb. e.g. I bought IT.; COD (direct objects) generally follow a verb when spelled out. If we use a COD pronoun then the pronoun moves in front of the verb.

question: List the french COD pronoms.
answer: me + te + le(m)/la(f) + nous + vous + les(m/f); me + te + le/la change to m’ + t’ + l’ in front of a vowel or mute H.; NB: The COD pronouns for he/she/they are the same as the definite articles (le/la/l'/les).

question: What is a COI (compléments d’objet indirect) aka an indirect object?
answer: An indirect object receives a direct object or is 'for whom' the action of the verb is done. e.g. I gave THEM the book.; Indirect objects follow a verb when spelled out.; NB: When a preposition is used in front of the object (for THEM) then it is technically NOT an indirect object (and is not receiving the direct object) in English. Instead we call it an 'object of a preposition'. e.g. I gave the book to THEM. The coffee is for HIM.; That noun 'him' is required to be present. The preposition 'for' doesn't make sense without 'him'.

question: List the french COI pronoms.
answer: me + te + lui(m/f) + nous + vous + leur(m/f); me + te change to m' and t' in front of a vowel of mute H.; NB: The COI pronouns for him/her/them are genderless. LUI is used for both masculine and feminine.; NB: LEUR does not have an S when used as a COI pronom. But leur can also be a possesive adjective (e.g. their cat = leur chat). When leur is used as a possesive adjective then it must agree with the number of the noun that it describes (e.g. their cats = leurs chats).

question: Sometimes we do not use a COI pronom to reference an indirect object or object of a preposition. When is that the case?
answer: Use COI unless it is one of the many special cases where pronoms toniques is used. This depends - among other things - on the preposition (or lack thereof) required by the verb - which is not consistent between English and French. You cannot translate directly from English.; NB: In English the treatment of pronouns for indirect objects and objects of a preposition are the same. The pronouns taking the objective case: him/her/them.

question: Which COD and COI pronouns are the same? Which are different?
answer: They are mostly the same: me + te + nous + vous. The only perspectives in which they differ are 3rd person singular (le/la vs lui) and 3rd person plural (les vs leur).

question: When we have both a COD pronom and a COI pronom in a sentence they are both placed before the verb. Which one is placed first?
answer: COI; General order: Subject + COI pronom + COD pronom + Verb.; Exception: When both pronouns are in the 3rd person then the order is reversed.

question: What are pronoms toniques?
answer: Pronouns that are used in french in some special circumstances (including for emphasis). Sometimes pronoms toniques replace COI when referring to indirect objects. Sometimes they are used to show possession. Pronoms toniques ALWAYS refer to a person (never a thing). Do not use a tonique pronom if you are referring to a thing.; Other names for these pronouns: stressed pronouns + disjunctive pronouns + pronoms disjunct.

question: List the pronoms toniques.
answer: moi + toi + lui(m)/elle(f) + nous + vous + eux(m)/elles(f); me + te change to m' and t' in front of a vowel of mute H.; NB: Pronoms toniques differ by gender in 3rd person singular AND plural. (This is not surprising considering that pronoms toniques are always used to refer to people - never to things.); For example... 'to him/her/them(m)/them(f)' does not adapt to gender because TO triggers COI: lui/lui/leur/leur. BUT 'with him/her/them(m)/them(f)' must adapt to gender because WITH triggers tonique (assuming that we are referencing people): avec lui/elle/eux/elles.

question: What are the special scenarios where we use pronoms toniques?
answer: Most importantly you can only use a tonique pronom when referencing a person (not a thing). Then the scenarios include (but are not limited to): 1) a short response to question (e.g. Who is there? I am! = Moi!); 2) a double subject - a very french structure (e.g. Me` I am... = Moi` je suis... ); 3) indirect objects when we are forced - in french - to place a preposition (like APRÈS AVEC DANS DEVANT POUR SANS CHEZ...) in front of the pronoun; 4) in comparisons after QUE - remember that QUE contracts to QU' when followed by a vowel (e.g. bigger than her = plus grand qu'elle; bigger than them masculine = plus grand qu'eux); 5) a shortcut for ownership called independent possessive pronouns (e.g. mine = à moi); 6) together with -même (e.g. moi-même = myself + elle-même = herself + lui-même = himself); 7) After C’est... and Ce sont... (e.g. Ce sont EUX qui sont venus ici = They(m) are the ones who came here.)

question: for me + you + him/her + us + you guys + them(m/f)
answer: POUR triggers pronoms toniques (as long as the pronouns reference a person): pour moi + toi + lui/elle + nous + vous + eux/elles

question: with me + you + him/her + us + you guys + them(m/f)
answer: AVEC triggers pronoms toniques (as long as the pronoun references a person): avec moi + toi + lui/elle + nous + vous + eux/elles

question: his + hers + theirs(m) + theirs(f)
answer: à lui + elle + eux + elles; Use pronoms toniques to show ownership when the owner is a person. It also requires preposition À in french.

question: I walk the dog (gender not specified).
answer: Je marche le chein.; MARCHER does not use a preposition for its direct object (the dog).; Objects of the verb (direct and indirect) are placed after the verb (unless they are represented by pronouns).

question: I walk it (the male dog). + I walk it (the female dog).
answer: Je LE marche. + Je LA marche.; The dogs are direct objects of the verb. So we use the COD (le/la) pronouns.; All pronouns that represent objects of the verb are placed before the verb.

question: I help her/him. + I can help her/him.
answer: Je L'aide. + Je peux l'aider.; AIDER does not use a preposition for its direct object (him/her). So we use the COD (le/la) pronouns.; Use l' to avoid two vowels together.; All pronouns that represent objects of the verb are placed before the verb.

question: I bring you (informal). + I bring you (formal). + I bring us.
answer: Je T'amène. + Je VOUS amène. + Je nous amène.; AMENER does not use a preposition for its direct object (you/us). So we use the COD (te/vous/nous) pronouns - though the COI pronouns in these cases are exactly the same.; All pronouns that represent objects of the verb are placed before the verb.

question: I bring them (all masculine). + I bring them (all feminine).
answer: Je LES améne. (same for both); AMENER does not use a preposition for its direct object (them). So we use the COD (les) pronouns.; All pronouns that represent objects of the verb are placed before the verb.

question: She gives the hen to Anna. + She gives IT to ME.
answer: Elle donne la poule À Anna. + Elle ME LE donne.; DONNER does not use a preposition of its direct object (the cat). DONNER uses À for its indirect object (Anna).; All pronouns come before the verb. If a phrase includes both COD and COI pronouns then the COI pronoun comes first. UNLESS both pronouns are in the 3rd person - then the order is reversed.

question: She gives IT (feminine) to you (informal).
answer: Elle TE LA donne.; 'It' is a COD (la). 'You' is a COI (te) because DONNER uses À before its indirect object.; All pronouns come before the verb. If a phrase includes both COD and COI pronouns then the COI pronoun comes first. UNLESS both pronouns are in the 3rd person - then the order is reversed.

question: She gives IT (feminine) to him/her.
answer: Elle LA LUI donne.; 'It' is a COD (la). 'Him/her' is a COI (lui) because DONNER uses À before its indirect object.; All pronouns come before the verb. If a phrase includes both COD and COI pronouns then the COI pronoun comes first. UNLESS both pronouns are in the 3rd person - then the order is reversed.

question: She gives IT (feminine) to us.
answer: Elle NOUS LA donne.; 'It' is a COD (la). 'Us' is a COI (nous) because DONNER uses À before its indirect object.; All pronouns come before the verb. If a phrase includes both COD and COI pronouns then the COI pronoun comes first. UNLESS both pronouns are in the 3rd person - then the order is reversed.

question: She gives IT (feminine) to you (formal).
answer: Elle VOUS LA donne.; 'It' is a COD (la). 'You' is a COI (vous) because DONNER uses À before its indirect object.; All pronouns come before the verb. If a phrase includes both COD and COI pronouns then the COI pronoun comes first. UNLESS both pronouns are in the 3rd person - then the order is reversed.

question: She gives IT (feminine) to them (m/f).
answer: Elle LA LEUR ('leuhr' same as heures) donne.; 'It' is a COD (la). 'Them' is a COI (leur) because DONNER uses À before its indirect object.; All pronouns come before the verb. If a phrase includes both COD and COI pronouns then the COI pronoun comes first. UNLESS both pronouns are in the 3rd person - then the order is reversed.

question: We work for me. + We work for you (informal).
answer: Nous travaillons pour MOI. + Nous travaillons pour TOI.; The preposition pour triggers pronoms toniques as long as the pronoun references a person.

question: We work for him. + We work for her.
answer: Nous travaillons pour LUI. + Nous travaillons pour ELLE.; The preposition pour triggers pronoms toniques (which disambiguate between genders in 3rd person) as long as the pronoun references a person.

question: We work for us. + We work for you (formal).
answer: Nous travaillons pour NOUS. + Nous travaillons pour VOUS.; The preposition pour triggers pronoms toniques as long as the pronoun references a person.

question: We work for them (masculine) + We work for them (feminine).
answer: Nous travaillons pour EUX ('oo'). + Nous travaillons pour ELLES.; The preposition pour triggers pronoms toniques (which disambiguate between genders in 3rd person) as long as the pronoun references a person.

question: We go without them (unspecified gender).
answer: On va sans EUX.; The preposition sans triggers pronoms toniques so the object of the preposition (them without specified gender) translates to EUX (instead of les or leur). is the tonique pronoun for them (male).

question: It is difficult for them (all women) to travel.
answer: C'est difficile pour ELLES de voyager.; The preposition pour triggers pronoms toniques so the object of the preposition (them feminine) translates to ELLES (instead of les or leur).

question: Simone is stronger than her.
answer: Simone est plus forte qu'ELLE.; Using the comparator QUE triggers the pronoms tonique. So we use ELLE to represent 'her' (instead of la or lui).

question: Michael and I are playing tennis.
answer: Michel et MOI jouons au tennis.; When there are two or more subjects in french and any of them are pronouns... this triggers pronoms toniques (moi instead of me).; NB: One way to think of this: Michael WITH me. AVEC triggers the use of the pronoms toniques.

question: Who is going to the beach? He is! She is!
answer: Qui va à la plage? Lui! Elle!; When answering a question quickly in french like this it triggers the pronoms toniques which disambiguate between gender in the 3rd person. So use lui/elle (disambiguated) instead of le/la or lui (ambiguous).

question: They (unspecified gender) want to come too.
answer: EUX aussi veulent venir.; When using emphatic phrases (words like aussi + non plus + seul) it triggers the pronoms toniques (eux - or elle - instead of les or leur).

question: You want me to 'do something'.
answer: Tu veux que je... ; VOULOIR triggers the subjonctif to express this (You want that I...). We do not translate it directly with a direct or indirect object (me).

question: If some noun/pronoun is an indirect object in English then will it also be an indirect object in French? Why?
answer: No. Not necessarily.; French and English verbs differ in their use of prepositions. This means that a verb might use a preposition in English but not in French (and vice versa). The presence/absence of a preposition can often determine whether or not the object of the verb is direct or indirect. So you have to memorize whether how each french verbs us prepositions in order to know which pronouns to use for the objects following the verb.

question: We listen to our mothers. + We listen to THEM.; Explain the selection of the french pronoun for 'them' in this case.
answer: Nous écoutons nos mères. + Nous LES (COD) écoutons.; In English the verb that means 'to listen to something' requires a preposition TO and its object is indirect. But in french the verb ÉCOUTER does not use a preposition and its object is direct (not indirect). So when we replace the object (mothers) with a pronoun we use COD (les) instead of COI (leur).

question: We call our mothers. + We call THEM.; Explain the selection of the french pronoun for 'them' in this case.
answer: Nous téléphonons À nos mères. + Nous LEUR (COI) téléphonons.; In English the verb that means 'to call someone' does not require a preposition and its object is direct. But in french the verb TÉLÉPHONER requires the preposition À and its object is indirect (not direct). So when we replace the object (mothers) with a pronoun we use COI (leur) instead of COD (les).

question: She likes her. + She likes it (la fromage).; Explain the exception in choosing the object pronoun.
answer: Elle l'aime. + Elle aime bien./Elle aime ça. (NOT Elle l'aime.); This is a special case where we sometimes omit the object pronoun completely in french. AIMER is intended to be used for people (not objects). So in the first sentence we can replace her with the pronoun LA. In the second sentence the object is an inanimate object so we use ça (or omit it completely) instead of using the COD pronom (la/le).

question: He hates her. + He hates it (la fromage).; Explain the exception in choosing the object pronoun.
answer: Il la deteste. + Il deteste ça. (NOT: Il la deteste.); This is a special case where we sometimes omit the object pronoun completely in french. DETESTER is intended to be used for people (not objects). So in the first sentence we can replace her with the pronoun LA. In the second sentence the object is an inanimate object so we use ça (or omit it completely) instead of using the COD pronom (la/le).

question: I know of him. + I know of it (le gorgonzola).; Explain the exception in choosing the object pronoun.
answer: Je LE connais. + Je connais. (NOT Je le connais.); This is a special case where we sometimes omit an object pronoun completely in french. CONNAÎTRE is intended to be used for people (not objects). So in the first sentence we can replace him with the pronoun LE. In the second sentence the object is an inanimate object so we use ça (or omit it completely) instead of using the COD pronom (la/le).

question: Define transitive and intransitive verbs. Give examples.
answer: Transitive verbs can take a direct object. e.g. To put: He put the book on the table.; Intransitive verbs do not require a direct object. e.g. To die: John died.; NB: In English you cannot have an indirect object if there is no direct object.

question: Define linking verbs. Do they have direct/indirect objects?
answer: Linking verbs do not have action. They connect the subject of a sentence to some information. e.g. To be: Simone is a leader.; Linking verbs do not have direct objects. Therefore they also do not have indirect objects.

question: What is an independent possessive pronoun?
answer: An independent possessive pronoun is a shortcut for showing ownership where the pronoun stands on its own instead of being an adjective to the noun that is possessed. For example: This is my cat. 'my' is a possessive pronoun. 'cat' is the noun being possessed (by me). BUT... This cat is mine. 'mine' is the independent possessive pronoun - you could eliminate the cat entirely: It is mine.

question: How do you construct the independent possessive pronouns in french? (e.g. mine + yours ...)
answer: There are two ways to express these in french. In both cases you need a second word. 1) À + generic tonique pronoun (e.g. La chat est à moi. = The cat is mine.) These pronouns do not adapt to the number and gender of the possessed noun. They only adapt to the thing that has ownership.  2) DEFINITE ARTICLE + non-generic posessive pronoun (e.g. C'est mien. = It's mine. ...if the noun being owned is singular/masculine) In this second case the gender/number of the thing with ownership matters. AND both the article and the possessive pronoun change to adapt to the gender and number of the noun being owned.

question: What are the generic possessive pronouns in french? - the ones that do not adjust to the gender/number of noun being possessed
answer: Use À + the tonique pronoun that reflects the thing that has ownership: à moi (mine) + à toi (yours informal) + à lui (his) + à elle (hers) + à nous (ours) + à vous (yours formal or plural) + à eux (theirs masculine) + à elles (theirs feminine); This is the easiest way to construct possessive pronouns. Another way is to use the non-generic possessive pronouns. e.g. le mienne = mine IF the noun being owned is singular and feminine.

question: It is my pen.
answer: C'est mon stylo.

question: The pen is mine. (Use generic possessive pronoun with à.)
answer: Le stylo est à moi.; Generic possessive pronouns are just the tonique pronouns preceded by À. They do not need to adapt to the number and gender of the noun being possessed.

question: It is your (informal) pencil.
answer: C'est ton crayon.

question: The pencil is yours (Use generic possessive pronoun with à.).
answer: Le crayon est à toi.; Generic possessive pronouns are just the tonique pronouns preceded by À. They do not need to adapt to the number and gender of the noun being possessed.

question: Which book is yours? (Use generic possessive pronoun with à.)
answer: Quel livre est à toi?; Generic possessive pronouns are just the tonique pronouns preceded by À. They do not need to adapt to the number and gender of the noun being possessed.

question: It (masculine) is his / hers. Use generic possessive pronoun with à.
answer: Il est à lui / à elle.; Generic possessive pronouns are just the tonique pronouns preceded by À. They do not need to adapt to the number and gender of the noun being possessed.

question: It (feminine) is ours. Use generic possessive pronoun with à.
answer: Elle est à nous.; Generic possessive pronouns are just the tonique pronouns preceded by À. They do not need to adapt to the number and gender of the noun being possessed.

question: It (masculine) is yours (formal). Use generic possessive pronoun with à.
answer: Il est à vous.; Generic possessive pronouns are just the tonique pronouns preceded by À. They do not need to adapt to the number and gender of the noun being possessed.

question: It is their cat.
answer: C'est leur chat.; Only the gender/number of the cat matters because 'their' is a possessive adjective in this case...describing the cat.

question: It is theirs (all masculine). Use generic possessive pronoun with à.
answer: C'est à eux.; Now the gender/number of the people that make up 'them' matters because we are using a pronom tonique in the 3rd person.; Generic possessive pronouns are just the tonique pronouns preceded by À. They do not need to adapt to the number and gender of the noun being possessed.

question: It is their cat.
answer: C'est leur chat.; Only the gender/number of the cat matters because 'their' is a possessive adjective in this case...describing the cat.

question: It is theirs (all feminine). Use generic possessive pronoun with à.
answer: C'est à elles.; Now the gender/number of the people that make up 'them' matters because we are using a pronom tonique in the 3rd person.; Generic possessive pronouns are just the tonique pronouns preceded by À. They do not need to adapt to the number and gender of the noun being possessed.

question: What are all the forms (masc sing + fem sing + masc pl + masc pl) of the non-generic possessive pronouns that mean 'mine'?
answer: le mien + la mienne + les miens + les miennes; Do not forget the definite article. Choose the correct form based on the gender and number of the noun being possessed.

question: What are the two ways to express: The dresses are mine.
answer: 1) Les robes sont à moi. 2) Les robes sont LES miennes.

question: What are the two ways to express: The dresses are his. + The dresses are hers.
answer: 1) Les robes sont à lui (his). + Les robes sont à elle (hers). If you use a tonique pronoun the gender/number of the owner matters. 2) Les robes sont LES siennes. If you use the non-generic possessive pronouns the number/gender of the owner does not matter. But the number/gender of the owned noun matters.

question: What are all the forms (masc sing + fem sing + masc pl + masc pl) of the non-generic possessive pronouns that mean 'ours'?

question: She is as tall as you (are).

question: Everyone is going home.

question: What is an adverbial pronoun?
answer: It is a pronoun that represents a place or a quantity or the object of a preposition.; 1) there: I go to the store. I go there. There references the store - which also happens to be the object of the preposition 'to' (à).; 2) them: Cars... I have some of them/those. 'Them/those' references the object of the preposition 'of' (de).; 3) those/that: I have none of this/that. 'This/that' references the object of the preposition 'of' (de).

question: When do you use the pronom Y?
answer: Rule of thumb: Y is a pronoun that replaces a place. It means 'there'. e.g. Je vais À Paris. becomes... J'Y vais. (I go there.).; The more correct rule: Y is an adverbial pronoun that replaces a noun that is the object of the preposition À. Y can replace any noun that is the object of preposition À EXCEPT an animate object (including people).; This means that you first need to understand whether a verb requires À (use Y) or DE (use EN).; NB: If the structure is À + NOUN and the noun is an animate object...then use a tonique pronoun instead of Y.; Pronunciation: Pronom Y is pronounced 'ee'. So J'y is pronounced 'gee'.

question: When do you use the pronom EN?
answer: Rule of thumb: EN is a pronoun that replaces something that clearly or vaguely has a count/quantity to it. e.g. Je parle DE mon ami. (I talk about my friend.) becomes... J'EN parle. (I talk about them.). e.g. I want one (of those).; The more correct rule: EN is an adverbial pronoun that replaces a noun that is the object of the preposition DE.; This means that you first need to understand whether a verb requires À (use Y) or DE (use EN).; e.g. Il cherche DEs idées. (He looks for ideas.) becomes... Il EN cherche. (He looks for some.); NB: EN can replace a NOUN on its own or an entire phrase.

question: When is it difficult to determine when to use Y vs EN?
answer: For example when someone says: I'm thinking about X. And then the next sentence references X as a pronoun. Whether you use EN or Y to reference X depends on whether you say (in french) Je pense à X or Je pense de X. So you have to memorize whether to use verb + à X or verb + de X. Then this determines whether you use Y (replaces à X) or EN (replaces de X).

question: Where do you place pronom Y or pronom EN in a phrase?
answer: Pronom Y/EN are placed last after all over pronouns. This means that they are placed directly before the verb (before the auxiliary in passé composé).; NB: Only PAS (no pronouns) comes between the auxiliary and past participle in passé composé.

question: I went to Beijing. + I went there.
answer: Je suis allé(e) à Pékin. + J'y suis allé(e).; 'there' is an adverbial pronoun refering to 'Beijing'. In this case we use the pronom Y (instead of EN) because the verb (ALLER) is always followed by À (instead of DE).; Another way to remember this is that we generally use pronom Y when referring to a location.

question: I think about my country. + I think about it.
answer: Je pense À mon pays. + J'Y pense.; Use pronom Y (instead of pronom EN) because the verb PENCER uses À (instead of de). Therefore the object of the preposition (my country) is replaced with Y.

question: I think about Simone. + I think about her.
answer: Je pense À Simone. + Je pense À ELLE.; Use pronom tonique (instead of Y) because the verb PENCER uses À and the object of the preposition is a person. Therefore use the pronom tonique (elle) to replace Simone.

question: I'm interested in politics. + I'm interested in it.
answer: Je m'intéresse À la politique. + Je m'Y intéresse.; Use pronom Y (instead of pronom EN) because the verb SE INTÉRESSER uses À (instead of de). Therefore the object of the preposition (politics) is replaced with Y.

question: I change the train. + I change it.
answer: Je change DE train. + J'EN change.; Use pronom EN (instead of pronom Y) because the verb CHANGER uses DE (instead of à). Therefore the object of the preposition (the train) is replaced with EN.

question: I need a television. + I need one.
answer: J'ai besoin D'une télé. + J'EN ai besoin.; 'one' is an adverbial pronoun refering to 'a television'. In this case we use the pronom EN (instead of Y) because the verb (AVOIR besoin) is always followed by DE (instead of À).; Another way to remember this is that we use pronom EN when referring to a quantity of something (one television).

question: They want telephones. + They want some.
answer: Ils veulent des téléphones. + Ils EN veux.; 'some' is an adverbial pronoun refering to 'telephones'. In this case we use the pronom EN (instead of Y) because we are referring to a quantity of something (some phones).

question: I have it. + I do not have it.
answer: J'EN ai. ('zshoh-nay') + Je n'EN ai pas. ('zshuh-noh-nay-pah'); These are very common french expressions. This is typically how you express these phrases in french.; Use pronom EN to refer to the thing that you have or do not have because it clearly or vaguely has a count/quantity.; If you are really referring to a very specific thing that was explicitly discussed before this phrase then you can use a regular pronoun (e.g. le) instead of pronom EN to refer to 'it': I have it. = Je l'ai. (le + ai = l'ai)

question: I like to go to the Mediterranean Sea. + I like to go there. + I like the climate there.
answer: J'aime aller à la mer Méditerranée. + J'aime Y aller. (Y is placed before the infinitive verb that it modifies.) + J'aime le climat là-bas.; In the last case it doesn't make sense to use Y to replace 'there'. The verb AIMER must be connected to the object (le climat). What we really mean is that we like the climate 'over there'.

question: I am looking forward to the concert. + I am looking forward to being there.
answer: J'ai hâte ('hat') de le concert. + J'ai hâte d'Y être.; Use pronom Y to replace an event (the concert) even though the pronom DE is in play.

question: I have not gone to the Netherlands.
answer: Je ne suis pas allé(e) aux Pays-Bas.; Use ALLER instead of ÊTRE.; NE always comes directly after the subject (before any pronouns). PAS goes between the auxiliary and past participle in passé composé.

question: I have not gone there.
answer: Je n'Y suis pas allé(e).; Use pronom Y to replace À + location.; Use ALLER instead of ÊTRE.; NE always comes directly after the subject (before any pronouns). PAS goes between the auxiliary and past participle in passé composé.

question: I have never gone there.
answer: Je n'Y suis jamais allé(e).; Use pronom Y to replace À + location.; NE always comes directly after the subject (before any pronouns). JAMAIS replaces PAS (between the auxiliary and past participle in passé composé).

question: I have never gone to Japan or Vietnam.
answer: Je ne suis jamais allé(e) au Japon et au Vietnam.; You can use ET (and) or OU (or) here - they are both correct.; JAMAIS replaces PAS.

question: I have never BEEN to the Netherlands.
answer: Je n'étais jamais allé(e) aux Pays-Bas.; JAMAIS replaces PAS.; This is NOT passé composé! Use plus que parfait (past perfect; 'had been doing something') tense. Plus que parfait: être conjugated in imparfait + aller past participle.

question: I have never BEEN there.
answer: Je n'Y étais jamais allé(e).; Use pronom Y to reference À + location. NE always comes directly after the subject (before any pronouns). JAMAIS replaces PAS.; This is NOT passé composé! Use plus que parfait (past perfect; 'had been doing something') tense. Plus que parfait: être conjugated in imparfait + aller past participle.

question: I would install it. + I would like to install it.
answer: J'Y installerais. + J'aimerais Y installer.; INSTALLER uses À so 'it' is replaced by pronom Y.; Both sentences use the conditionnel.; The second phrase is a slight exception because pronom Y comes after one of the verbs (instead of before the verb which is generally the rule).

question: It's ONLY 30 minutes.
answer: Ce N'était QUE 30 minutes.; QUE replaces PAS to give emphasis... ONLY a friend. This does not negate the phrase. Generally if you omit PAS then negation does not occur.

question: He/she is ONLY a friend.
answer: Ce N'est QU'un ami.; QUE replaces PAS to give emphasis... ONLY a friend. This does not negate the phrase. Generally if you omit PAS then negation does not occur.; Use CE instead of il/elle. This is an idiomatic phrase.; NB: qu'un is pronounced 'kahn' not 'koon'

question: When do the standard rules for possessive adjectives not apply? ...what are the exceptions?
answer: When the object starts with a vowel or a silent 'h' ...french avoids a double vowel so you have to use the masculine possessive adjective even if the object is feminine; e.g. his year of birth = son année de naissance ...use 'son' even though annèe is feminine because sa annèe would be a double vowel sound

question: What is the general rule for adapting adjectives to gender and number?
answer: Add E to form feminine singular - this will force the pronunciation of the final consonant (that was silent in the masculine singular form) but it's a light touch on the consonant...it's not hard or heavy; Add S to form masculine plural; Add ES to form feminine plural; No change in pronunciation from the singular to plural forms of the same gender because the S and ES are generally silent.; There are many different variations of adjectives but this is the most basic transformation.

question: What is the difference in pronunciation between bon (good/masc) + bonne (good/fem) + beau (beautiful/masc)?
answer: The first two have an extreme nasal quality: 'boh' and 'bohn'. Shoot the sound up at the roof of the mouth and out the nose. The third (beau - like beaucoup) is not nasal and sounds exactly like the word 'bow' in English.

question: What is the difference in pronunciation between beau (beautiful/masc) + beaucoup?

question: best
answer: There are two possible translations and they all always include an article because 'the best' is actually always a noun. Adjectives must adapt (in number and gender) to the noun they describe.; LE MIEUX is the superlative for bien (well). question: worst

question: What are the two basic rules (not exhaustive) for transforming an adjective to an adverb (e.g. blind to blindly)?
answer: 1) If adjective ends in vowel (e.g. absolu): Add -MENT (e.g. absolument).; 2) If adjectives ends in consonant (e.g. amical(e)): Add -MENT to the feminine form (e.g. amicalEment).; These 2 rules ensure that adverbs have a vowel immediately preceding the -MENT ending. Sometimes (no rule of thumb) we add an accent to that E (e.g. obscur = obscure; obscurÉment = obscurely).; NB: Adverbs do not change form to agree with gender/number because they modify verbs - not nouns.

question: How do you transform an adjective that ends in -ANT or -ENT to an adverb?
answer: Remove the -NT. Then add -MMENT (with double m).; e.g. apparENT = apparent to apparEMMENT = apparently; NB: This is a group of exceptions from the general two rules for transforming adjectives to adverbs.

question: How do you avoid ending a phrase with a preposition (which would be grammatically incorrect in both french and english)?
answer: Use the word DONT at the beginning of the phrase.; This is roughly translated as from/with/of which OR from/with/of whom.

question: Here’s the family. I’m talking about this family. Here’s the family I’m talking about.
answer: Voici la famille. Je parle de cette famille. Voici la famille DONT je parle.; Use DONT to avoid ending the phrase with a preposition.

question: I have all the books that I need.
answer: J'ai toutes les livres DONT j'ai besoin.; Use DONT to avoid ending the phrase with a preposition.

question: I told you about my friend.
answer: J'ai parlé DE mon amie.; Use DE in this context when you mean 'about'.

question: She is the friend that I told you about.
answer: Elle est l'amie DONT je t'ai parlé.; Use DONT to avoid ending the phrase with a preposition.

question: She told me to wait.
answer: Elle m'a dit D'attendre.; The formula for telling someone to do something: DIRE + DE + INFINITIVE (of whatever you are telling them to do)

question: I’m suspicious of him. That is the man of whom I am suspicious.
answer: Je me méfie de lui. C'est l’homme DONT je me méfie.; Use DONT to avoid ending the phrase with a preposition.

question: I’m looking for a house. The house’s door is yellow. I’m looking for the house with a yellow door.
answer: Je cherche une maison. La porte de la maison est jaune. Je cherche la maison DONT la porte est jaune.; Use DONT to avoid ending the phrase with a preposition.

question: I have a lot of friends. Two of my friends are poets. I have a lot of friends - two of whom are poets.
answer: J’ai beaucoup d’amis. Deux de mes amis sont poètes. J’ai beaucoup d’amis - DONT deux poètes.; Use DONT to avoid ending the phrase with a preposition.
